A survey by a top recruitment firm found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees agree that titles create divisions among colleagues. Surprisingly, the survey revealed that 70% of office workers would prefer a more 'motivational' or 'professional' job title over a pay raise. If our desire for impressive titles is so strong that it surpasses even our basic greed, we are in a difficult situation. In today's world, no one wants to be seen as inferior. The job titles being discussed focus on skills (like specialist or coordinator) but are often just fancy terms.

I was in Vienna to take photographs. That was usually why I traveled anywhere. Photography was more than just my job; it was a big part of my life. I was always fascinated by how light fell on surfaces and how a single photo could capture the essence of a moment, a place, or a person. I always hoped to take the perfect photograph, and as long as I had film in my camera, there was a chance I might. My routine was simple: finish one roll, load another, and keep looking for that perfect shot. This had been my approach for a long time.

I once got lucky with a photo of a smoke plume from a burning oil well, which became very popular in newspapers and magazines worldwide. It was a brief moment of fame, but it was mostly luck. After that, I decided to work freelance, which seemed like a smart move. However, life outside photography didn't go as planned, and the mid-nineties weren't as successful as I had hoped, even though my photo had made it to the cover of Time magazine. That's why I was in Vienna, not somewhere more newsworthy. But I was still taking photos and getting paid for it, which wasn't bad.

The Vienna assignment came by chance. I had taken photos in London for a picture book called "Four Cities in Four Seasons," which included London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. The publishers liked my work, and when the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, left the Vienna job, they offered it to me. I was available, unlike the French and Italian photographers, and I was happy to go because things at home weren't great.

They put me up at the Europa Hotel in the heart of Vienna. I had been to Vienna before with my wife during a busy summer, but this time, in cold January, it felt different. I knew I would enjoy it and take great photos. On the first day, I didn't take any pictures. Instead, I rode the trams around the city, getting a feel for the place. The weather was cold and set, much like the grand old buildings of the city. I hadn't seen Schussner's work from other seasons because I wanted this to be my Vienna.

Photography is about capturing the right moment, so I waited and observed until I was ready. The next morning, I went out at dawn. Fresh snow had covered Stephansplatz, making it look untouched and almost empty. I struggled to capture the cathedral in one shot because its spire was tall and elegant, while the base was large and imposing. I realized I might have to settle for capturing just a part of it, but even that could be magical in the right conditions.

Photography has always had a magical quality, even for the pioneers of the 19th century before they fully understood the process. Watching a blank sheet of paper turn into a photograph in a darkroom is a mysterious experience, and even when you know how it works, the magic remains. That's why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning didn't completely surprise me.

**Kinetic Art Rejoice**  
Something remarkable has happened: London's serious Hayward Gallery has become a place of wonder. This change wasn't due to a big-budget, heavily promoted multimedia show, but rather a unique exploration of a nearly forgotten art form from the past 60 years. The new exhibition explores the history of kinetic art, which is art focused on movement, in the 20th century. It shows that creating art that moves or explores movement has been a consistent, though often overlooked, theme in fascinating creative work of this century. Curator Guy Brett, who has dedicated his life to studying kinetic art, has gathered a wonderful collection of paintings, drawings, documents, and films. These are presented with minimal text, allowing visitors to enjoy making their own connections and discoveries.

**David Hockney**  
David Hockney's art appeals to many people who might not usually be interested in art. This could be because his work is figurative and easy to understand, or because it offers an escape from everyday life. Some might be drawn to Hockney's charming personality and witty comments, which make him popular in the media. Some critics think Hockney is overrated, but this might be because being popular is not always seen as a good thing today. Hockney himself knows his limits and doesn't claim to be a great artist. He believes that only time will tell how his work is judged.

**Window-shopping - an art exhibition**  
In recent years, I've seen many contemporary art exhibitions, some brilliant and some mediocre. What bothers me are shows that push a hidden agenda, suggesting a common attitude among artists. Sometimes this works, revealing new trends, but often it feels forced. As a curator, I wanted to create a show that was the opposite of this. With seven artists, I took over a space in an empty warehouse. "Window-shopping" was a collection of individual artworks connected only by their claim to be art. For example, Sam Cole's knitted cats chased each other on a toy train track, while Matthew Crawley's video camera experiment flickered on a monitor. These works didn't fit into a themed exhibition, but they complemented each other through their contrasts. I didn't make any grand statements about contemporary art, but perhaps there aren't any to make about an activity where artists set their own rules.

**Art History**  
People who enjoy paintings sometimes hesitate to analyze them, fearing it might spoil their experience. Some say art historians, who focus on theory, ignore the pleasure of looking and the creativity of art. This is like thinking that knowing a recipe's ingredients and cooking method takes away from enjoying the dish. Understanding something doesn't stop us from enjoying it; it might even enhance our pleasure. Enjoyment is complex, and how we perceive it can be questioned. Our preferences are influenced by societal values, not just our genes or personalities. While it's important to appreciate the sensory and instinctive responses to art, the idea that intellect undermines these responses is outdated.

**Metals**  
Stone Age people might have first been interested in metals because they wanted to decorate themselves. Imagine sitting by a river, waiting to catch a fish, when one of our early ancestors found a shiny yellow pebble. It wasn't like a regular stone; it was attractive. This is how gold might have become part of their lives. Gold is easy to shape, so it quickly became a valuable material. Copper might have been discovered by accident too. Once people realized how useful copper tools were, they eagerly searched for copper ores and learned how to extract the metal. This marked the beginning of metalworking, an important skill for our ancestors.

**St Ives**  
We walked down the winding, cobbled lane into the town, carrying our bags and struggling against the strong wind. The icy waves crashed over the promenade, and the streets were empty. Every cottage by the waterfront had its shutters tightly closed against the storm. We had seen the weather getting worse as we arrived in St Ives on the small railway. The dark grey skies made us question our decision to visit Cornwall in the off-season without a car. I had convinced my friend to come with promises of beautiful coastal walks and cozy evenings by the fire.

**Computer Modelling**  
Studying the past is challenging because it is gone. The people who lived through peaceful times and hardships are no longer here. The reasons they settled in certain places or formed communities have been forgotten. Archaeology gives us some clues, but we can't test our ideas with experiments on past cultures. We can't watch the past like a movie. However, computer modelling offers a solution. We can recreate ancient landscapes and fill them with virtual communities. These digital people have some needs and abilities like real humans. We can set rules for their behavior and simulate changes, like less rain or more people, to see how these virtual societies react.

**Vervet Monkeys**  
Cheney and Seyfarth observed a group of vervet monkeys. One day, the dominant male noticed a strange male monkey nearby. This stranger wanted to join the group, which could mean trouble for the current leader. To prevent this, the dominant male used a clever trick. Whenever the stranger tried to approach, he gave an alarm call that vervets use to warn of a leopard. This scared the stranger back into the trees. The plan worked well until the dominant male made a mistake: he gave the alarm call while casually walking in the open, revealing his deception.

**What Cats Catch**  
In the English village of Felmersham, residents collected prey caught by their cats. Over a year, 70 cats caught over 1,000 animals. An American professor estimated that, based on these numbers, cats in Britain might be killing 100 million birds and small mammals annually. However, this calculation is misleading. Most cats live in towns, have smaller territories, and catch less prey than rural cats. The important question is whether these numbers are sustainable. The answer seems to be yes. Many people feed birds in winter, and gardens provide nesting sites, keeping bird populations higher than natural levels. The survey showed that while cats are significant predators, they are not destroying Britain's bird population.

**Buffalo's Day**  
Buffaloes are essential to marshmen and are well cared for. Each morning, the buffaloes leave their resting places slowly and with groans, heading to the reed beds. They stand at the water's edge, complaining about the day's work, until the leader finally steps into the water. Once in, they seem to forget their purpose and wallow for a while. Eventually, they move so gradually that it's barely noticeable. They spend the day in the reeds, grazing on green shoots, appearing almost submerged and exhausted.

**PICASSO, Pablo - The Soles, 1940**  
In early 1940, Picasso painted several still lifes of fish while staying in the fishing port of Royan. One painting shows a fishmonger's slab with a crab and some soles. Despite their situation, the sea creatures appear alive. The painting is complex, with overlapping and interlocking transparent planes. The thin, delicately brushed paint and cool colors create a calm, underwater feel. However, this is disrupted by a sense of an impending battle between the fish and the crab. The sharp forms and even a chain around one fish add a sense of menace and tension, giving the painting a symbolic depth.

Photography has been a powerful tool for capturing human life and activities for the past 150 years. It allows us to see moments that are brief or visualize things that are either very large or very small. Photography has shown us images from faraway places on Earth, distant parts of the solar system, and the complex social issues of modern life. It has become a crucial way to express the human experience.

However, using images to record events is not new. It dates back to the Upper Palaeolithic period, about 35,000 years ago, with early cave paintings. We don't know exactly why these paintings were madeâ€”whether they depicted real hunting events, served as magic to increase animals for hunting, acted as religious symbols, or simply decorated living spaces. But images have always been a part of human culture.

Throughout history, people have questioned how accurate visual images are and their importance in society. The saying "seeing is believing" has given visual images a special status. When photography was invented in the mid-19th century, it promised to provide a truthful visual record automatically. The camera, much like the human eye, was seen as a machine that could capture a fixed image, closely resembling what we see. This was a significant cultural achievement, as artists had long worked to develop the skills to create such images manually.

Photography's realism led to the belief that everyone could understand photographs, raising the question of whether photography is a "universal language." In 1933, photographer August Sander suggested that even isolated people could understand a photograph of the sky. However, with the rise of global communication in the late 20th century, we must consider whether photography can truly bridge cultural differences or if it is as culturally bound as language.

Photography is often seen as providing clear evidence, making it seem transparent and blurring the line between reality and its photographic representation. It's common for someone to show a photo and say, "this is my grandson." Since its invention in 1839, photography and attitudes towards it have changed significantly. Initially a tool for recording, photography has become a historical document, revealing much about the people and society that created it.

The camera is not just a silent recorder of events. Photography can inspire social and political change. Just as the development of perspective was crucial to the cultural changes of the Italian Renaissance, photography has played a major role in shaping our media culture and bringing the world's harsh realities into our homes.

**How to Write Poetry**

Writing poetry is like walking through a minefield: you need to be spontaneous, but one wrong move can ruin everything. Claiming to know everything about poetry is risky, so instead, I suggest that beginners focus on reading a lot, writing often, and freeing their imagination in any productive way, without causing chaos. Some people need stability in their lives to write poetry, while others can write even when they're unhappy. Some follow a schedule, while others wait for inspiration. All methods are valid as long as they aren't just copying someone else's style. The key is to find your own voice, nurture it, and let it grow until it can stand on its own.

**The Short Story**

In a short story, there's no space for too many characters or long narratives. Flashbacks should be brief and only used if necessary to clarify something. A good way to do this is through a quick memory in the main character's mind, which can help move the story forward. Dialogue is very useful because it can show different sides of a situation quickly and keeps the reader interested. Overwriting can ruin a short story, but that doesn't mean it should be as short as a summary. A short story needs to maintain conflict and action like a novel, but every word must be meaningful in a limited space.

**Screenplays**

Writing a screenplay is like playing chess. Many chess players make moves without knowing the outcome, seeing only a few moves ahead. As they learn more, they realize chess is about long-term strategy, not just short-term tactics. They start to see the whole game and recognize patterns, like openings and endgames. Similarly, the more you write screenplays, the more you understand their complexities.

**Looking at Writing**

Charles Darwin noted that humans naturally speak, as seen in children's babbling, but writing is not instinctive. Language exists in all societies and doesn't necessarily improve over time. Children learn to speak without formal lessons, and if they lack a language, they create one. Writing, however, has been invented only a few times in history, in complex societies, and has evolved slowly. Many children still struggle to read and write, even with education. Unlike speaking, writing is a skill that must be learned and understood, requiring effort to master.

I have never started writing a novel with more uncertainty. I call it a novel only because I don't know what else to name it. I have a small story to share, and it doesn't end with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave the reader hanging. This book is about my memories of a man I met only occasionally, and I don't know much about what happened to him in between those meetings. I could make up details to fill the gaps and make the story more complete, but I don't want to do that. I just want to write down what I know. To avoid embarrassing people who are still alive, I've given the characters in this story made-up names and taken care to ensure no one recognizes them. The man I'm writing about isn't famous. He might never be. When he dies, he might leave no more trace than a stone thrown into a river leaves on the water's surface. If my book is read at all, it will be for its own interest. But maybe his chosen way of life and his unique character will influence others, and long after his death, people might realize he was a remarkable person. Then, it will be clear who I'm writing about, and those interested in his early life might find something useful in my book. I think my book, despite its limitations, will be a helpful source for his future biographers. I don't claim that the conversations I've included are exact quotes. I never took notes, but I have a good memory for things that matter to me. I've written these conversations in my own words, but I believe they accurately reflect what was said. I mentioned earlier that I haven't invented anything, but like historians, I've added speeches to my narrative that I didn't hear myself. I've done this to make the scenes more lively and realistic. I want my book to be read, and I think it's fair to make it engaging. Intelligent readers will easily spot where I've used this technique, and they can choose to ignore it if they wish. Another reason I'm nervous about this work is that the people I'm writing about are from a different culture. It's hard to truly know people, and I think you can only really understand your own countrymen. People are shaped by where they were born, the places they grew up, the games they played, the food they ate, the schools they attended, the sports they followed, and the poets they read. These experiences make them who they are, and you can't fully understand them just by hearing about them; you have to live them. You can only truly know them if you are one of them. Because you can only observe people from a foreign culture, it's hard to portray them convincingly in a book. I've never tried to write about anyone but my own countrymen, and if I've done so in short stories, it's because you can describe characters more briefly there. You give the reader broad hints and let them fill in the details. In this book, I don't claim that my characters see themselves as I describe them; they are seen through my eyes, just like the main character.

At any point in history, the literary world can seem confusing to those experiencing it. It's only later, when we look back, that we see clear patterns and recognize which writers were truly important. Today, poetry is especially complex, with many different styles and debates about how poetry should be presented, criticized, and taught. There is a general divide between 'literary' poets, who write for their work to be read on the page, and 'popular' poets, who prefer performing their poetry to an audience. However, this division isn't strict. Public poetry readings have become more common over the past twenty years. These events happen in various places, like small town halls, schools, colleges, and arts festivals, where poets read and discuss their work with audiences.

For poets who write specifically for live performances, these events are beneficial. Their poems are often simple and easy to understand in one hearing, but might seem lacking when read on the page. On the other hand, poets who focus on crafting complex and thoughtful poetry might not be fully appreciated in a live setting, especially if the audience is hearing their work for the first time. The risk is that these poets might choose to read only their simpler, more accessible poems, which might not represent their best work.

Listening to poetry readings is not a replacement for reading poetry on the page, but it can be a valuable and enjoyable experience. Hearing poets read their own work can help listeners understand the emphasis and rhythm intended by the poet. It's helpful if the audience can follow along with the text or is already familiar with the poems. The main benefit of popular poetry recitals, sometimes mixed with music, is that they help people associate poetry with enjoyment, making it feel accessible to everyone, not just a select few.

**Oral History**

Historians are increasingly using oral evidence, but this method has challenges. It's a mistake to think that someone's spoken account is a perfect reflection of past events. During an interview, both the historian and the person being interviewed influence each other. The historian chooses who to interview and what topics to cover. Even if the historian just listens, their presence can change how the person remembers and talks about the past. The final account is shaped by the historian's social status compared to the interviewee and the way the historian has been trained to think about history, which might affect the interviewee's responses. Historians must acknowledge their role in shaping new evidence. Even without the historian, the interviewee's memories might be influenced by other sources, like the media, or altered by nostalgia or later life experiences. Emotions and attitudes can make the testimony seem convincing, but they might not accurately reflect the past.

**Animal Science**

Animal science can be approached in two main ways: focusing on physiology or on the whole animal. Physiologists study how the body functions, such as how nerves and muscles work together to create complex behaviors. Those who study the whole animal look at the behavior of the entire animal and what influences it. Within this approach, psychologists and ethologists are distinguished. Psychologists usually work in labs, studying how animals like rats and pigeons learn. Ethologists focus on natural, instinctive behaviors, often in wild settings. Although these fields are merging, physiologists often claim their methods are more fundamental. However, understanding every nerve cell's function doesn't eliminate the need to study behavior as a whole. Behavior has its own structure and must be studied at its own level. Describing a bird's nest-building by looking at nerve cells is like trying to read a book with a microscope.

**The Social Sciences**

New social science students face the challenge of learning both the content and the methods of their subject. They need to understand the knowledge and research findings in textbooks and the methods used to gather and organize this knowledge. These two aspects are closely linked. While social life might seem like common sense because of our daily experiences, social sciences go beyond this. Each social science focuses on a specific part of social life, uses particular study methods, and has its own concepts. These concepts form the 'logical basis' of the subject, allowing social scientists to move beyond everyday understanding and distinguishing each discipline.

**Classical Architecture**

In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building structures. According to the Roman architect Vitruvius, architecture involves order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, propriety, and distribution. He used Greek terms for some of these ideas, likely from an earlier Greek source. While utility and function aren't part of his definition, Vitruvius does discuss the best designs for different building purposes. However, he emphasizes architecture as an art form. Classical architecture has complex origins, with a long history of simple constructions in Greece and Italy that didn't meet Vitruvius' artistic standards. These early structures, though not artistic, contributed to the development of classical architecture. Despite its elaborate appearance, a classical temple is essentially a simple, single-roomed hut.

The two sisters, Lily and Mui, kept Lily's driving a secret from Chen for a while. Lily would drive around the allotments, near the railway line and gasworks, even jumping a small bridge with all four wheels off the ground, which was her only mistake. She would finish her drive near the gasworks, surrounded by the smell of sulphur. When Chen found out, he was amused rather than upset. "So you can really drive, Lily? Well done!" he said. Mui thought men were strange; she expected Chen to be angry, but instead, he was excited and started planning a trip with Lily. They decided on a Monday at the start of the next month, the quietest day of the week, to leave early and return by midday, so they wouldn't lose any customers. Meanwhile, Lily would practice driving around the allotments. Mui, despite her doubts, bought a road map and got a ten percent discount, which impressed Chen. Lily, however, felt a bit insulted by Mui's lack of trust in her navigation skills.

On the day of the trip, they left the house and, within an hour, were looking at the English Channel. Lily drove perfectly. Even Mui, who was ready to give directions from the back seat, had to admit this. Lily overtook a few slow vehicles with great skill, and Chen even applauded. After passing through the gasworks of a seaside town, they drove along the empty promenade. Lily parked in a street full of empty parking spaces, unsure of the road markings, and preferred to pay a fee rather than risk being towed or fined. She hoped this caution would reassure Mui. Lily had noticed Mui's tense face in the mirror during the drive and thought it best not to mention worries that hadn't occurred to her sister.

Lily locked all the van doors carefully. Chen joked, "Don't worry, no one will want that heap of tin." The sisters were annoyed. Lily accused Chen of being ungrateful, and Mui scolded him for being too easily fooled by appearances. Surprised, Chen took their son, Man Kee, to look at the sea. He lifted Man Kee onto the railing and held him close. Man Kee, warm and increasingly responsive, put his small hand on Chen's sleeve. In that moment, Chen decided to raise Man Kee his way, ensuring he got a good education in business and eventually owned many restaurants.

The sight of the sea made Chen feel thoughtful as he planned Man Kee's future. He saw a ship on the horizon and used a telescope to get a better look. At first, he couldn't find it, but then he saw it clearly: a small, old, rusty tramp steamer. He lifted Man Kee to the eyepiece. "Do you see the ship, Son?" he asked. "It's a special ship for people like us. It will take us back home when we're done here, to your homeland, which you've never seen." Chen kissed Man Kee's head. Lily and Mui joined them, and Chen let Lily look through the telescope. But by then, the ship had disappeared over the horizon, and all Lily could see were seagulls following the ship's wake.

THE WELL

I had read somewhere that if you looked up from a deep hole, you could see the stars during the day. I convinced you to help me test this idea. You watched nervously as I pulled up the well bucket, steadied it, and climbed in. I asked you to lower me down. I didn't consider how much heavier the bucket would be with me in it, or that you might not be strong enough to hold it. You tried to hold the handle but let go, and I fell into the well, hitting my head. At that moment, I didn't realize I had, in a way, achieved my goal. I saw strange lights, like the stars and planets in cartoons when a character gets hit. At first, I was dazed, then scared, then relieved, and finally angry at you for letting me fall and worried about what Mother would say. You called down to see if I was okay. I was about to shout back when your voice, filled with panic, stopped me. I lay still, watching you through my eyelashes. You ran off to get help. I quickly climbed out of the well and hid in the shadows near the moat bridge. I heard voices from the castle. Mother and Father came out with you and Arthur. Mother was frantic, and Father told Arthur to use the winch. You looked pale and shocked. I felt a mix of excitement and fear. Then I noticed the trail of water drops I had left from the well to my hiding spot. I was horrified that no one had seen them. Father shone a flashlight into the well, and the drops glistened in the sunlight. Mother was screaming, a sound that shook me deeply. I realized my prank had gone too far and would lead to serious consequences. I regretted not thinking it through. In a moment of desperation, I came out of hiding, pretending to be weak and disoriented. I claimed I had found a secret tunnel from the well to the moat and had crawled and swum through it. I thought I might get away with it until Father asked me to repeat my story. I hesitated, and his eyes narrowed. Trying to cover my lie, I said the tunnel had collapsed, making it pointless to check. Father looked at me with disbelief, as if seeing me for the first time. His words, "Don't be ridiculous, boy," were filled with contempt. He walked away, leaving me feeling exposed. Arthur looked at me with pity, not because of my adventure, but because he saw through my lie and worried about my character. His pity was a harsh rebuke, confirming the seriousness of my actions. It affected me deeply.

**REMOVAL DAY**

Susan, now a widow, is leaving her family home as her children have grown up. The moving van had "Removers of Distinction" written on it, and indeed, everything unique about the house was being packed away. Fred, the removal man, with his large, gentle hands, was carefully packing fragile items, while his team was less gentle. Susan was leaving a beautiful four-storey house overlooking a small harbour. The memories of her children growing up there lingered like dust in the air. 

When they first bought the house, her son Robert, then five, had asked, "Mum, when you buy a house, how do you get it home?" Now, Robert was there helping with the move, especially making sure Susan didn't mention the piano. Francesca, her daughter, was also helping, insisting that only she could handle the Steinway piano with enough care.

Fred, the removal man, noted that Susan didn't seem like she was going to cry. Susan asked if people often cried during moves, and Fred explained that they do, but they feel better once everything is at the new place. Susan could understand this feeling. She would have warned the movers about the piano, but Robert insisted it was their responsibility to notice any issues.

The piano was in the best room of the house and would be moved last. Sitting on the bottom stair, as all the chairs were gone, Susan remembered when they first moved in. The piano had been brought in first and got stuck on the stairs. The movers struggled for hours, and Francesca, then a child, cried, "We can't live in a house without a piano!" Her husband Peter had solved the problem by hiring a builder to remove a window and using a crane to bring the piano in. It was an expensive process, and they couldn't afford to tune the piano for months. Peter had said, "That's there forever," but forever is a long time.

Now, the children were busy, and Susan found it hard to move around the house. She thought about the stairs and the slightly misaligned banister rails from the piano incident. She should have warned the movers, but it was too late. Fred reassured her that only the piano was left to move. Susan, feeling emotional, moved from the stair. Robert and Francesca watched as the piano was carefully carried down the stairs and out the door. 

Once the piano was safely outside, they all laughed with relief. As they walked down the path for the last time, arm in arm, Susan's only tears were tears of laughter.

Online Literary Criticism For Everyone

The idea of open access to the Internet was always about letting anyone share their thoughts. In the beginning, you needed some technical skills to do this. But one area that really opened up to everyone was literary criticism. With Amazon.com, the first big online bookstore, anyone could write a book review. Amazon's approach was simple: anyone could say what they thought about a book and give it up to five stars. This seemed like a great idea because it allowed readers to see what others thought about a book, not just the publisher's description or professional critics' opinions.

Other online bookstores also offered similar features, but Amazon, being the largest, attracted the most reviews and, consequently, the most issues. With so many reviews submitted daily, it was impossible to check them all. Amazon had a team to ensure reviews followed their guidelines, like not allowing single-word reviews, personal attacks, or spoilers. However, since reviewers were anonymous, some mischievous activities went unnoticed. For example, authors could write positive reviews of their own books. Lev Grossman, an author, did this to counteract negative reviews of his first novel until he confessed in an article, leading to the removal of his fake reviews.

Authors could also comment on their books through a special link, but Amazon didn't verify if the comments were truly from the authors, except for famous ones. A fake comment pretending to be from John Updike was removed because it was clearly not genuine.

The real drama came from readers' reviews. When James McElroy's book about a cheerleading team was published, it got good reviews from the press, but people mentioned in the book felt betrayed and expressed their anger on Amazon. Many critical reviews appeared but were later removed.

Despite these issues, Amazon saw the high number of reviews as good for business. They monitored bestselling books closely to ensure reviews followed the rules. For less popular books, like "The Story about Ping," some reviews were humorous, using the book's plot to make jokes about Internet technology. However, most reviews were serious, and they provided a reliable indication of whether a book was worth buying.

The writer George Orwell once said that reviewing too many books meant inventing feelings about them. This makes the open and democratic process of online reviews a positive development.

**Art in Modern Times**

In the last two hundred years, we've started to think that every artist must rebel against the art of their time. We praise art for being unique, revolutionary, and even shocking. We admire artists whose work was not appreciated a hundred years ago. But when it comes to contemporary art, we often hesitate and say an artist has gone too far, questioning if it can still be called art. The media often voices these doubts for us, and we tend to agree because we expect art to be puzzling and new. This expectation makes us overlook the old themes, methods, and virtues present in today's art. We see artists as separate from the rest of us, with special talents and energy that break conventions. In the past, people commissioned art for specific purposes, making it part of everyday life. Today, we leave artists to their own devices and get annoyed if they try to be more relatable.

**Picture This**

Let me describe a situation and ask an important question about it. An artist selects a piece of text from an art book. The text talks about the variety of pictures, asking, "What are they all about?" and concludes, "There is no end to the number of different kinds of pictures." The artist then asks someone to prepare a canvas and take it to a sign painter. The sign painter is instructed to write the text on the canvas in simple black letters, without any fancy lettering. The question is: Is the finished product a painting?

**Underground Encounters**

At the Mercury Gallery in London until June 26th, there is an unspoken rule in the art world that once an artist finds success in a particular style, they should stick to it. Collectors expect consistency, and trying something new can upset them. Gallery owners prefer safe bets, and the art-buying public often seeks comfort in continuity. However, some artists, like Picasso and Hockney, have successfully broken this mold. Eric Rimmington is another artist challenging expectations. His new show moves away from the still lifes that made him famous to paintings of the London Underground. Railways have always fascinated Rimmington. After drawing the railway land of King's Cross Station in the 1980s, he naturally turned to the underground world. His exhibition, "Underground Encounters," features 40 paintings and drawings capturing the unique charm of this hidden world.

**Extract from a Novel**

I have come to this island with a few books. The villagers joke that only a sick person would choose such a remote place to rebuild. So, I am here to heal myself, if you want to put it that way. Apart from an old peasant woman who comes daily to clean, I am alone. I am neither happy nor unhappy; I feel suspended in memories. I spoke of art's uselessness but didn't mention its comforts. The solace in my work as a painter or writer is that in silence, reality can be reimagined and shown in its true form. Our everyday actions are like a rough covering hiding the true meaning beneath. For artists, art offers a way to reconcile with life's challenges, not to escape destiny like ordinary people, but to fulfill it through imagination. Otherwise, why do we hurt each other?

Text: 'Family Business'

"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were driving back to London. My father, with my brother Maurice, had just picked me up from the fancy girls' school I attended. He had also just sat through Parent's Day, where I received the Latin prize and the prize for doing best in my final exams. He had a long talk with my headteacher, and now we were heading home for the holidays.

"What isn't?" I asked, though I had a feeling I knew what he was thinking from his unusual silence. He was usually very talkative. "You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I was told you'll get a scholarship to Oxford."

"So?" I said, trying to act confident. "Mightn't that be useful?"

"I also hear," he continued, and I knew a confrontation was coming, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister of all things!" My father knew a lot about barristers and the law.

"I just said that," I replied. "I couldn't think of anything else to say!"

"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality - you can quickly understand complex information, you have the gift of talking, and you enjoy performing."

"I don't know about that," I said. "All I know is what I see in TV dramas."

"Be that as it may," he continued, pulling himself together, "I feel your heart's never going to be in the family business now. Obviously, you'll go to Oxford University, and after that, I can't see you wanting to join us."

The problem was that, like many children in family trades, I felt trapped by family expectations. I saw other career options and wanted to explore them. At the same time, I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was the favorite - but I found him intimidating.

"It's too soon to know," I said weakly.

"I tell you, you're not going to want to join us," said my father, who was annoyingly often right about such things, "and it's a pity because you've got the gifts - the brains, the nerves, the vision."

"There's still Maurice," I said, sulking. My father snorted. We both knew Maurice hated the business.

"Anyway," I continued, "you could always use me as a sort of consultant."

My mother wasn't around to help - she had died when I was young, and my father raised Maurice and me. Maurice was two years younger, and because he was motherless, I got used to taking care of him. It wasn't a hardship. I loved Maurice. Because the business was successful, we lived in luxury - a big house in London, posh schools, nice clothes, parties, theatres, operas. My father knew all kinds of people - politicians, actors, businessmen - and our house was full of interesting conversations and encounters.

"I tell you what," my father continued. "You can help us out during holidays until you leave Oxford, and then if you decide to leave us, you can. It will give you some pocket money and be a real help to me."

"OK," I said, relieved to avoid immediate decisions and especially the depression and sulks my father would fall into if I opposed him. This was how he controlled us.

So it happened. In my last term at school, and then during university vacations, I helped out, never more than twice a year, and always on the safer tasks. I became one of the smarter undergraduates, with a little house of my own, a small but powerful white car, designer clothes, and a black dress with a Paris label that I planned to wear for my final exams.

In my last term, my father visited me and took me to a village for a meal and a chat. There were only a few weeks left. My tutor predicted I would get a First Class degree in Law, and I knew that if I stayed focused and used these last days wisely, he might be right. I felt poised, confident, and concentrated.

This was not to be. My father told me that, in about a week, he needed me for one last assignment, the most important business the family firm had ever attempted, and that it would be worth my while.

"But Dad," I protested, "I've got my final exams coming up, and I need to focus on that. It's really important that I do well, and I don't want to think about anything else right now."

I could tell that such pressures were beyond my father's imagination (or maybe he was jealous of my life away from him?) and that he would see a refusal as a betrayal in his time of need. That wasn't all. As he described the procedures, I saw more clearly than ever his single-mindedness - the clarity and resourcefulness with which he approached his work, his dynamic energy, his perfect self-control. In his way, he was a sort of genius, and I respected that. It made my own plans and hopes seem less important.

"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with his wife, Lois. They could only afford it by being extremely careful with their money, which wasn't ideal. Initially, it seemed like a good decision because Simon had been successful in his legal cases, and Lois had returned to her advertising job with a salary increase to thirty-five thousand. Lois was the one who pushed for the move, arguing that their flat wasn't suitable for a family, and they needed more space, a garden, and a place for an au pair. These needs could have been met in a less expensive area, but Lois wanted more than just space. She felt their old address, Mornington Mansions, wasn't prestigious enough for their careers. 

To save money, Lois decided one of them should use public transport, and since her job was far away, Simon had to take the crowded tube. This commute left him feeling resentful and thinking about his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he was treated with care and respect after a long day. His grandmother was a traditional 'lawyer's wife,' involved in legal causes and content with her role. But times had changed, and Lois made it clear that her career was as important as Simon's. Their lifestyle depended on both their incomes.

Now, their situation was threatened by Venetia, who had confronted Simon with intense anger. She accused him of knowing that a client, Brian Cartwright, had bribed jurors in a past case and of accepting shares for his fiancÃ©e. Simon denied the accusations, but his denial felt weak even to himself. He was filled with guilt and remembered feeling similar shame in his school days. He wished he had been prepared and could have responded differently, but he lied, and Venetia saw through it. He wondered why she was so angry and what right she had to judge him. He feared that if the accusations spread, even as rumors, his career would be over.

I chose to live here because I thought I could be anonymous among people who didn't mind if their rented houses fell apart or if their gardens were overgrown. But I was wrong. People in the shops soon start to recognize you, even if you're not living your "real" life. The roses next door remind me that the gardens were once cared for. Usually, I stay inside, trying to ignore the summer outside, but tonight I'm watching the swifts fly between the treetops and roofs. I've cleared some space in the garden for a chair, and my arms are scratched from cutting back rosemary and lemon balm. It's a small London garden where plants have to grow tall or spread out to survive. 

My upstairs neighbor, Jaz, leans out of the window. She's written several unpublished manuscripts, and as an English teacher, I sometimes have to pretend to be interested. I have her latest one now. "How's the work going, Jaz?" I ask. "In no other job do you have to explain yourself a thousand times a day," she replies, then adds, "I'll bring something to drink." I don't really want Jaz in the garden, and I realize it looks messy. The only way to the garden is through my flat, and Jaz is knocking on my door. "You're on holiday now," she says, lounging in shorts and a vest. "I should've been a teacher. Writers don't get holidays. But you know what they say, those who can, do; those who can't, teach." And some can't do either. "What are your plans for the holidays?" she asks. 

I dread the end of the school year. Empty days, hot pavements, the walk to the shops, and loneliness in the park. "I'm going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed the cats?" I ask, my heart racing. "Of course," Jaz says, knowing she will be around. "Where will you stay? A nice B&B?" "No, with my oldest friend, Ruby, at the Rising Sun. We've known each other since we were eight." It's not true, but I often deal with fiction. "Going back to your roots. What do you think of my manuscript?" Jaz asks about her book, The Cruelty of Red Vans, which I haven't finished. I like the title and tell her so. Red vans can seem cruel, always bringing gifts to others and rejection letters to her. I decide to be honest. "Try writing about nice people for a change," I suggest. "Less focus on yourself, more fiction." "Teachers!" Jaz responds like a rebellious student. "I keep a journal," I say, "writing something good about each day." My words sound old-fashioned. "Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann." 

Oh, I have a life. I have my work, and I go out sometimes, reading on the tube. When we go inside, my calm kitchen reassures me. Then I remember my school geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, winking as she said, "I've had my moments." We nearly died laughing.

**Heritage**

Heritage is important because it connects people and communities to their past. We often feel linked to our personal heritage, knowing about our grandparents and their lives. Beyond this, there is a broader need to understand our past to help us interpret our individual and national futures. Heritage fulfills a basic desire for continuity, providing assurance about the past and, in turn, our future. Just as you inherit genes, you also inherit a culture passed down through generations. There may be parts of your national heritage you dislike, but it is still yours, and it is comforting to belong to something. Heritage teaches us a lot and is crucial for our well-being, influencing everything from customs to material culture. Traditionally, our connection to the past came from stories and legends passed down by ancestors. However, Western industrial society disrupted communities and families, leading to the loss of much oral tradition. Now, places and architectural 'memories' offer clues to our past. It is essential to preserve these links as a testament to our ancestors' identity.

**The Fens**

I started a novel, "Waterland," where the landscape of the Fens in England became significant. People often ask why I, a Londoner with no personal connection to the Fens, chose to write about it. The short answer is that I was drawn to the Fens because they seemed unobtrusiveâ€”a flat and empty stage for my book's drama. However, I learned that the Fens are neither flat nor empty. They are as richly English as any other part of England but also strangely compelling and haunting. It's remarkable that in the middle of England, there is a region that many English people find foreign, even when other unique areas of Britain have become part of the nation's cultural and literary heritage. The Fens are both empty and full, cultivated yet wild, seemingly open and obvious yet deeply mysterious. My research for the novel wasn't extensive; I haven't visited places like Wisbech or Prickwillow. As a fiction writer, I prefer imagining worlds and making inspired guesses rather than seeking documentary proof. Imagining the Fens has its logic because, as Edward Storey's book shows, the Fens are not just a landscape but a state of mind.

**Museums**

Museums must make their collections accessible. In the past, this meant putting items in display cases with long labels that were hard for the average person to understand. Today, accessibility means more. Displays should be lively and interesting, using theatrical or architectural techniques to capture visitors' attention and evoke emotions. Museums should do more than just display items; they should make their collections available to the widest community. For example, they can provide loan boxes of objects for teachers or use similar materials to help elderly people with memory loss. Museums focus on 'artefacts and specimens'â€”not replicas. They offer encounters with authentic items that existed and had meaning in history. This is their strength and what sets them apart from heritage centers, theme parks, books, and CD-ROMs. Museums that embrace this challenge and offer exciting, accessible displays, catalogues, and outreach programs will find that their competitors in 'virtual history' are actually allies, creating a desire for the 'real thing' that only museums can satisfy.

**Architecture and Environment**

The desire to preserve things is not new, but now changes in our towns happen so quickly and on such a large scale that most of us are affected. This turns some people into strong preservationists and encourages others to think more about the nature of towns today and their future. It can be argued that generations who have lived through events like world wars are more inclined to preserve things than those before themâ€”anything that represents stability becomes important. If there is a psychological need for preservation, it is part of the planner's job to consider it. Change is not an enemy if we learn how to manage it. Physical change in our towns reflects social changeâ€”changes in our population, welfare, and demands.

**Einstein**  
If you ask someone on the street to name a scientist, they will likely mention Albert Einstein. His image is often used to promote products that are associated with intelligence, like computers and encyclopedias. Most people don't know much about what Einstein actually did, except that he developed theories called 'relativity', which are known for being hard to understand and making strange predictions that seem to contradict everyday experiences. Einstein was part of a major change in scientific thinking, marking the start of modern science in the 20th century. Scientists were trying to create a new, more logical way to describe the universe by studying how matter and natural forces interact. Einstein made significant contributions by re-examining the basics: time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, scientists relied on Isaac Newton's idea of a universe where stars and planets moved in a fixed framework of space and time. Einstein challenged this idea, suggesting that time and space are not fixed but relative.

**Young Readers**  
When we were children, Lydia and I avoided any book that won a prize because we thought it would be 'worthy', which to us meant 'boring'. Our mother disapproved of our attitude, but our father would happily give us small amounts of money to encourage us to read these 'improving' books. He would also sneak in a few high-quality books among our Christmas and birthday gifts, marking them with a note saying, 'This Book is NOT Literature'. Although we often dismissed his choices as 'boys' books', he did manage to introduce us to some good short stories and, on one occasion, a well-known collection of poems.

**Language**  
In 1851, Jacob Grimm wrote that 'the origin of human language is truly secret and marvellous'. This mysterious origin has led to many strange theories. In 1928, Charles Caller suggested that early humans might have made sounds like "meuh" when they felt danger. "Meuh" sounds sad, and humans in a dangerous world full of scary animals might have made desperate noises. Some languages have kept echoes of these sounds, like the word malaria meaning "fever" or the Latin mors meaning "death". Because of such odd ideas, many people avoided discussing the topic, thinking it was for eccentric thinkers. However, recently, the origin and evolution of language have become important research areas. Language likely developed in East Africa around 100,000 years ago. It was mainly used for friendly communication and played a key role in power dynamics. Sharing information was probably not its original purpose, contrary to philosopher John Locke's view of language as a 'great conduit' for sharing knowledge.

Text: 'Writing Reviews Frank Kermode explores the art of writing reviews from the perspective of someone who does it. Most reviews are written and shared in ways that make them relevant for only a short time. There are deadlines and strict limits on their length. Once published, they are only relevant for as long as the newspaper or magazine they appear inâ€”usually a day, a week, or at most a month. The temporary nature of reviews often defines their literary value. Many people, including the writers themselves, often think that reviewing is a job done out of necessity, like needing extra money, or because they can't spend all day working on a novel or a serious book. However, reviewing is a skilled and complex task. Writing a concise and fair review in 600 to 800 words for a newspaper is different from writing a detailed 6,000 to 8,000-word piece for an international journal. A 1,500-word article in a weekly magazine combines challenges of both short and long reviews. Length isn't the only factor. Reviewers must consider their audience, from casual weekend readers to those deeply interested in the subject. A reviewer needs to know a lot about various topics and write in a way that intelligent readers can understand and enjoy. This means reviewers often write other things besides reviews. The American novelist John Updike, who isn't fond of criticismâ€”calling it "hugging the shore"â€”still enjoys writing reviews between his major novels. He collects all his reviews, even the short ones, into books with modest titles. While some might think less famous writers should accept the temporary nature of their reviews, there's no reason they shouldn't enjoy some recognition if they believe their best work is in their reviews. I feel this way about my own work. My main job has been academic, and most of my serious books are academic, the kind professors are expected to write. In the English-speaking world, unlike in some other cultures, there's no strict separation between reviewing and literary study, so it's common for the same people to do both. The days when academics criticized professors for writing reviews are mostly over, and complaints from non-academics about professors taking their work are less common, partly because there's more reviewing work available now. I believe this is good for readers, who can trust the reviewer knows what they're talking about, and for professors, as it helps them stay grounded. It also reminds them to communicate clearly with non-academics. While they might use complex language with each other, they need to be clear when addressing intelligent non-academics. Ultimately, reviewing is a secondary job. You can only do it well if you are also doing something else well.'

Ralph unlocked the door to his apartment and, as he stepped into the dark, still hallway, he felt a brief moment of doubt about owning the place. Even after three years, this feeling sometimes came over him when he returned home alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the flat, he would come home eagerly, often as early as possible, curious about what the flat had been like while he was away. It felt like a welcoming place where he was in control. He thought he should worry about things like intruders or plumbing issues, but the flat always seemed to be waiting for him, either looking independent or neglected, depending on whether he had left it tidy. Over time, he began to see it as just another part of himself, a space where his thoughts and feelings spilled over. He became frustrated that it couldn't change. Sometimes, there would be a small pile of letters by the door or the answering machine would be blinking with messages. He was thankful that the windows hadn't been broken or the place vandalized, though he wondered what it would look like if that happened. From his dull office on Holloway Road, Ralph often looked forward to his few evenings alone at home each week. Once he left the artificial world of the office and started to feel like himself again on the bus ride home, he realized he didn't need to be alone, a fact he often forgot when planning his social life. At his desk, he longed for solitude and time with his belongings, but once he escaped, he felt drained and waited in vain for a sense of self to return. Instead, he felt empty, suspecting that working in a job that didn't suit him had changed him, moving him away from who he thought he was. He would read or listen to music as the night went on, but he found himself questioning why he did these things. His sense of direction was unclear, and ideas would come and go without connecting. He remembered a time when he didn't feel so powerless, when he might have escaped if he had realized his own worth. But he had been eager to settle into something and followed the first opportunity that came along, as if it was meant to be. After university, he tried to make a plan for his future, but he wasn't surprised to find that he only wanted to survive quietly. He applied for jobs he heard about from friends, following their paths without imagining he could find work that would make him happy. He went to his only job interview with gratitude and didn't think to evaluate the positionâ€”a vague editorial role at a free local newspaper. He was relieved to have a pleasant conversation with Neil, his boss, and didn't consider the long meetings he would face daily. Neil offered him the job on the spot, saying Ralph was the only graduate who applied, which Ralph took as a compliment at the time.

**Goat Racing**

I was about to see a goat race on Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. The place was crowded with ice-cream vans, lots of people, food stalls, and loud music. Everyone was moving towards the racecourse, and I pushed through the crowd to find a good spot. A section was marked off for the race. It wasn't like a professional racecourse, but the idea was the same: spectators stood on either side of the track where the goats would run. Keeping the goats in order was a challenge since they are known to eat almost anything.

**Canoe Trip**

As the day ended, I started worrying about the night. The canoe was too wet to sleep in, and we hadn't seen any villages or huts since morning. In the dim moonlight, with our torch, we could barely see the cliffs. The torch batteries were dying, so we replaced them, but the new ones didn't work. It was clear we wouldn't find a camping spot. A few miles later, Lesley thought she saw a light, and we got hopeful, but it was just moonlight on the waves. Soon, we heard the loud noise of fast-moving water, but we couldn't see what was happening. Time seemed to stop as we continued on.

**How to be Presentation Perfect - we answer your questions**

I am not naturally good at making presentations, but as a managing director, I often have to present to my colleagues and major shareholders. How can I improve my presentation skills and confidence? 

You're not alone. Presenting requires different skills than running a company, but many senior executives need to be good at it. To convince your audience, you must first convince yourself. Show your belief through passion and enthusiasm in your presentation. This means you need to prepare well. Test your ideas in advance and ask colleagues to think of tough questions the audience might ask. Start by creating a positive atmosphere. Begin with something everyone can agree on and gradually lead to your conclusion.

Some activities simply cannot be rushed; they take the time they need. If you're late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you're impatient while making mayonnaise and add the oil too quickly, it will curdle. Similarly, if you pull too hard on a tangled fishing line, the knot will only get tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some mental tasks are done very quickly, while others take longerâ€”seconds, minutes, hours, days, or even years. Some tasks can be sped up, like solving crossword puzzles or doing mental math faster. However, other tasks cannot be rushed. If you try to hurry them, they might fail, like the mayonnaise, or become more complicated, like the fishing line. The idea of "Think fast; we need the results" can be as unrealistic or counterproductive as trying to fit a full night's sleep into half the time. We learn, think, and understand in various ways, and these mental processes work at different speeds, each suited to different tasks. "He who hesitates is lost," says one proverb. "Look before you leap," says another. Both are true. Generally, the mind has three different processing speeds. The first is faster than thought. Some situations require an immediate, instinctive reaction. For example, when my motorbike skidded on a wet road in London, my brain and body quickly coordinated a series of movements that kept me from falling. Only after the incident did my conscious mind and emotions catch up. A concert pianist or an Olympic fencer doesn't have time to think about their next move. This type of quick, physical intelligence can be called our "wits." Then there is thought itself: the kind of intelligence that involves figuring things out, weighing pros and cons, constructing arguments, and solving problems. A mechanic diagnosing an engine issue, a scientist interpreting experimental results, or a student working on an assignment all use this type of reasoning and logic, which we often call "intellect." People who excel at these tasks are often described as "bright" or "clever." Below this is another, slower mental process. It is often less focused and more leisurely or dreamy. In this mode, we are reflecting or contemplating. Sitting on a seaside rock, absorbed in the sound and motion of the waves, or hovering between sleep and wakefulness, we are in a different mental state than when planning a meal or writing a letter. This slower, seemingly aimless way of thinking is just as intelligent as the faster ones. Allowing the mind time to wander is not a luxury to be cut back when life or work becomes more demanding. On the contrary, slow thinking is an essential part of our cognitive abilities. We need the slow, thoughtful mind just as much as the quick, analytical one. Some everyday problems are better approached with a slow mind. Some mysteries can only be understood with a relaxed, open mental attitude. Recent scientific studies show that these patient, less deliberate ways of thinking are particularly good for understanding complex, unclear situations. Deliberate thinking works well when the problem is straightforward. For example, when deciding where to go on vacation, the options may be clear. But when we don't know what to consider or which questions to askâ€”or when the issue is too subtle for conscious thoughtâ€”we need the slow mind. If the problem is how to manage a difficult team at work or whether to change careers, it might be better to sit and think rather than rush for answers. This type of intelligence is linked to creativity and even "wisdom." Poets have long recognized the limits of conscious, deliberate thinking and have tried to nurture these slower, more intuitive ways of knowing. Philosophers have written about the parts of the mind beyond conscious intellect. Only recently have scientists begun to explore these slower, less deliberate ways of knowing. The field of "cognitive science" is discovering that the unconscious mind can accomplish many complex and important tasks if given time. It can learn patterns too subtle for normal consciousness, make sense of complex situations, and solve difficult problems more effectively than the conscious mind.

Surviving in a Foreign Land

I have been warmly welcomed here. It's a friendly and well-equipped base camp in a very remote area. At any given time, there are about forty people - scientists, students, weather experts, and satellite trackers - forming a close-knit community where everyone helps out. My basic French is just enough to communicate, but not for casual conversation or jokes. I miss the subtle meanings, and my phrasebook is useless at breakfast. This isn't a practical problem for me, but at first, it affected my self-confidence. I found myself slightly dreading mealtimes. I would hesitate, unsure of which table to choose, and felt anxious when everyone went silent as I spoke, a feeling I hadn't experienced since my early school days. I still smile awkwardly or panic when people talk to me. I think this occasional sadness isn't about missing company or communication, but because I've lost the social advantage my ability to talk has always given me.

Elliot

When I first met Elliot, I was just another young author, and he didn't pay much attention to me. However, he never forgot a face, and when we met again, he would shake my hand warmly, but didn't seem interested in getting to know me better. If I saw him at the opera with someone important, he often pretended not to see me. But then I had a surprising success as a playwright, and I noticed that Elliot started to show more interest in me. One day, he invited me to lunch, and I thought he was testing me out. After that, as my success brought me many new friends, I began to see him more often.

Alfred Hitchcock

The film director Alfred Hitchcock always said he didn't care much about the story or the acting in his films, but he did care about the photography, the soundtrack, and all the technical details. For Hitchcock, it wasn't the message or a great performance that moved the audience; he believed that people are affected by pure film, no matter their cultural background. So, if a film is designed correctly to have an emotional impact, audiences from Japan and India should react at the same moment. Hitchcock's view of himself was always clear, logical, and seemingly undeniable. He was a man of reason and a genius craftsman who enjoyed hearing an audience scream. He didn't deal with speculation, abstract ideas, or intellectual hints, and he didn't explore his screen characters deeply. He focused on film, pure film, and the precise, calculated beauty of what a strip of film can do to an audience.

**Amateur Astronomy**

Astronomy has changed a lot in the last 50 years. About 30 years ago, there were not many charts or catalogues. Telescopes were basic, and there were few books on how to do astronomy. Now, you can buy almost any telescope or equipment you need. Electronic calculators and computers have made it easier to create almanacs and charts, analyze observations, and publish results. This should be a great time for amateur astronomers. However, some things have been lost. You might need to travel 80 km to find a sky as clear as it was in cities 50 years ago. During the day, airplane trails can last for hours and turn into clouds, making it hard to observe the sun and stars.

**Too Much Choice**

Today, society has too many choices. There are too many things to do and too many options. In the modern economy, people always want the newest product or service, and technology speeds up these changes. New products come out quickly, making it hard to keep up. This can be stressful and disconnects people from life. More choices mean more stress, less time, and more complexity. People are now looking for 'simplexity'â€”simple things that bring meaning in a complex world. But simplifying life is hard when there are so many products and services. There are more types of detergent and breakfast cereals than we need, and too many software updates and phone plans to follow.

**McAndrews Hotel**

Every summer, we spend two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. It's a family tradition started by my grandmother and has become very important to us. We don't let anything disrupt this ritual. The guests at McAndrews are similar: old-fashioned, maybe a bit odd, and some might say snobbish. I dislike the rude behavior of shop assistants today, which is seen as being equal. I also don't like overly friendly waiters who seem like they might slap you on the back. I know most of the other guests' names because they have been coming here since they were children, like me. But I can be sure that when I see them around the hotel, we will only exchange polite greetings. Such respect for privacy is rare in hotels these days.

**Othello**

The transfer of an outstanding production of Shakespeare's play "Othello" from Stratford to London gives me a chance to correct a previous unfair review I wrote when the show first opened last spring. At that time, I criticized Ray Fearon for being too young for the role of Othello and underestimated his acting skills. Although I still believe that the age difference between Othello and Desdemona is important to the story, I must admit that Mr. Fearon's performance is truly remarkable. In fact, the entire cast is excellent. Notable scenes include Cassio's competitive games with other young officers, which become dangerously intense, and the moment when Iago starts to lose control and struggles to regain it. I dare anyone not to be moved to tears during the scene where Emilia helps Desdemona prepare for bed. The pace and tension throughout the play are incredible. Don't miss this production.

**Lake Vostok**

In the center of Antarctica, everything is still. While the edges of the continent are full of penguins, seals, and birds, the vast white plateau in the interior is lifeless. However, beneath nearly 4 kilometers of ice lies Lake Vostok, a huge hidden freshwater lake directly below the coldest place on earth. This water has been cut off from air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Biologists are eager to explore its depths and find out what unusual organisms might live there. Geologists and glaciologists are also very interested. For the past two years, researchers worldwide have been planning how to uncover the lake's secrets. If successful, the coming years could be known as the decade of Lake Vostok.

**Scientists**

There was an interesting discussion on the radio last week. It seems that a group of scientists is debating what motivates them to pursue science. The phrase "because it's there" comes to mind. We all know it's the timeless quest for knowledge and the desire to understand everything from atoms to black holes. But these scientists are curious about why we want to know all this in the first place and why science can't explain our curiosity. Surely, it's more important to consider whether what scientists are doing is right, rather than getting caught up in debates about the purpose of it all. I believe the key issue is not why we pursue science, but recognizing that science is a tool, and we should decide how, where, when, and why to use it.

**Food**

Our connection with food is basic and deeply satisfying. Many people who love cooking might already agree with this, as they often buy cookbooks like this one. We sometimes think that cooking is only worth it for special occasions or complex dishes, but that's not true. You can make a delicious soup just by putting some roughly chopped carrots, a leek, celery, and a few herbs into water. This is much more rewarding than buying a packet or opening a can. Instead of purchasing a chocolate mousse filled with preservatives and additives, you can make a delightful dessert in five minutes that both adults and children will enjoy. Cooking is also a way to show care and love by bringing your own creation, no matter how simple, to the table. Sharing food is rich in symbolism and meets our deepest human needs, which is why all our celebrations, like birthdays, anniversaries, and engagements, happen around tables. No one would have a takeaway for a wedding or anniversary party, and few would discuss a business deal over canned soup.

**In the Elevator**

This morning, Alistair tried to tidy up his office, but papers were still everywhere. Tax forms were overflowing from desk drawers and boxes, waiting for a day when he felt like filing. Owning an apartment building added even more paperwork. Books and journals were piled near the new bookshelves. As the elevator took him to his floor, he knew Mallory would be punctual for their meeting. She would knock on his office door exactly on time. She was as precise about time as she was about cleanliness. How would she react to the mess? She might think his office had been vandalized. He could pretend to be shocked when he walked in behind her. Mrs. Wilson, his cleaning lady, arrived while he was trying to clear some space on the carpet. He smiled at her hopefully as she unlocked his apartment door. Her expression was firm, indicating she had no intention of cleaning his office. She believed he was like a visitor from another world, far removed from her own familiar streets of Brooklyn.

**KAREN**

Karen's simple wish not to be like her mother led her to create her own story, a story of difference and strength. In her personal tale, there were key moments, like when she was twelve and her brother accidentally hit her in the eye with a golf club. At first, she thought she was blind, but the bone protected her, as the doctor later assured her. The club missed her eye, leaving only a few stitches that healed as a reminder of past pain. When she opened her eyes in the doctor's office and saw her mother talking about miracles and small mercies, she realized she was saved for a purpose.

**Miss Fogerty**

Miss Fogerty, walking quickly across the wet grass of the village green, felt both excited and sad about what she had just seen. It's thrilling to be the first to know something important, especially in a small community, and Miss Fogerty's quiet life had little excitement. However, she was deeply saddened by Dr. Bailey's condition. He had been her doctor for many years, and she appreciated his care during her annual bouts of laryngitis, which were her only health issues. His most valuable quality, she thought, was making patients feel he had plenty of time and genuinely wanted to hear their concerns. This quality made him beloved in the village. He was always willing to give his time, knowledge, and humor, and in return, he received loyalty and affection.

Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist, yet she has taken on the task of writing books for young children learning the piano. Her performances are captivating, showcasing her incredible skill and energy. At a recent concert for children, after playing a wide range of music styles, a young boy asked her to play the theme from "Match of the Day." For Joanna, this was amusing, and she easily fulfilled the request, understanding that in the boy's eyes, this was the true test of her abilities.

Joanna is unique among top pianists because she is deeply interested in how young children learn the piano. She has published a piano tutor for children called "Joanna MacGregor's Piano World," despite her demanding schedule. She is involved in numerous festivals, collaborates with young composers, runs her own recording label, and is always eager to start new projects with other artists. So why add writing a book to her list of activities? Joanna believes that the first lessons in music are crucial. She feels that the music profession often focuses too much on creating child prodigies, while most people's interest in music is more everyday and accessible.

Her experience teaching beginners and growing up in a home where her mother taught piano to children of all backgrounds has shaped her approach. She believes everyone should have the chance to learn the piano, just like learning to swim or speak a little French. Some children progress quickly, but she is particularly interested in those who take their time and enjoy the process, even if they eventually stop. She worries that some parents push their children to achieve in music, rather than letting them enjoy it.

Joanna's books aim to make learning fun and engaging. They include storylines and CDs with accompaniments in various styles, so children can enjoy playing along. She emphasizes the importance of improvisation and exploring the piano. As children progress, they need encouragement to read music rather than just play by ear. Joanna understands this challenge, as she relied on her ear during her own childhood. However, she believes practice is the key to improvement. She didn't practice rigorously until she attended the Royal Academy of Music, where she developed a contemporary repertoire that required it. Now, she values practice as the core of her musical life, even more than performances.

Joanna advises that whether practicing for twenty minutes or five hours, it's important to have clear goals. She suggests rewarding yourself by playing through a piece, regardless of mistakes, and mixing difficult pieces with easier ones.

**Writing by Hand and on Screen**

Dr. Johnson once said that writing without effort is often not enjoyable to read. This suggests that good writing is challenging. When I look back at my handwritten school essays, I notice there were few mistakes. Today, I would rewrite them many times. I think this is because writing by hand was physically demanding, which made me think more carefully. The slow pace of handwriting disciplined my mind. What was hard to change or erase was written with care. In contrast, the ease of using a computer can lead to carelessness. Many writers find that the time spent editing drafts on a computer is similar to the time spent writing by hand. Similarly, emails, unlike handwritten letters, can be emotionally heavy. Some say that emails have revived the art of love letters, with millions being sent where there was once only casual conversation. That's a positive change. At least these emails are written in some form of English and grammar. However, words on a screen can feel monotonous. Writers often don't realize the power of written words and may exaggerate their meaning. Words typed quickly lack the care and personality of handwriting.

**The CD**
