I put down my cup and looked at the CD. The case was not impressive, but the shiny disc inside was interesting. "Wonderful little things, aren't they?" Mr. Warriston said as he returned to the room. I agreed and carefully handed the disc to him. "It's amazing they can hold seventy minutes of music," he said, as he turned on the hi-fi system. Lights came on, and he pressed a button to open a small drawer. He placed the disc inside and closed it. "Some people say they sound sterile, but I think they..." "Do you have to turn them over, like records?" I asked. "What? No," Mr. Warriston replied. "You only play one side." "Why?" I asked. He looked puzzled, then thoughtful. "You know," he said, "I have no idea. You could have two lasers or just turn it over by hand... hmm." He smiled at me. "Yes, good point." He gestured to my chair. "Come on, let's get you sitting in the best spot for the stereo effect, eh?" I smiled, happy to have asked a technical question Mr. Warriston couldn't answer.

**Books versus Electronic Text**

When comparing books and electronic text, author Malcolm Bradbury was right when he said that if matches had been invented after lighters, we'd be amazed by the improvement. Many people, excited by new technology, claim that electronic text is as revolutionary as the invention of printing and that this change is almost complete. They ignore that changes in how we think take generations. This kind of thinking is self-centered, believing our generation is at a historical turning point. For example, a book from 1979 predicted that the 1980s would see the decline of books as we know them. This prediction was wrong. Reading long texts on a screen is often unpleasant, so most people don't do it. Computers encourage people to skim text. Some argue that this leads to new forms of storytelling, but non-linear reading isn't new. Many books, like religious texts and dictionaries, aren't read from start to finish. What's new is that computers don't encourage reading a text in its entirety.

**The Office**

Charles walked into the office, which was perfectly organized. The carpet was clear of the papers that had once covered it, and the desk was the dark wood he remembered from an auction five weeks ago. Neat file-holders were being placed in drawers. Twelve years of trade journals filled the shelves on one wall. Kathleen struggled to close the filing cabinet and then turned to him. "You need to switch to computers, Charles. This is too much." "Hello, Kathleen. This is amazing," he said, admiring the room and its antique furniture. He wasn't thinking about adding a computer or any other device, not even a pencil sharpener. "Simply amazing," he said, avoiding the topic of computers. Over the two years he had known her, they had this conversation many times. She couldn't understand why he resisted technology when he was skilled with computers and had even published an important paper on computer-related talents. She had inspired that paper. With a keyboard, she could transform any software into something new and exciting.

"You don't take sugar, do you?" his secretary shouted, more as a statement than a question. She had been making Lancelot coffee for months, so she should have known. Her excuse for forgetting was that he wasn't usually supposed to be there. But now, he was there all the time because he realized that staying away would lead to chaos. He thought about how he had gone from being a respected advisor, meeting authors and playwrights over lunch, to a stressed worker trying to prevent disasters, with no parking space when he arrived at work.

"This came," she yelled, waving a manila folder before placing it in front of him. "From that guy in Los Angeles. You said you wanted to see it." The label read: "A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert." Below it, "An Expanded Synopsis." Lancelot didn't want to see another synopsis; he wanted a first draft. Ian Cuthbert had received a large advance for this book when Lancelot bought the company. Ian was one of several old friends Lancelot had mistakenly commissioned to write books. Ian was a prime example of how someone with an unpredictable nature becomes even less reliable when given a chance.

Lancelot skipped the introduction, which he had read many times, and looked at the synopsis. He recognized almost every phrase. He closed the folder and set it aside, realizing Ian's manuscript might never come. The synopsis lacked the brilliance Ian was known for and felt like it had lost its conviction. Lancelot remembered stories of a famous author whose last book was published incomplete after his death, with payments made chapter by chapter. But in that case, the payments were for a hypothetical advance that was never given. Ian's advance was huge, a reversal of the usual business practice where authors deliver a manuscript before being paid.

Lancelot, who studied modern languages at Oxford, remembered when Ian was the most promising talent at Cambridge, a place so full of promise it made other places seem unimportant. Ian's peers had taken over British theatre quickly, but Ian's energy made them seem lazy. He wore his coat like a cape and talked about famous French writers as if he had met them. Yet, Ian's creative potential remained untapped. While others succeeded, Ian withdrew further. At the peak of his influence, he was difficult to work with. Appointed to edit an arts magazine, he failed to produce even one issue despite using the budget for twelve. His contract with a fashion magazine resulted in stories about his large salary, which increased in hopes of making him produce more, but he produced nothing. At editorial meetings, Ian was critical and dismissive of others' ideas. Ten years later, he was unreliable even for his own funeral. Lancelot was close to admitting that commissioning "A World History of the Short" was a mistake from the start.

Text: 'The evolution of breakfast in England

Health experts agree that having a good breakfast is very important. However, historically, breakfast is a relatively new concept in England. In medieval times, breakfast was rarely mentioned in literature. There are a few references to travelers eating at dawn before long journeys and to sick people having breakfast for health reasons. But generally, only kings or nobles had breakfast. 

In the sixteenth century, breakfast started to become common for everyone. Some believe this was because food became more available. However, they often overlook other important social changes. For instance, new work patterns might explain why breakfast became more important. People began working set hours, often starting very early. So, having a meal in the morning became necessary and was no longer just for the wealthy.'

**Photography**

When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to include based on their skills, personal views, and cultural influences. This book will explore how these factors shape the style, content, and expression of a photograph, and how viewers interpret these images. For instance, a newspaper reader might think they understand the photos they see. However, instead of accepting the image as it is, we might ask if it truly shows the scene as it was or if it reflects the photographer's perspective. Is the exact moment captured important, or is the photo meant to symbolize something broader about the world?

**More than a Game**

For me, sport is more than just a game. The most successful athletes have complete self-confidence. To succeed, you need to focus entirely on your goal, putting everything else aside. Sport is tough, and no one will do it for you. It's a matter of survival. Sport has taught me discipline and determination, and it also shows the value of teamwork. My sport allows individual excellence but is also a team effort, requiring a balance between the two. Like life, you can achieve personal success, but you must remember others around you. Sport has given me a lot, not just money. It has opened opportunities and shown me things worldwide that many never see. However, you must sacrifice a lot for these benefits.

**Tuning In**

Some experiences are so vivid that they stand out in our memories. For me, one such moment happened years ago in California. I lay awake, listening to a mockingbird singing beautifully from a hidden spot in the trees. I don't usually have trouble sleeping, but the bird's skill kept me awake. Its complex melodies drew me into a new artistic experience. To follow the bird's patterns, I relied on my knowledge of jazz and Indian classical music. The bird's performance felt like an amazing improvisation. I reacted with awe and delight as each unexpected musical variation came through my window until I finally fell asleep.

Birds have always been a significant part of human culture, inspiring a range of emotions from love to fear. But what does our fascination with birds reveal about us? Paul Evans explores this idea. 

In a greenhouse, a small brown bird, a wren, is repeatedly hitting the glass. This bird has long been seen as a symbol of omens and messages. Is it trying to communicate something mysterious, or is it simply trapped? Both interpretations could be valid. Wrens have been part of British culture for centuries. In medieval times, people believed the direction a wren flew could predict their luck. Today, images of wrens are common in British homes, showing that even if old beliefs have faded, the wren still holds a place in our hearts. A forest without wrens feels empty and lacking.

This connection to birds is rooted in folklore, which dates back to when humans relied more directly on nature for survival. People developed a cultural language to express the importance of animals. However, cultural views can change, altering how we see these creatures. For instance, in the early 1500s, red kites were common in London and valued as scavengers. But they were later seen as pests and nearly disappeared, except in Wales. Over time, red kites became symbols of conservation and have been reintroduced to restore their numbers.

Our bond with birds goes beyond culture and is linked to human evolution. Early humans watched birds closely for signs of danger, weather changes, and food availability. Birds also connected them to the spiritual world. Our interest in birds reflects our own identity, as we admire their flight, song, and freedom. Some might say these feelings are outdated, but like the appendix or wisdom teeth, they remain part of us, and losing them is painful. This is why birds are now seen as indicators of environmental health. In Britain, 30 bird species are endangered, which is concerning not only for the loss of these birds but also for the cultural heritage they represent. Birds like the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing symbolize spiritual love, romantic love, and magic. Their decline is a cultural loss, as seen in the works of poets like Shelley and Shakespeare.

Folklore plays a crucial role in our connection to birds. Stories and legends, with their mysterious origins and constant evolution, create a stronger bond with birds than scientific terms can. They evoke feelings and attitudes buried beneath modern life. Whether watching wildlife films or observing birds in our gardens, the joy we feel is not easily explained by science. Birds captivate us in ways we struggle to understand, and the stories we tell about them help us interpret their messages. The wren in the greenhouse creates a link between the present and a distant past, holding its song as it flies into the future, leaving us to ponder its mystery.

Maps are tools that show how different points and features on the earth's surface relate to each other, mainly through distance and direction. In the past, people often measured distance in terms of time, like "a day's journey," which told more about how easy it was to travel through an area than the actual distance. Direction was less important for travelers who just wanted to know where to go and how far it was. Because of this, written travel guides were popular alongside maps for a long time. Even today, some maps, like those of railway systems, don't always show true directions. Early maps used signs to mark important landmarks, and these signs varied in size to show their importance. The style of these signs depended on the map's purpose and where it was made, so understanding these styles is crucial when studying old maps.

The history of map-making, or cartography, is about improving the accuracy of distance and direction and making maps more detailed. Cartography has used other sciences to help with this. For example, instead of using shadows or stars to find direction, people started using the magnetic compass, which allowed for more precise measurements. As people explored more of the world, they tried to map it more accurately. Astronomers found out that the earth is slightly flattened at the poles, which led to more precise mapping of large areas.

Over time, the needs of map users changed. Maps were no longer just for travelers and merchants. Soldiers needed accurate maps for artillery use, which required showing the land's surface features accurately. This led to the invention of contour lines. Archaeologists, historians, and modern geographers also had specific needs, leading to new mapping methods for things like geological layers and climate patterns. Today, maps are valued for their ability to help coordinate and interpret information across many sciences, leading to a modern revival in map-making.

However, the development of cartography hasn't been a smooth, continuous process. There have been times of slow progress and times of rapid change, with old ideas sometimes persisting alongside new ones. Cartographers often knew what needed to be done but had to wait for better tools to implement their ideas. Since making a map by copying an old one is easy, and because of the investment in printing, map publishers have sometimes resisted new ideas. Therefore, maps should not be taken at face value as evidence of the knowledge and techniques of their time. The many maps we have today are the result of much human effort and thought, making them a valuable record of human history. This is what makes the study of historical cartography so interesting and educational.

TIM RICE

I was invited into a young man's drawing room, a calm and cultured space amidst a chaotic cluster of rooms where the less ambitious family members lived. Moving from the kitchen to his parlour felt like upgrading from economy to business class. This room housed the largest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player and tuner I had encountered, and the surprising evidence that a teenager had invested in Georgian wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had won a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history, and had nine months before starting, during which he planned to become England's answer to the composer Richard Rodgers. My own dreams were just as wild; I wanted to be a pop star for the usual reasons: women, money, and fame. The difference between Andrew and me was that my dreams weren't a matter of life or death, though it's easy to say that now. They might have been if I had failed. So, when Andrew suggested a new crazy ambition for meâ€”to become as famous a lyricist as Oscar Hammersteinâ€”I had no hesitation in trying. This was partly because within ten minutes of meeting, he played me three tunes he had composedâ€”I could tell he was very talented. As he confidently played selections from the many shows he had written and produced at school, I was reminded of the best show albums from my parents' LP collection. He needed a new lyricist for the outside world. I had little to impress him with, other than instant praise for his music and a genuine, released seven-inch single of a song I had written (both words and music) that an unknown pop group had recorded three months earlier, ending their failing career. We parted, promising to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in the music charts than in West End theatre, but on the bus back to my flat, I told myself I had just met someone with rare talent and determination, and I would be foolish to miss the chance to work with someone who was clearly going to make a big impact on musical theatre, probably very soon. And even if we didn't succeed in challenging the top musical composers, we could try to compete with the Beatles and Rolling Stones later in the summer. The Everly Brothers had just made a comeback and would likely need new material. The next day, back at my desk in the office where I was training to become a solicitor, the brief certainty I had felt about a life in show business with Andrew Lloyd Webber had faded somewhat. I would, of course, continue to look at the small ads in Melody Maker for groups needing a vocalist and would write a few more simple songs that wouldn't reveal the limitations of my voice, but it was still likely that I would eventually pass my exams and become a respectable lawyer by the time I was twenty-five. By then, I would surely have outgrown pop music, as my father confidently predicted I would by the time I was twenty-one. This was worryingâ€”if he was right, I only had a few more months to enjoy it. But in the meantime, I felt I had nothing to lose by seeing Andrew again. It would be fun to see a musical with him and to write lyrics that imitated musical lyricists rather than pop stars. Andrew was a fascinating person who talked about Good Food Guides and Victorian architecture, besides supporting Leyton Orient football team. I wasn't convinced by the idea for a musical he had been working on for the past year, but in 1965, I was rarely convinced about anything. His talent was undeniable, and he claimed to have all the contacts. I was soon back in his drawing room. The idea was about the life of Dr. Thomas Barnardo, the nineteenth-century philanthropist who founded the orphanages that bear his name. His story was indeed worthy, but it didn't truly inspire me. The hero was too perfect, at least in Andrew's version of his life, and the project was unoriginal in both concept and execution, owing too much to Lionel Bart's hit show, Oliver. On the other hand, Andrew's belief in his score's brilliance was infectious and not entirely unjustified. What did I know about musicals? As David Land, who later became my agent for over twenty-five years, memorably (and repeatedly) said, if there's a demand for one hamburger bar on the block, there's room for two. We could be the second hamburger joint. I set to work with great enthusiasm, especially for the songs meant to be funny. Andrew outlined the plot, played me the tunes, and often gave me the title as well, most of which had likely been thought up by his former school friend who had already tried. I skipped a day at the solicitor's office, pretending to be ill, to write my first batch of theatrical lyrics. I didn't know it that day, but I had changed careers.

**Language**  
Humans have an amazing ability: we can influence each other's thoughts with great accuracy through language. Language is so integral to our lives that it's hard to imagine living without it. If you see two or more people together anywhere in the world, they are likely to start talking. Even when alone, people often talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I like to think of language as an 'instinct'. This suggests that people know how to speak in a way similar to how spiders know how to spin webs. Spiders didn't learn web-spinning from a genius spider or need special training; it's a natural ability.

**Climate and Weather**  
Climate and weather, mainly created by the air around us, have a big impact on where animals and plants live. Climate can greatly influence the look of landscapes. For instance, warm and wet conditions all year support the growth of tropical jungles, which are rich in species diversity. On the other hand, cold and windy areas can only support a few living things. The daily weather patterns that form the climate over time are caused by large air masses rising and mixing, as the atmosphere is always moving. Some of this movement is because the air, being thin, doesn't move as fast as the spinning Earth. However, the sun is a more significant cause of air movement.

**Coffee**  
As a bar-person, I had to serve drinks and, more importantly, make coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee. I went through several days of intense coffee-making training, learning more than I ever wanted to about maintaining the restaurant's shiny espresso machine. I also learned the key steps to making a perfect cappuccino. By the end of the first week, I realized making good coffee wasn't as easy as it seemed, and I thought I might be demoted to cleaning ashtrays. Fortunately, my boss was patient. "Making coffee is both an art and a science," he said, "and you need time to get the hang of it."

**Art on TV**

Why does television often struggle with programs about visual arts? Painting and sculpture seem perfect for TV, as cameras can show an entire artwork and then zoom in on details. However, few TV series successfully capture both the enjoyment and complexity of viewing art. A good example of this issue is Robert Hughes's series "American Visions," which explores American art. Hughes is a reliable critic with a captivating presence, and he had nearly eight hours to introduce British viewers to American art, which is often overlooked by British galleries. I expected the series to focus on major artworks, but it instead explored how American history and culture are reflected in its art and architecture.

**Dealing in Metals**

For 20 years, I worked as an international metals dealer and became known as a speculator. The metals market is less regulated than others. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, one can make a lot of money. Risk-taking is essential in this industry, which aligns well with a free-market global economy. However, free-trade economists who believed the market would keep metal prices stable have found the opposite. More minerals are being extracted, and raw material costs are dropping. Adjusted for inflation, most metal prices are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to investigate claims against a multinational company benefiting from these cheap raw materials.

**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**

Abaco and its offshore cays are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, stretching from Florida past the Tropic of Cancer to Cuba. Each island has its own character and offers something unique. To explore the islands and cays of Abaco, a boat is essential. If your accommodation doesn't include one, don't worry. There are plenty of ferries and water-taxis, or you can rent a boat to travel independently. Sailing is the most popular way to get around here. Abaco is called 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for a reason. Its calm, naturally protected waters are perfect for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The cays and their beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. On land, the lights of the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly at night.

**Build Your Own Bamboo Bike at the UK's First Workshop**

At the Bamboo Bike Club, run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan, you can spend a weekend building your own custom-designed bamboo bike frame. Located in Hackney Wick, east London, this is the only place in the UK where you can take such a course. The atmosphere is lively and fun, quite different from a typical woodwork class.

Bamboo bikes are becoming popular again, with companies like Calfee Design in California and Bamboo Bikes in Yorkshire leading the way. However, their ready-made frames can be expensive, costing around $2,995 or Â£1,868. James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes more affordable and spent years developing their idea in a shed in Brecon, Wales. They realized they didn't just want to sell frames; they wanted to share the joy of making something unique and sustainable. This led to the creation of the Bamboo Bike Club, which they run alongside their full-time jobsâ€”James works with wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer.

The course is reasonably priced and includes a custom-designed bike frame and a weekend of bike-building. Participants learn how to select strong bamboo and form joints, starting with the front triangle and then moving to the seat and chain assembly. Alloy tubes are used for parts that need extra strength, like the handlebars and wheel forks. The process involves using jigs, power tools, and design blueprints, which can be challenging for those not used to DIY projects. However, James and Ian are there to help and ensure everything is done correctly.

Most participants enjoy the hands-on experience, and many are engineers. But even if you're not, Ian reassures that mistakes are okayâ€”you can always try again with another piece of bamboo. The bamboo is pre-checked for quality, allowing you to focus on the look of your frame, choosing from plain, black, or mottled bamboo.

On Sunday, the focus is on building the lugs, or wraps, using hemp bindings and epoxy resin to create strong joints. A final polymer coating makes the bike waterproof, and then it's ready for wheels, brakes, gears, and other personal touches. The finished bike is strong and durable, comparable to metal bikes. Ian has used his for over a year on a 16-mile commute, and James has tested one off-road for three months without damage.

While bamboo bikes might look a bit rough compared to professional frames, they have a unique charm. James and Ian believe this individuality is what makes them special. Personally, I think bamboo bikes are perfect for a relaxed ride rather than racing. I chose a 'Classic English' frame for a smooth, easy-going ride. Bamboo bikes are light and absorb vibrations well, making for a comfortable ride.

The workshops are most rewarding when you finally take your bike on the road. They're light, easy to ride, and a lot of fun. And the best part? The cost is less than Â£500.

**Self-help Books**

Dione Reverend was just an editor at Random House in New York when she came across a manuscript by an unknown pop psychologist, Dr. John Gray. She immediately knew it would be a bestseller, and she was right. Dr. Gray is now a multimillionaire, and Dione Reverend has her own company. Dr. Gray's book on improving communication between men and women is a key part of the growing self-help industry. This industry claims to address Americans' desires for self-improvement, while also creating new desires and supporting the New York publishing world. In Britain, the genre is also popular, with many books being published, though many are rejected for being too similar or too niche. Editors focus on marketability, asking questions like, "How promotable is the author? What's the 'hook'? Is it universal enough?" According to Reverend, a catchy title is crucial for success.

**Autobiographies**

There is an unspoken agreement between an autobiographer and the reader that the truth will be told. However, this agreement is often not fully kept. Writers might avoid sharing certain actions or thoughts they find too embarrassing or unimportant. Some writers might even invent stories to better convey the truth about themselves, believing that these stories capture their essence more effectively than strict facts. Others might label their work as an autobiography to gain the reader's trust, even if the story is fictional. This can be done without any cynical intent.

**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**

Detective stories have been seen as reflecting the conflicts of late 19th and early 20th-century society. These stories are allegorical, with the crime symbolizing human impulses like lust or greed, and its resolution representing the restoration of order in society. In Hammett's stories, society is restored, but it is shown to be corrupt. The detective and the criminal are two sides of the same coin, understanding each other well. The private detective is both a crook and a competitor, sometimes feeling conflicted about his role.

**Science Writing**

Stephen Jay Gould is considered one of today's greatest scientific essayists. When discussing the art of writing, he emphasized the importance of understanding the culture you are writing about. He believes that only scientists can effectively present science because they understand its community and rules. Gould advises never to underestimate the reader. While you can simplify the language, you should not simplify the argument. Patronizing the reader will ruin the piece.

**Air-conditioning**

At Cannons Gym, a popular spot for City of London workers during lunch, the air feels very cold. To combat this summer's unusually high temperatures, the gym has used a lot of air-conditioning. In fact, when it's not busy, the gym feels as cold as the Arctic. This is just one example of how modern society often misuses air-conditioning. It has become a key part of both work and leisure, symbolizing humanity's ability to control or change the climate. However, many air-conditioned buildings could use other cooling methods. They could use natural light and ventilation and have thicker walls that absorb less heat during the day and release it at night. These simple measures can be very effective and would greatly reduce the need for air-conditioning.

**Sundials**

It's likely not a coincidence that the start of a new millennium has brought renewed interest in sundials, which measure time based on the sun's position. A hundred years ago, sundials were essential for keeping clocks accurate. But as clocks and watches became more advanced and reliable, sundials became garden ornamentsâ€”romantic and intriguing, but outdated in a modern technological age. Now, interest in them is growing again. David Harber, a sundial maker, believes their charm comes from their direct connection to the planets. He says there's a magical moment when a sundial starts working. They are still, calm, and romantic objects that remind us of our place in the universe.

**Paint Your Own China**

My idea of china-painting came from a visit long ago to an arts and crafts show where serious-looking older women showed how to paint delicate flowers on a teacup with precise brushstrokes. It was fascinating because each stroke created a perfect petal or leaf. Their hands were steady, the paint never smeared, and it seemed like these women had either practiced for decades or had a natural talent for precision. Remembering this, I wondered what kind of people would join a china-painting course. Would even beginners show natural artistic skill? In reality, the atmosphere was not intimidating at all. The students were there to have fun, and even the teacher didn't want to paint petals on teacups with the robotic speed I had remembered.

Uncle arranged a package holiday for Keith and Dawne at a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to book the trip, the travel agent mentioned that the other travelers were a school group learning Italian. However, something went wrong. Due to a mistake at the travel agency, the check-in desk, or a computer, Keith and Dawne ended up in Switzerland at the Edelweiss Hotel, Room 212.

At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She confirmed their details and said everything was fine. On the plane, they were surprised to hear people speaking with North of England accents. Keith thought there might have been a cancellation or that the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks and relaxed.

When they landed, a woman with glasses told everyone to stay together. There was no mention of an overnight stop in the brochure, but Keith assumed it was part of the plan. Tired and not wanting to argue, they accepted the beds offered to them. The next morning, they realized they were staying there for the entire holiday and became worried.

The receptionist explained they could enjoy the lake and take a steamer to Interlaken. Keith calmly explained there was a mistake; they were supposed to be in Venice. The receptionist didn't know about any mistake. Dawne described the travel agent who booked their trip, hoping it would help.

A woman named Mrs. Franks, who they had seen at Gatwick, approached them. Dawne asked if she was in charge because they were in the wrong hotel. Mrs. Franks explained that Your-Kind-of-Holiday offers many trips, and all tickets and labels look similar. She laughed, saying they couldn't end up in a wildlife park by mistake.

Keith insisted they weren't meant to be in Switzerland. Mrs. Franks left them standing there, and the receptionist was gone. Dawne whispered that Mrs. Franks seemed kind, but Keith was lost in thought, trying to remember everything that happened.

An elderly couple, Mr. and Mrs. Nottage, interrupted Keith's thoughts, saying they had a great night's sleep due to the lakeside air. Keith and Dawne left the reception area. Outside, they didn't mention the irony of their situation: on their first holiday since their honeymoon, they ended up on a tour with elderly people, when they wanted to escape the demands of the elderly. Uncle had insisted on this trip, even though they tried to convince him to join them.

American executives are looking to the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a model for good management. Eluned Price reports. In Britain, many people know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and have a general idea of his achievements. However, in America, he is only now being recognized, despite the Wall Street Journal's claim that Shackleton was an Antarctic explorer whose feats were largely unnoticed for most of the 20th century. Now, Americans are showing great enthusiasm for him. Biographies and accounts of his voyage on the Endurance are being produced and are expected to sell quickly. The American Museum of Natural History is planning a major exhibition, and Columbia Tristar is making a film about Shackleton's life. Some American managers have also adopted Shackleton as a role model. They admire his actions and draw lessons in leadership and communication from his story, referring to each other as "speaking Shackleton." The determined and resourceful Shackleton, with his reindeer sleeping bag and blubber-stove, has become a model for modern management consultants. Jim MacGregor, managing partner of Abernathy MacGregor Frank in New York, has used Shackleton as a role model for years. His firm specializes in communication during mergers, acquisitions, and corporate crises, such as when a company's plant explodes or when half the workforce must be laid off. MacGregor believes Shackleton is a model for management because of his leadership and communication skills. Shackleton was at his best when he and his team had a lot to lose, like their lives. One of Shackleton's most fascinating decisions was to turn back when only 97 miles from the South Pole during his 1908 expedition. This decision showed his credibility for future expeditions, as he prioritized the lives of his men. In a crisis, people want to know someone is in charge. While many managers today avoid responsibility, Shackleton was willing to take it on. His 1914 expedition became legendary when his ship, the Endurance, was trapped and crushed by ice. Shackleton assured his men they would reach safety if they trusted him and did their best. From their accounts and diaries, it's clear Shackleton was always in charge. He planned for every possibility, kept his men informed, and sought their opinions. He was adaptable and willing to start fresh when needed. Shackleton believed an explorer needs optimism, physical endurance, and patience. MacGregor notes that in desperate situations, doing nothing can be the hardest thing, especially in America, where people are eager to act quickly. If you buy bonds and guess wrong on interest rates, holding on can eventually recover your money, while selling would mean a big loss. Similarly, don't be afraid to change plans if they're not working. Shackleton led by example. On the return voyage from the Endurance, he noticed the expedition photographer, Hurley, was gloveless and forced his own gloves on him, threatening to throw them overboard if Hurley didn't wear them. He did something similar with a biscuit during the 1905 expedition when they were near starving, showing his selflessness. Caroline Alexander, author of "Endurance," says the public's appetite for heroic endeavors is growing, and Shackleton stands out as a genuine embodiment of the ideals we long for today.

In the forests of Madagascar, there is a primate called the aye-aye that has a unique way of finding food, similar to a woodpecker. Both the woodpecker and the aye-aye search for insect larvae hidden in wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to drill into the wood and its long tongue to catch the insects. The aye-aye, however, uses its sharp incisor teeth to gnaw into the wood and its long, thin third finger to reach and scoop out the insects.

Although scientists described the aye-aye's feeding method over a hundred years ago, they have only recently discovered how it finds the insects inside the wood. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied the hunting skills of some captive aye-ayes named Nosferatu, Poe, Samantha, and her daughter Annabelle. He tested if they found insects by looking for visual signs, like holes on the wood surface where insects might have entered. He gave them logs with drilled holes, some leading to mealworms and others to empty spaces. The aye-ayes went directly to the mealworm cavities, showing they didn't rely on visual clues.

Dr. Erickson also tested if the aye-ayes used smell or sound to find the insects. Even when the smell was blocked or the insects were dead and silent, the aye-ayes still located them. It turned out that the aye-ayes could sense the cavities themselves. They tap the wood with their middle finger and use their large ears to listen for echoes that indicate a hollow space. They might also hear insects moving when disturbed by the tapping.

The idea that aye-ayes take the place of woodpeckers in Madagascar is interesting, but there are birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that also search for insects in wood. So, the woodpecker role might not be entirely empty. The aye-aye is not only like a woodpecker and an echo-locating bat but also behaves like a squirrel. Its incisors grow continuously like a squirrel's, and it has been seen in the wild gnawing through nut shells and using its long finger to extract the nut meat.

Text: 'Ordinary people, ordinary lives Most of us have photos of our grandparents, but how many of us know what their lives were like when they were young? Diaries give us small, incomplete glimpses, and family stories are often only half remembered. What will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write things down but never do. We might leave videos instead of photos, but those are still just images. Hannah Renier has a solution: she writes autobiographies for other people, creating a hardback book of at least 20,000 words, with illustrations if wanted. These books are not about famous people, but about ordinary ones. The idea came to her when she talked to her family and realized how much of the past was disappearing. "When I started, I didn't take it as seriously as I do now," she says. "I've met people who have led interesting lives. They say they do it for their children or for the future, but they also enjoy it themselves." The promise of confidentiality helps people be honest. "I had the confidence to be honest," says a 62-year-old man who made and lost a fortune before making another. "I was surprised at what came out. Some things were painful, like my divorce, and the pain was still there." "I did it for my family, so they might learn something, but I haven't let my children read it yet. They were hurt by things in my life, and there are details I don't want them to know right now. If they insist, I'll let them. But I'd rather they read it after I'm gone." He also saw patterns from his childhood that led to repeated mistakes. Ms. Renier has noticed this in others too. "It's amazing how many people are influenced by their parents," she says. "The things parents say and do in childhood affect people for the rest of their lives. They repeat behaviors, marry people their parents would approve of, or rebel against them." "Many disappointments come out. Even sixty years later, people regret or resent things unresolved with their parents. There's no age of reason. If people had issues in their youth, they still have them in middle age. They try to impress a parent who wasn't impressed, and if that fails, some seek permission to say 'I can't stand my mother.'" Ms. Renier is more of a recorder than an inquisitor, keeping her distance. "It's not for the public, and I'm not there to be nosy. People sometimes tell me things and then say, 'I'm not sure if that should go in.' I include it anywayâ€”they can remove it when they see the draft. But generally, people want to be honest, warts and all." "It's not vanity publishing. It's not people saying, 'I've had such an interesting life, the world needs to know.' Things are changing faster than ever, and we're losing sight of the past. It's a way to connect with our roots. We need a link to our ancestors because families don't sit together as they used to. People want a little immortality." Each book involves up to 30 hours of recorded interviews, which Ms. Renier uses to write the life story, rearranging and interpreting the events. Modern technology allows her to produce everything except the binding with its gold lettering: you can choose your own color and title. Fascinating to the private audience each book is for, the results are not about exposing secrets. Ms. Renier organizes her material logically and writes well, so the final content is as good as its subject. The book looks high-quality and costs nearly Â£3,000, with extra copies at Â£25 each. She gets about 10 inquiries a week, but the cost, due to the time involved, deters many people. "I thought it would be a more affordable product," she says. "But the people I've worked with are all from well-off backgrounds, readers of Harpers & Queen, where I advertise. They're the kind of people who would have had their portraits painted for their descendants."'

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**  
The Museum of Classical Archaeology is one of the few places in the world where you can see a large collection of casts of Greek and Roman sculptures, with over six hundred pieces. It's important to note that none of the sculptures are original; they are all precise replicas made from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The museum is located in a specially designed gallery with great natural light. The benefit of these plaster casts is that sculptures originally displayed together but now separated across different museums in Europe can be seen together as they were meant to be. You can view nearly all the famous Greek and Roman sculptures in just one afternoon.

**B. Cambridge Darkroom**  
Cambridge Darkroom is a photography center with community darkrooms and a gallery that hosts a variety of photography exhibitions and related media. We offer courses and workshops for all ages and skill levels, including a popular Beginner's Course, a shorter Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. We have a membership program that allows members to use our darkrooms. We also support young photographers (aged 12 to 16) through our Young Members scheme, led by our resident photographer. We sell photographic books, magazines, and a full range of photographic materials.

**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**  
The Sedgwick Museum has an impressive collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all geological ages and parts of the world. It also holds Britain's oldest complete geological collection, that of Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728), which includes nearly 10,000 rare specimens in their original 18th-century cabinets. Adam Sedgwick, a Professor of Geology, greatly expanded the collections, creating an outstanding museum. The collection is organized by geological age, allowing visitors to trace major changes in life on Earth over time. The new Whewell Gallery displays beautiful minerals and gems, with detailed labels explaining their nature and modern uses.

**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**  
This collection contains over 400,000 air photographs, both oblique and vertical, taken by university staff over the past 45 years. The University has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and conducts photographic work throughout Great Britain. The photographs are interesting as they provide a detailed, year-by-year record of the landscape, showing both natural features and human impact from prehistoric times to today. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the knowledgeable library staff can help with inquiries. The photographs cannot be borrowed, but copies can be ordered and usually take about a month to produce.

**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**  
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is the second oldest and longest-running center of its kind in the world, and it's a unique tourist attraction in the region. Visitors can enjoy creating wall hangings by rubbing one of over a hundred different brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. By making resin copies, known as facsimiles, the center preserves the originals while allowing everyone to enjoy brass rubbing. Brass plates, used as an alternative to tomb statues, spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many were destroyed during various revolutions, but most of the surviving brasses are in Britain, and the Cambridge Centre has the widest range of examples.

**From Here to Paternity**

**A. The Theatre Director**

I've had 35 years of raising young children due to my unusual personal life, and I've loved every moment. This morning, I fed the baby, and to me, that's what being a father is all about. I'm very lucky with my children; we all enjoy opera, theatre, books, and music, which has created a strong bond. Now that they're mostly grown, I've become more of a friend than a father. I don't believe in physical punishment. I've slapped my children in anger before, but I don't support it. I may not have been the most attentive father, but I've always tried to be available. I'm here if they need me, but I let them contact me. If you start chasing them to ask why they haven't been in touch, it creates a burden of guilt. My parents did that to me, and I would never do it to my children.

**B. The Advertising Executive**

I was young, about 25, when my children were born, and I found the responsibilities challenging. It made me feel older quickly, but it also kept me young, which I value. As they became teenagers, they introduced me to music, youth culture, and fashion, which has been invaluable for running the agency. I never felt out of touch. I missed some events like first concerts and sports days because I was busy building my business, which makes me sad. But now, I can take them on holidays to the south of France. They get along well with our friends and join us at parties and advertising award ceremonies without feeling intimidated. I think it's an advantage that they see my work as glamorous and interesting.

**C. The Politician**

My first child was born just as I was about to be elected to the Greater London Council, and the others came soon after. My wife and I promised to make time for them, but as I became more politically active, time became a problem. I only accept weekend meetings and public appearances if there are facilities for the kids to come with me. This way, they understand what I do when I'm not with them, and there's no feeling of me disappearing. I've noticed more MPs bringing their kids to the House. Maybe we're all becoming more aware of the need to involve our children in our lives.

**D. The Writer**

My first marriage ended when Kate and Bonnie were young, so I had to think more about fatherhood. I made great efforts to stay in touch with them. My ex-wife and I even tried living next door to each other so the kids could come and go as they wished, but Kate and Bonnie found it confusing. Kate has said in interviews that I was always there for her, but I'm not sure I was a very good father. I was around a lot, but like many parents in the Seventies, I treated the kids as adults too soon. Kate recently complained that we were too liberal. I think I could have introduced more structure. I regret that now. I still worry about my older daughters as much as my youngest. In that way, your kids never leave you.

**E. The TV Presenter**

I was ready for kids. I was 30, met my wife, and we had a lovely house, so we thought, "Why keep spending money on new sofas when we could have a child instead?" Having my daughter Betty has made me understand who I am. You feel special when you have a child, and you are, but you're also just one more parent in a long line. It's a great equalizer. I sometimes resent it, but any irritation disappears with just one look at her. A baby's smile is the greatest way to melt a grown man.

**THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER**

**A. Tamburlaine the Great**  
Marlowe's epic about the unstoppable warrior Tamburlaine can feel endless, but in Terry Hands' version, it's one of the most exciting shows of the year. He has cut a lot from the original text, making it fast-paced and full of energy. Antony Sher shines in the lead role, performing daring stunts like somersaulting from a balcony and sliding down a rope while speaking. His intense performance captivates the audience.  
*Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*

**B. Women Laughing**  
This play by the late Michael Wall, first shown in Manchester, has now moved to London. The first act creates a tense atmosphere as two couples chat on a sunny lawn. The second act shifts focus to the impact of illness, showing deep compassion. Wall was a promising talent lost too soon at 44.  
*Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)*

**C. Amphibians**  
Irish playwright Billy Roche continues to enrich the English stage with his plays set in Wexford. This latest work explores the decline of the fishing industry with rich characters, deep emotions, and unexpected humor. Though it meanders at times, it ends with a powerful climax.  
*Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

**D. Murder by Misadventure**  
A classic thriller about 'the perfect murder'. Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play crime writers plotting against each other. While familiar, the plot twists are cleverly handled.  
*Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)*

**E. The Alchemist**  
Director Sam Mendes brings out the best in Jonson's comedy about 17th-century con artists. Originally at the Swan, it now plays well on the Barbican's main stage, with strong performances from Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce.  
*Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

**F. The Madras House**  
Peter James' production of Harley Granville Barker's comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society moves to London after success in Edinburgh. The production is stylish, the acting excellent, and the play is an overlooked classic.  
*Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)*

**G. Dreams from a Summer House**  
This new musical by Alan Ayckbourn is a charming take on Beauty and the Beast set in London suburbia. With a lush score by John Pattison, it celebrates romantic love and is a delightful show. London producers should take note.  
*Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)*

**H. The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's comedy almost received a negative review, but it is saved by excellent comic performances from Ron Cook and Anton Lesser. Most of the cast seems uncomfortable, which is unfortunate.  
*Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*

**I. The Voysey Inheritance**  
Another revival of Granville Barker's work, now touring. This play about a seemingly respectable lawyer who leaves a corrupt financial legacy to his son is outstanding.  
*Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)*

**Hide and Seek by Yvonne Coppard**  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game by watching a suspicious bookshop. She is surprised to see her Uncle Jim there. He tricks her into a world of lies and crime, using her love for him to turn her against her friends. Coppard skillfully portrays her friends' characters. When Emma's life is threatened, the story becomes intense, especially when she is trapped in the cellar of an abandoned house. The book explores family life, childhood friendships, and warns that adults aren't always the protectors they should be. It's a powerful and believable read.

**Backtrack by Peter Hunt**  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, discover that their relatives were involved in a mysterious 1915 train accident that killed eight people. The story uses different perspectives and documents like maps and first-hand accounts to shed light on the incident. The reader, along with the protagonists, works hard to uncover the truth. It's a clever and complex novel that rewards careful reading.

**Pigeon Summer by Ann Turnbull**  
Mary Dyer doesn't fit into her family or male-dominated society. She loves her father's racing pigeons, and when he leaves to find work, she takes over the loft and wins prizes, despite conflicts with her stressed mother. Set in 1930, this story has a strong message that there are different kinds of intelligence. Thoughtful readers will find it satisfying.

**Yaxley's Cat by Robert Westall**  
Robert Westall tells a chilling story of rural prejudice through the eyes of a mature woman, Rose. She rents Sepp Yaxley's cottage to escape her materialistic life. A fierce cat and strange items in the house reveal why Yaxley disappeared. The locals become hostile, putting Rose and her children in danger. By the end, the threat is controlled, but Rose is troubled by her son's ruthless behavior. It's a gripping story.

**Someone's Mother is Missing by Harry Mazer**  
Sam, from the poorer side of the family, is in awe of his sophisticated cousin Lisa. When Lisa's privileged life falls apart, Sam helps her find balance, and both learn the value of family. The story is a bit slow in parts but has gentle humor and convincingly shows the growing closeness between the two teenagers. It's appealing to both boys and girls.

**Stanley's Aquarium by Barry Faville**  
Barry Faville writes with confidence and humor, vividly describing New Zealand and creating a smart and likable narrator. Robbie takes a job gardening for Stanley, who is initially fascinating but later repellent. When Robbie discovers what Stanley keeps in his aquarium, the story takes a thrilling turn while maintaining sharp insights into character and relationships. It's unusual and compelling.

**Dodger by Libby Gleeson**  
This is a sad story about Mick's troubled personal relationships and difficult school life. The story is told through flashbacks, a teacher's letters, Mick's notes, and a sympathetic narrative. Mick improves his self-worth through a role in a school play and the support of a sensitive teacher. It's highly recommended, though it's a painful read, especially at the end.

Title: 'Science Defying Gravity'

Journalist Tom Mumford joins students testing their theories in weightlessness. From the outside, it looked like a regular aircraft. The pilot informed the young passengers that it was a Boeing KC-135 refueling tanker, built in 1964, based on the Boeing 707. However, the inside was transformed into a long white tunnel with few windows, lit by lights along the padded walls. Most seats were removed, leaving a few at the back where 13 students from Europe and America sat, looking nervous. They had spent a year competing with other students to join this flight, a challenge by the European Space Agency to propose creative experiments in weightless conditions. The best ideas earned a spot on this unique flight, which was like an extraordinary roller-coaster ride.

For two hours, the Boeing would fly like a giant bird, soaring up and then diving down. The goal was to create a weightless state at the top of each curve. At 3,000 meters, the pilot cut the engines, and the plane continued upward by momentum before gravity pulled it back down. In those few silent seconds between rising and falling, everything inside became weightless, and the students felt closer to the moon than Earth.

The takeoff was smooth, but any illusion of a normal flight vanished when the pilot put the plane into a steep 45-degree climb for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, blood rushed from our heads, and bodies were scattered across the cabin floor. Then the engines cut out, and weightlessness was almost immediate. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence: the floor felt like a trampoline, and a single step sent us towards the ceiling. We drifted aimlessly; directions like left, right, up, or down lost meaning. Only gravity, by anchoring us, allows us to understand movement.

After ten seconds of freefall, the pilot pulled the plane out of its dive. Gravity's return was less sudden than its loss, but still abrupt enough to cause some students to land with a thud. With the first curve done, some students turned pale at the thought of 29 more. Thirty curves meant ten minutes of 'space time' for experiments. Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to understand how cats always land on their feet. They released the device, and one student managed to turn it belly-down using radio controls. However, during the next curve, another student accidentally landed on it.

Nearby, a German team from the University of Aachen studied how metal joins are affected by the lack of gravity, important for future space station construction. Another team from Utah State University explored creating solar sails from thin liquid films hardened by ultraviolet sunlight. They spent the flight trying to produce these films in microgravity, believing that perfected solar sails could use the sun's radiation like a yacht uses the wind.

After two hours of swinging between heaven and Earth, breakfast felt unsettled, but the main feeling was exhilaration, not nausea. This sensation would last a long time. "It was an unforgettable experience," said one student. "I already wanted to become an astronaut, but now I want to even more."

Jonathon Porritt, author of "Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology," shares his unique experience of spending nine consecutive winters in New Zealand. He traveled there every summer from the UK, which is winter in New Zealand, and enjoyed the cold season. His parents bought a small piece of land near Auckland for him and his siblings to manage. They were encouraged to plant trees on it, giving them a lasting connection to New Zealand, where their father grew up.

The land, located in Rangitoupuni, was not very fertile but suitable for tree planting. Jonathon, who had experience working on farms in Australia, was excited about the project. He began planting trees in 1968, and by 1972, he and his siblings had planted all 70 acres. Despite the constant rain and cold during that first winter, Jonathon remembers it as a happy time. Each day involved preparing for planting in wet and muddy conditions, which led to deep reflections on life.

An experienced tree-planter helped Jonathon in the beginning. They used a planting bag to carry as many trees as possible, and the hardest part was keeping the planting lines straight. Once the lines were set, planting became a rhythmic process. This repetitive work allowed Jonathon to think deeply about the natural world, sparking ideas that influenced his later life.

Jonathon has returned to New Zealand four times to see the trees grow, which he finds very rewarding. He worries about natural disasters affecting the trees but is pleased they are now thriving after 20 years. In 1984, he took a break from teaching to spend three months alone on the tree farm, where he wrote his first book, "Seeing Green." The simple cabin on the farm became his writing retreat. This place holds a strong connection for Jonathon, symbolizing the bond between people and the land.

Text: 'BRINGING UP BADGERS'

When one of my helpers handed me a cardboard box, my first thought was, "What now?" My husband Derek and I had turned our dairy farm in Somerset into an 'open farm' six years ago, and we had become known for caring for orphaned animals. The noise from the boxâ€”a mix between a cackle and a barkâ€”was unfamiliar to me. Curious, I looked inside and found three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their coats, which later turned out to have fleas, felt like velvet, and their milky eyes looked up at me from their tiny black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most are born between mid-January and mid-March and spend their early life underground. If orphaned, they usually die of starvation and are never found. These three were brought in by building contractors who accidentally dug into their sett while laying drain pipes. The mother was found dead with her babies still nursing. The cubs were healthy but cold and whimpering. After removing their fleas, I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and placed them by the stove for warmth. There were two females, Primrose and Bluebell, and a male, Willow. At first, I fed them with a syringe, but I had to wipe each cub with a warm cloth to mimic the mother's licking, which helped them relieve themselves. For the first few days, they were fed every four hours. Within a week, they were drinking from a bottle and moving around, though unsteadily. With each other for company and a heated pad as a substitute 'mum,' they seemed content. 

Three weeks later, I noticed Willow was lethargic, though he was still eating normally. It was a warning sign I didn't recognize, and the next morning, I found him dead. The vet's post-mortem revealed Willow had died from a lung infection. When bottle-feeding any animal, it's important not to let it drink too fast, as liquid can enter the lungs. In Willow's case, this caused an infection that would have been hard to treat, even with antibiotics, in such a small animal. Disheartened by my failure, I continued caring for the others. Then, six days later, a local farmer who heard about our cubs brought me another male cub he found abandoned. The area had been disturbed too much, and the cub was cold and hungry. We named him Willow II. At six weeks, he was about two weeks younger than the females, and I soon discovered why his mother left him. He was very difficult to feed. I had to keep moving the bottle's teat around in his mouth and squeezing it to get him to drink. After ten minutes, he would finally latch on as if he hadn't drunk all day. By the end of April, the females were weaned onto creamed rice and then anything else. Willow was different. He was happy to give up the bottle but couldn't eat without walking through his food, tipping it over, or sitting in it. Eventually, I offered him a sausage, which he slowly chewed, played with, and finally ate. After a week of sausages, he was ready to try other foods. 

At nearly five months old, they were all eating cereals for breakfast, a meat and vegetable meal for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Badgers usually eat 60% earthworms, plus beetles, bugs, baby rabbits, mice, voles, and even plant shoots or roots. My badgers were better off than others that year; the summer was very hot, making it hard to dig for earthworms. By August, my foundlings had become nocturnal and would only go for walks at dusk or late at night. We often walked through the cider orchard, where the cubs would get excited, fluff up their fur to look like snowballs, and chase each other's tails. As 'human badgers,' we were part of this game. I learned to avoid their playful nips, but Derek, who joined us less often, never did and sometimes reacted colorfully to being caught. During these late-night walks in the dry period, I saw other badgers in our field. They were likely expanding their territories to find food, as badgers are very territorial and will kill intruders. We were warned they might climb into our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we covered the gate with sheet metal to keep it secure. The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and the response was so great that we started an appeal to build a sett on the farm for them. With advice, we designed a new home for the badgers. Our son Daniel drew up the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels, an enclosure, and a badger gate facing their usual walking direction. It had three chambers, one larger than the others, with a glass side for viewing from a darkened enclosure. As the sett took shape, the badgers explored it before their walks. Eventually, they forgot about the walks, excited by the tunnels and arranging bedding. The building cost more than expected, but a local bus company, Badgerline, sponsored part of the appeal, and local firms donated materials. Everyone wanted to see the badgers with a home of their own. One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Half an hour later, I returned to find them curled up asleep in their chambers. These days, I don't walk with them as often, especially since they wake up at midnight. We see Primrose occasionally, as she has joined a neighboring sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still greet us before rushing off into the night. This is their territory now, a place they know well and a home they have accepted.

Text: 'In search of true north - and the man behind Halley's comet Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, plans to follow Sir Edmund Halley's journey to map compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports. Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, one of his major achievements was mapping 'compass variations' during his sea voyages on the warship Paramore. These variations, now called 'declination', refer to the angle between magnetic north and true north. Without understanding declination, sailors couldn't accurately correct their compasses, making it difficult to determine longitude and navigate the seas. Halley, one of the few people paid to do scientific research at the time, set out for the Cape Verde Islands to map declination in the North and South Atlantic. The first trip was cut short due to crew issues, but Halley tried again. This second voyage took him to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. From these travels, Halley published a 'New and Correct Chart showing the Variations of the Compass in the Western and Southern Oceans' in 1701. This chart and its later versions were crucial for sailors for over a century until changes in Earth's magnetic field made them outdated. Dr. Clark, an enthusiastic sailor, wants to honor Halley's achievements by retracing the Paramore's route for its three-hundredth anniversary. He needs to raise Â£70,000 for the journey, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, known for leading the first cross-Antarctica expedition, is supporting him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley during a two-year stay at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about the scientist's life. 'Halley led a remarkable life,' Dr. Clark says. 'He was a respected scientist and explorer. He wasn't just an astronomer; he also did geophysics research. As Astronomer Royal, he mapped stars and pursued other interests.' During this time, Halley invented a diving bell and advised Sir Isaac Newton on his Principia Mathematica, a key work in classical physics. Dr. Clark believes recreating the voyage will give Halley the recognition he deserves. The expedition, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will also have scientific value. It will involve taking the same measurements Halley did, but with more accurate instruments. These measurements are important because Earth's magnetic field is always changing. The data will help improve the international geomagnetic reference field, a model of Earth's magnetic field. 'It's common to measure the size but not the direction of the magnetic field. You need to know true north to measure direction,' says Dr. Clark. 'On our expedition, we can use global positioning satellites for that.' The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements globally. Dr. Clark hopes his data will fill any gaps in the satellite's coverage of the Atlantic Ocean and provide useful ground-based comparisons. It's easy to forget how important Halley's Atlantic journey was. It was the first scientific sea expedition, and Halley was the first civilian naval captain focused on declination. Does Dr. Clark have what it takes to succeed in his voyage? Besides his two years in Antarctica and work with the British Geological Survey's geomagnetic group, he has already sailed 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews. Does he share Halley's passion? 'I'm willing to dedicate eight months of my life to this, so some might say I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't cross the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his fascinating life have given me a real sense of purpose.'

Every summer, peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tails to the female peahens, who often look at them critically. This behavior puzzled Charles Darwin because, in a world where survival is tough, it seemed strange that birds would evolve such extravagant features. Darwin believed that evolution happened through natural selection, where the fittest individuals survive and reproduce. However, the peacock's tail seemed to be a disadvantage, so Darwin suggested another idea called 'sexual selection.' He thought females chose mates based on beauty alone.

Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, disagreed. He believed that if peahens chose the most beautiful males, there must be a practical reason. The males with the best tails might have other qualities that help them survive, even if humans can't see them. Wallace thought the tail was a sign of these hidden qualities.

Today, scientists like Marion Petrie are studying peacocks at Whipsnade to understand this better. They want to know if peahens really prefer males with the showiest tails and if these males have other advantages. Observations suggest that peahens do prefer males with more eye-spots on their tails, which are linked to tail length. However, it's still unclear if these males are better in other ways.

William Hamilton from Oxford University proposed that showy male birds might be healthier and free of parasites, which their plumage could indicate. While this is true for some birds, Petrie and her team haven't been able to test this in Whipsnade peacocks yet. This year, they are comparing the offspring of attractive and less attractive males to see if the former grow faster or are healthier, which would support Wallace's idea.

There's another theory by R.A. Fisher called 'Fisher's Runaway.' It suggests that if females start preferring males with slightly better tails, their offspring will inherit these traits. Over generations, this preference could lead to increasingly extravagant tails, supporting Darwin's idea of 'beauty for beauty's sake.' Modern computer models show that this feedback loop could explain the peacock's tail.

Text: 'THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS The best boat design should blend old and new, says Tom Cunliffe. He did this with his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of impressive yachts with the latest technology. Most of these yachts are based on design changes from 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat is quietly moored on a tidal creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it could be 100 years old, making people think I'm a romantic dreamer. Maybe I am, but I doubt it. This boat uses the charm of traditional design, but modern technology made it easier to build. However, while modern technology is essential in today's boat design and building, it often shields sailors from the true experiences of sea life. These are often the experiences they seek when they go to sea. I'm not saying sailors should suffer through every hardship. I always make sure my boats have a coal stove for warmth and dry comfort, and cozy sleeping areas. But why go sailing if every sail operates automatically? Sometimes, dealing with a flapping sail is part of a sailor's life. And why should we give up common sense and move our steering positions from the safe back of the boat to a risky spot halfway to the front? Sadly, this is done to create a cabin as spacious as an ocean liner, with a bed bigger than the one at home. For me, a boat should always be a boat, not a floating cottage. When I bought my previous boat, Hirta, which I sailed around Britain for a TV race series, the previous owner said she had every comfort but no luxury. During my time with her, Hirta showed me how wise he was. Her sails were heavy, and she had no pumped water, no significant electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics, especially for navigation, yet she was the kindest, easiest boat I have ever sailed. However, classic boats need a lot of care because they are old. After a serious back injury, I realized my 15-year love affair with her had to end. I couldn't find a suitable younger boat, so I decided to build a new one from scratch. The Westerman has never let me down. Although designer Nigel Irens and his assistant Ed Burnett are skilled with computer design programs, Irens first sketched this boat on a paper napkin and later used the computer. After creating a set of lines, he carved a model, just like in the old days. We reviewed the initial model, then adjusted the design on the computer. The next version was almost perfect, and the final one was just right. The finished boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of her first six races. She looks timeless, moves beautifully at sea, and her interior, made mostly of reclaimed pitch pine, feels peaceful. This might be because she was designed purely as a sailing vessel, without considering any furniture. This is the traditional way of the sea. In her timeless calm, she proves that this method works; that you don't need to follow trends to find satisfaction, and that sometimes it's wise to learn from history. Built with wood treated with a special glue, she is completely waterproof. So, she has all the advantages of a fiberglass boat but looks, feels, and sails like a traditional one.'

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are thriving. We asked five journalists to review some of these places.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**

I was thrilled to spend six days at Henlow Grange as I needed a break. My room in the large 18th-century house was extremely comfortable, and I felt relaxed immediately. On the first day, I rested and slept a lot. From the second day, I joined various classes like body conditioning, yoga, and body alignment. The instructors are very skilled, and I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments, including aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The hour-long facial made me feel rejuvenated. The staff were friendly and professional, creating an energetic and enthusiastic atmosphere. Henlow plans to renovate, adding a half-size Olympic pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds or enjoy a peaceful walk in the garden. My mood and appetite improved during my stay, and I left feeling energized. This is an ideal getaway for a stressed working woman. Save Room 5 for me! - Marcella D'Argy Smith

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**

The calm atmosphere of this stately home was clear as soon as I entered. The Hall has a beautifully decorated library, a lovely conservatory, and plenty of space for solitude. Upon arrival, everyone gets a medical check-up, including weight and blood pressure. We were called patients, which felt odd since I was healthy. However, a shoulder issue was found during the check-up and addressed in group workshops and a personal session. Each person follows a specific diet. I lost weight without fasting but had a headache on the second day from hunger. My daily menu included grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and exotic fruit with yogurt and broth for dinner. If not fasting, you eat in the main dining hall, where the food is tasty. Massages or water therapy are given on alternate days, and extra treatments are reasonably priced. - Liz Gregory

**C. CAREYS MANOR**

Careys is not a health farm but a charming old manor with cozy log fires and a spacious lounge. If you're watching your weight, you might skip the gourmet food, which includes rich sauces and creamy desserts made by the French chef. Luckily, there's a gym and pool to burn off the calories. You can choose a health-conscious diet if you want to lose weight. The spa includes a bath, steam room, Swiss shower, sauna, and treatment rooms. A highlight is the sports injury clinic, where I got advice on an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist suggested good posture, exercises, and massage. Careys is both comfortable and luxurious, relaxed and calm. If you want to explore, the surrounding countryside is beautiful. - Beverly D'Silva

**D. CLIVEDEN**

Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. The 376-acre National Trust estate has beautiful woodland walks and gardens. Waldo's, a renowned restaurant, offers a menu that took me half an hour to read. The meal was fantastic, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. I went to bed happy! The next morning, I spent time in the gym to burn off calories before my next meal. In the Pavilion, I enjoyed a facial with essential oils and an aromatherapy massage. Cliveden offers fitness assessments, workouts, and beauty treatments if you want them before indulging at Waldo's. - Kay Letch

**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**

The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It's delicious but has 360 calories, which isn't great if you're trying to lose weight. You've been warned! The second best thing is the aromatherapy massage. I chose relaxing oils, fell asleep twice during the massage, and had a refreshing night's sleep. The modern facilities are efficiently run, with luxurious bedrooms. There are many therapists and beauty rooms, so scheduling appointments is easy. They offer a variety of treatments, from manicures to deep-cleansing facials. Guests range from football teams to mothers and daughters, friends, and singles.
