He even doubted the paper's success, thinking it was as likely as a millionaire personally supporting him. When he first saw someone reading his review on the London Underground, he was unsure how to react.

Tom's idea for a team of critics didn't work out as planned, and they ended up coordinating by phone. The public preferred critics to focus on one area, so Mark chose film. Thanks to Tom's initial push, Mark now writes a detailed weekly piece on one film, which suits him. He wouldn't have enjoyed the typical critic's job of reviewing every film, as it would quickly become monotonous. The freedom he has allows him to explore his arguments more deeply or find something interesting to say even in a dull week.

Mark questions his role in influencing the public. He believes people choose films based on stars, publicity, or directors, and rarely change their preferences because of a review. For instance, someone who dislikes westerns is unlikely to watch one after reading a review, and a fan of romantic films won't avoid one because of critics. So, if reviews aren't just consumer guides, what are they? Mark doesn't feel he needs to be 'right' about a movie or that there should be a set number of 'great' or 'bad' films each year. His job is to present an argument, not to act as a judge, which he has no desire to be.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers? Because she thinks it's fun. A teenager with a passion for endurance sports is looking for a training partner. Ideally, this person should be female and interested in becoming an Olympic champion. They should love long-distance running (regular 15 km sessions), swimming (enjoy training in cold rivers during winter), and cycling (enjoy 100 km rides). They must be able to do all three activities without resting.

The triathlon is becoming one of the most popular Olympic sports. It attracts large crowds who are both fascinated and shocked by athletes swimming 1500 meters, cycling 40 kilometers, and running 10 kilometers without stopping. It might be exciting for spectators, but why do triathletes push their bodies so hard? And why would a talented 17-year-old with excellent grades give up everything for this challenging sport?

Melanie Sears hasn't yet learned the usual phrases about personal satisfaction and mental challenges that athletes often use. She says, "You swim 1500 meters, then jump on your bike while still wet, which makes you cold. After cycling 40 kilometers, you have to run 10 kilometers, which feels long when you're tired. But it's great fun and worth it in the end."

Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14 and won the junior section, although she was the only junior competing. Feeling confident, she entered the National Championships. Despite having the second-fastest swim and the fastest run, she didn't place well. She got lost during the cycling part and ended up riding 20 kilometers too far, crying through the run. But she didn't give up and is determined not to. "Sometimes I wish I could stop to end the pain, but I'm afraid if I stop once, I'll be tempted to do it again."

Her determination impresses Steve Trew, the sport's director of coaching. He says, "I tested her fitness, and she worked so hard on the running machine that it threw her off into a wall. She gave it everything, but unlike most people who stop when they can't go further, she kept going."

Melanie was the top junior at this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. She was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running but slower in cycling, so she's working hard to improve. She's trying to convince her parents, who are paying Â£1,300 for her trip to New Zealand for the World Championships, to buy her a Â£2,000 bike (with a Â£1,000 discount) so she can compete in national 25 km and 100 km races later this year.

However, her intense training has made her a bit of a loner. "I don't have a social life," she says. "I'm not a party person anyway. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I keep in touch with the other girls on the team by phone and letters." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, we talk about the times we're achieving."

Where will all this focus lead? Melanie has tried other events, like the triathlon 'sprint,' which involves swimming 750 meters, cycling 20 kilometers, and running 5 kilometers. She wants to try even tougher events than the triathlon. "The big problem is, I have no one my age to train with," she says. It's surprising, isn't it?

Amanda Roy discusses her love for collecting and why many people share this hobby. Collecting is a popular pastime, with one in three adults participating. It's a world filled with passion and excitement. But remember, only collect items you truly love. 

Since ancient times, humans have collected things. Early humans collected pebbles for their beauty, wearing them as necklaces. This was one of the first instances of collecting for intellectual and spiritual reasons. Today, children still collect stones and seashells for their beauty.

I've been a collector all my life, gathering everything from tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. At six, I went to a school in a remote, windy part of England. My parents would visit and take me to a local museum filled with historical collections, which fascinated me.

Many people share my interest in collecting. The reasons vary, but some find it gives them a sense of control. For me, it's simply enjoyable. Historical figures like the Duc de Berry in France and Catherine the Great of Russia were famous collectors. The Duc de Berry had a 'room of wonders' with items like coconut shell cups and Oriental china. Catherine the Great collected over 4,000 paintings. But you don't need to be wealthy to collect. I've collected tulip bulbs and china cups with great determination. I once convinced another tulip collector to give me a bulb, only to have it stolen later.

I also collected 350 American rag dolls, searching across the USA for different designs. Unfortunately, this collection was lost in a house fire. The next day, I stood in the ruins, unsure if I was more upset about the furniture or the dolls.

I'm intrigued by how collections change hands. A silver spoon once owned by a king or poet gains value because of its history. As items become popular among collectors, their prices rise. Toys from the 1950s are now valuable investments, especially if you kept the original boxes. Sadly, I threw mine away, along with the toys.

Text: 'My line of work Four people talk about their jobs. Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum I organize temporary exhibitions. This involves planning, designing, and promoting them. I research the exhibition topic and talk to experts to decide on the main themes and goals. I plan what objects and pictures to display and ensure the public understands the exhibition's message. This includes planning interactive displays, workshops, and theatre. I also coordinate with engineers and electricians to ensure safety. Before the exhibition opens, I help design and write brochures and leaflets to inform the public. Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers I start my day at 7.30 a.m. by checking the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents are needed for students to learn the routes for the London taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are in school, figuring out the best routes using the correct streets and turns. I help when there's a disagreement, like whether a right turn is allowed at a junction. As they get closer to the test, I challenge them by giving them a route and then telling them it's blocked, so they have to find another way. This is to make them think. Sarah - Marine Conservationist I live by the coast and work from home. My job includes answering phone enquiries, creating educational materials, and setting up training courses. I sometimes go to the main office but mostly work on the coast. I work with schools and study centers and run courses for coastal managers and decision-makers about the seas. I take them out to sea to help them understand marine life better, which often changes their views. I love my job because conservation is my passion, but working for a charity means I always need more funding and can't do everything I want. Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher My job is varied. I ensure our publishing program meets market needs and maintain stocks of about 300 books. We have high standards for information and content. We get many letters from readers about issues like international boundaries, which need careful responses. I discuss future projects and current sales with co-publishers. I work with an enthusiastic team, which makes the job enjoyable. The downside is the excessive administration, which leaves less time for interesting tasks like product development and design.'

We always went to Ireland in June. Since we started going on holidays together, the four of us spent the first two weeks of June at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a big house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who own the house, the Malseeds, have expanded it, but they've done it very tastefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement back when the Malseeds still needed to advertise. "How about this?" he said one evening and read out the details. The summer before, we had gone to a hotel recommended by friends, but it wasn't great because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, though my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school because Dekko Deacon sounds nice, I guess. He and Strafe went to school together, which is why we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We're all about the same age and live near the town where the Malseeds lived before moving from England to Ireland. We always think it's quite a coincidence. "How very nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling as she welcomed us again this year. She seems to know when guests are about to arrive because she's usually waiting in the large, low-ceilinged hall that always smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. "Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium." She was referring to the names of the rooms reserved for us. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of little details like that, while her husband handles redecoration and repairs. "Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said, entering the hall from the kitchen door. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he greeted us in the Irish way. He was smiling broadly, his dark brown eyes twinkling, making us feel like we were more than just hotel guests. Everyone smiled, and I could feel the others thinking that our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was as it should be. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone in the hall laugh again. Arthur led the way to the rooms, carrying as much of our luggage as he could and then returning for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but didn't stay up too late because we were still tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man on his own and a French couple. There were other people at dinner, of course, because in June, Glencorn Lodge is always full. From where we sat by the window, we could see some guests strolling on the lawns, others taking the cliff path down to the seashore. In the morning, we'd do the same: walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, returning in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we'd drive somewhere. I knew all that because, over the years, this routine had developed. Since we first came here, we had all fallen in love with every variation of its beautiful landscape.

Text: 'Keeping the holiday-makers happy A chalet girl's work is never done, Sarah Sutherland-Pilch tells Veronica Lee - in between making beds and delicious dinners. This is the second year as a chalet girl for Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex. Known by her nickname, Pilch, Sarah works for a company in Val d'Isere, France, cooking and cleaning for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses, known as chalets, that are characteristic of the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. Being a chalet girl isn't a career, she says, but an enjoyable way to spend a year or two before settling down. 'It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week.' Sarah does not 'live in'. She gets up at 7a.m. to walk the mile or so to the chalet, which sleeps up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing that of the guests. 'They get the works - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit and croissants.' When the last of the guests has had breakfast, by about 9.30 a.m., Sarah clears up and either makes the afternoon tea, which is left for the guests to help themselves, or cleans the rooms - 'the worst part of the job,' she says. By about 11 a.m. she is ready to go on the slopes herself. She skis as much as possible. 'On a good day we can be up there until 4.30 p.m.' Sarah returns to the chalet in time to prepare dinner and takes a shower before doing so, but does not sleep. 'It's fatal if you do,' she says. Dinner, a three-course affair, is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. Sarah clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. 'There's nothing worse than coming in to a messy kitchen the next morning.' Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests, other times they are content to be left alone. 'Good guests can make a week brilliant - breakfast this morning was great fun - but some weeks, for whatever reason, don't go quite so well.' Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives - and they go out at about 11 p.m. 'We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's and perhaps Dick's T-Bar at the end of the evening,' she says. But Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night as Sunday is her busiest time of the week. 'A frightful day,' she says, 'when you certainly don't want to be cooking breakfast with a terrible headache.' Work begins earlier than usual on Sunday, since breakfast for guests who are leaving has to be on the table by 7 a.m. As soon as the guests are gone, Sarah starts cleaning madly. 'We just blitz the place - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready.' If she hasn't already done the week's shop on Saturday, Sarah does it now. At around 3 p.m., the cleaning work done, Sarah then prepares tea for the new guests. 'They get here at around 4.30 p.m.' Sometimes they are disorientated and full of questions. I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them.' Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes any guests needing boots or skis down to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet from one of the ski shop staff. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a drink later, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night,' she says. '

Miss Rita Cohen, a small, pale-skinned girl who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but said she was about six years older, visited his factory one day. She wore overalls and big, unattractive shoes, and her pretty face was surrounded by a bush of wiry hair. She was so small and young-looking that Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania, researching the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. A few times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could see his factory, and sometimes he would help a student by answering questions over the phone or, if they seemed very serious, by giving them a short tour. Rita Cohen seemed almost as small as the children from Marie's third-year class, who had visited the factory years ago to see how Marie's father made gloves. They especially liked the laying-off table, where the men shaped and pressed each glove by pulling it over steam-heated brass hands. These hands were very hot, shiny, and stood straight up from the table, looking thin and flat. As a child, Marie was fascinated by them and called them the 'pancake hands'. Rita asked, 'How many pieces come in a shipment?' Seymour replied, 'Between twenty and twenty-five thousand.' She kept taking notes and asked, 'Do they come directly to your shipping department?' He was pleased that she was interested in every detail. 'They go to the tannery first. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they prepare it for us to work with. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. I did too, for six months, when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?' 'Not yet.' 'Well, you need to visit a tannery if you're going to write about leather. I can arrange that for you if you'd like. They're primitive places. Technology has improved things, but what you'll see isn't much different from hundreds of years ago. It's tough work. It's said to be the oldest industry with remains found anywhere. Six-thousand-year-old tanning relics were found in Turkey, I believe. The first clothing was just skins tanned by smoking them. I told you it was an interesting subject once you get into it. My father is the leather expert; he's the one you should talk to. Start him on gloves, and he'll talk for two days. That's typical: glove makers love the trade and everything about it. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?' 'I can't say I have.' 'Never seen anything made?' 'I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child.' He laughed. She made him laugh. An innocent with spirit, eager to learn. His daughter was at least 30 cm taller than Rita Cohen, fair where Rita was dark, but otherwise, Rita reminded him of Marie. The good-natured intelligence that filled the house when Marie came home from school, full of what she'd learned. How she remembered everything, neatly written in her notebook and memorized overnight. 'I'll tell you what we're going to do. We're going to take you through the whole process. Come on. We're going to make you a pair of gloves, and you're going to watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?'

Text: 'Is it really a dream job? Chris Arnot talks to four people with jobs that seem perfect to find out if they truly are. 

A. Raquel Graham
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She can't meet me tomorrow because her boss needs her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she often has to travel at a moment's notice. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss, but there's one small issue - she hates flying. 'On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to calm myself,' she admits. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. 'It felt so cramped with those tiny windows.' When she's not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. Her tasks include organizing the diary, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning schedules, and making more travel arrangements. She didn't apply for the job; she got it after meeting a pop group's manager by chance and took a secretarial course in the evenings. Five years later, she was in the right place when her boss needed a PA.

B. David Brown
David Brown has been both an accountant and a golf caddy, someone who carries a golfer's bags. Overall, he preferred being a caddy, especially since golf is his passion. However, there are downsides. Caddies earn a small flat fee plus a percentage of the golfer's winnings, with average earnings between Â£25,000 and Â£35,000, much of which goes to travel and hotels. He started caddying for golfer Greg Norman at age 31. 'It's not just carrying bags. You give advice, use your knowledge against the weather, and try to understand the course.' His accountancy skills were recognized by European Tour Productions, who made him a statistical data administrator. He compiles and analyzes daily play statistics from cards brought in by caddies, which are used by TV commentators, golf magazines, and golfers.

C. Martin Fern
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' section of a daily newspaper, and one of his easier tasks is trying food at top restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? 'For those who can afford it, it's their choice,' he says. 'I'd rather spend Â£120 on a memorable meal than buy a microwave.' His cooking talent led to a food column offer from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. At the time, Martin was a creative director at an advertising agency, and the column was a useful extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. 'It meant a 50% cut in guaranteed income,' he says. 'But it was a chance to turn my passion into a career.' He still cooks at home and tries to keep fit by cycling a few miles to the nearest tube station.

D. Dick Prince
'I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago,' says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's authors. 'Before that, I loved words and enjoyed using them, but mostly wrote poetry. Then I had an idea for a story. I had been a farmer and knew about the problem of foxes killing chickens. So I wrote a story with a twist called The Fox Busters, which became my first published children's book.' Where do his ideas come from? 'Well, it's not easy, I have to work at them,' he says. 'That's what I usually do in the mornings. I'm not an early riser. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing out the morning's notes - all with one finger on an old portable typewriter instead of a laptop. I get between 50 and 100 letters a week, and that's the part of being a writer I enjoy most. I try to answer them all, but now I have some secretarial help.'

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were turned into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Around it were big piles of soft sawdust, like golden mountains, reaching down to the blue lake. That afternoon, with nothing else to do, Michael and his friends climbed a ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs dangling over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof, landing in the sawdust and laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he teased, urging them to follow. Laughing, he watched them hesitate, but one by one, they jumped and stood up, relieved and smiling. In the hot afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust, telling jokes until one of them suggested, "Let's go back up and jump again." They weren't very excited, but they climbed back up and jumped off again, determined, until only Michael was left on the roof. The others were below, grinning and calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong?" Michael wanted to join them but stayed on the roof, nervous and unsure why it seemed so much higher this time. At first, they thought he was joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists, trying to count to ten and jump, or take a deep breath and close his eyes. Eventually, they got tired of waiting and started laughing at him. "Come on, you're a coward. Do you think we'll wait all night?" they shouted, and when he didn't move, they began to leave, still shouting. "Who started this? What's wrong with you?" he called after them. But he stayed on the roof, staring unhappily at the ground. He was alone for nearly an hour as the sun, like a big orange ball, slowly set beyond the lake. His clothes were wet with nervous sweat. Finally, he closed his eyes, slipped off the roof, fell heavily into the sawdust, and lay there for a long time. The yard was silent; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he couldn't jump earlier. Then he got up slowly and walked home, feeling ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You're old enough to get home on time. If you can't, you should stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a touch of grey in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke with controlled sternness, but Michael, with his dark, gloomy face, barely heard her. He was still thinking about the grinning faces and their laughter.

Careers Advice

Are you unhappy with your current job but unsure how to make a change? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people looking to switch careers are turning to careers advisers for guidance. The process usually involves writing a brief personal history and taking several tests called 'psychometrics'. These tests help identify your strengths and suggest possible career paths, along with any retraining you might need.

I decided to try Career Analysts, a major career advice organization. The experience reminded me of taking science exams. I was in a group of about ten people, answering timed questions. It was important to remember that the goal wasn't to pass or fail. The psychometric tests included tasks like finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes. After the tests, I had a detailed conversation with an adviser. Based on this discussion and the test results, the adviser created a report with observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of the conclusions, although I was surprised to learn I didn't do well in scientific, technical, and practical areas. It's probably a good thing I didn't become a nurse. However, it was reassuring to hear that journalism was a good fit for me.

Changing your career doesn't always mean a complete shift. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager at a large insurance company after five years. Her friends suggested she visit Career Analysts. "Losing my job was a chance to step back and review my career," Donna says. Some results were unexpected. "I didn't realize I had a talent for design, but I had to consider the cost of retraining against my financial obligations," she explains. Other options included taking a year off to work in the Far East. Ultimately, she decided to use her existing skills and moved into Public Relations. Donna believes she would have reached this decision on her own, but Career Analysts helped her see her options clearly. She has recommended the service to several friends, who are also satisfied.

Some people feel they wouldn't have made progress without help. A visit to Career Counselling Services led 26-year-old Juliet Greene to make significant life changes. "After six years at a major bank, I found my job boring and wanted a new challenge. I had no idea what to do, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind," she says. The tests showed her interest in sciences. After four sessions with an adviser, she decided to pursue a degree in geology. Juliet feels the advice was worth the cost and is now much happier and more positive.

However, careers advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, says, "I was at a point in my career where I didn't know what to do next. I hoped a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I received many ideas, I rejected them because they required a big salary cut or extensive retraining. I didn't learn anything new about myself," she says. "You have to share a lot of personal information with the adviser, and I felt a friend could have given me similar advice."

Title: 'A New Experience at the Dentist's'

When you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you'll notice bright, modern art on the walls and a stylish blue couch for patients. Jerome explains that half of the people only visit the dentist when they are in pain because they are scared. To change this, he has created a welcoming environment. He doesn't wear a white coat because it reminds people of pain. Jerome believes dental visits should be relaxing and even enjoyable.

This approach is surprising for many who associate dental visits with pain or clinical settings. Jerome says that if patients are relaxed and entertained, they will forget past negative experiences. One of his new techniques is using virtual-reality headsets. His practice was the first in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. During the initial check-up, patients sit on the blue couch and watch a film about underwater wildlife while Jerome examines their teeth. Then, the headset shows a camera view inside their mouth, which most patients find interesting.

The dental office also smells pleasant, like a perfume shop. Today, it smells of orange. Jerome believes that smell is important because the typical dental smell can make people anxious. I found the scent in the office very nice.

Although Jerome is known as a fashionable dentist, he emphasizes that he takes his work seriously. Relaxation is important, but the quality of treatment is the top priority. For example, he uses a tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It feels unusual at first, but it's not painful if you're relaxed.

Five years ago, Jerome went to the U.S. to learn about dental techniques. He discovered that making things easier for patients also makes it easier for dentists. He sees his patient-focused approach as a step towards less formality in British dentistry.

As a patient arrives, Jerome offers him tea, asks what video he wants to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this luxurious treatment, and it's easy to see why. The office feels more like a beauty salon than a typical dental practice.

Title: The Rise of Chocolate

Chocolate, originally from South America, is now a huge global industry. In the UK, people spend over Â£230 million on chocolate during Easter, with 8% of all chocolate sales happening at this time. Only Christmas sees more chocolate consumption. While large-scale chocolate production started in the 19th century, the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over 3,000 years ago. 

The cacao tree is a tropical evergreen found in Africa, the Americas, the West Indies, and Southeast Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and contains 20-40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, often called cocoa beans due to a 17th-century spelling error. The Aztecs used these beans as currency and to make a drink called xocoatl, meaning 'bitter water' in their language, Nahuatl. This drink was spiced and used in ceremonies and to welcome guests. The Spanish later added cinnamon and sugar to make it more enjoyable, but it took another century for the recipe to spread across Europe.

In the late 1600s, chocolate houses opened in European capitals, where people gathered to drink chocolate. Until the 19th century, chocolate drinks were made from solid blocks of chocolate melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands created chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the beans. The chocolate bar as we know it began in 1847 when Fry and Sons in Bristol combined cocoa butter with chocolate liquor and sugar to make a solid, edible block. A Swiss company later added milk solids, creating milk chocolate.

By the early 1900s, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, Cadbury named their Birmingham factory Bournville, hoping to add a touch of French elegance. However, Cadbury's Dairy Milk bar, launched as Dairymaid in 1905, became popular due to clever advertising linking it to the health benefits of English countryside milk. Today, chocolate consumption in Britain is stable at about four bars per week, prompting manufacturers to innovate with products like chocolate-flavored ice creams, drinks, and desserts to attract customers.

Meanwhile, cacao farmers have struggled since a price crash in the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business. So, next time you enjoy a chocolate bar, consider the challenges faced by those who grow the cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

Peter Cooke, at 83, has mastered the art of creating unique objects from shells. Although he is interested in trying other crafts like paper-making and feather-work, he is currently focused on his shell art, which he has been perfecting for the past ten years. As he shows me around his apartment, he worries about being boring, but his enthusiasm and the beauty of his work are captivating.

Cooke points out a pair of shell-covered ornaments above his fireplace, saying he wouldn't mind if they don't sell because he finds them adorable. He never intended to sell his work, but friends encouraged him to hold an exhibition. This led to a successful show in London, where 70% of his pieces were sold. His second exhibition just opened, featuring 86 pieces with prices starting at Â£225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase. Some pieces, like the ornaments, sell for around Â£2,000.

Cooke is open about the high prices, explaining that his work is unique. The gallery owner told him that once he stops creating, his pieces will become even more sought after. Cooke wishes he had started this craft earlier, as he feels physically limited now, but he continues to produce remarkable work.

His creations are far from the typical shell souvenirs found in seaside shops. He has developed his own techniques, using materials like cardboard from laundered shirts and a special glue from a sail-maker. He washes the shells with washing-up liquid. Cooke describes his process as having an idea that "just does itself," but the precision and detail in his work suggest otherwise.

To find beautiful and tiny shells, Cooke has traveled beyond his local Norfolk shore to places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He only collects dead shells and defends himself against accusations of harming the environment. He argues that many shells are crushed by people or broken by the sea, so collecting empty ones is harmless. His work, which often enhances the natural beauty of the shells, supports his argument.

The Schoolgirl Model

When 15-year-old Kira Langer isn't traveling to amazing places and appearing on magazine covers, she's likely studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw learns more about her.

The receptionist at the agency told me, "Kira will be a little late." I said, "That's fine, no problem." I was trying to ignore the negative stereotypes about models being difficult, vain, and unintelligent. Now, she was late. How late would she be? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she decided to go to the hairdresser instead of meeting me? If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and not want to answer my questions.

But when Kira, the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition, arrived, she was smiling, relaxed, and apologetic, and she came with her mother. Kira wasn't wearing expensive designer clothes, just a simple black dress and trainers. She didn't seem selfish at all; she was just a friendly, tall, and pretty girl. Kira explained that all models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work. Her mother looked like a normal, proud mom of a successful daughter.

Kira seems a bit surprised by her sudden fame, which makes sense since it was unexpected. Her older sister was the one who suggested she enter the model competition. "She saw the competition and said I should enter," Kira recalls. "I said no, but she sent some photos in anyway." When Kira found out she was a finalist, she was at school. Being selected for the final gave her the confidence to go through with it, and she performed perfectly. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London offered her work right away.

Kira now finds it challenging to balance her two separate lives. But her friends and teachers are used to having a star among them. "They're really proud of me," she says. However, some unkind people at her school make rude comments about her success. "They say I think too highly of myself." This must be tough for Kira, as she is not self-important. She says, "They think that because I've become a model, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that's changed is I've become more confidentâ€”not in a bad way, but I can stand up for myself more."

As a busy model, her social life is affected. The Select agency can call anytime and tell her she has a job the next day. "If my friends are going out, I can't say I'll come because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get canceled, but my friends are understanding. They don't say, 'Oh, you're always off modeling now, you never have time for us.'"

Kira has the looks, talent, and support for a great career ahead of her. Not many people can say that before they even finish their school exams. As I finish the interview with this successful girl, I ask what she would like to do if she didn't have the beauty that seems to promise a top career in modeling. She pauses and replies, "I'd like to do what you're doing."

Father and son, Terence and Chris Madden, have traveled from Canada's cold north to Africa's heat in search of gold. Terence, an explorer, and Chris, a mineral expert, believe their mine on a Welsh mountain might have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging, they think they are close to finding a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, 68, from Liverpool, said they are finding high levels of gold and need to dig a few more meters to reach the concentrated area.

Their gold search began when Terence read about valuable gold deposits in the 'Dolgellau gold belt' near the Welsh town of Dolgellau. They studied 19th-century mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth to choose the best land to explore. After clearing the area and finding gold bits in the rocks, they spent ten years getting permission from landowners, taking earth samples, and removing old cars and rubbish. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft. Now, they are running out of money and need to find someone to invest Â£50,000 to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says finding a backer is uncertain, but they have some contacts.

As news of their dig spread, the allure of gold caught the attention of locals and gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and residents are hopeful. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said more people might visit if the Maddens find gold, but he hopes it won't lead to many people damaging the hillside. The Welsh gold industry has declined since the late 1880s when many mines employed thousands. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed recently. However, individual gold diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. Hall, 70, says searching for gold is emotional, adventurous, and exciting, with the hope of finding hidden treasure.

IN HOT WATER

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She works at Southampton University as a lecturer and researcher in marine geochemistry, studying the chemical processes in the sea. When she's not teaching, she dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean in a small steel vehicle, about the size of a car, to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, space is so tight that she can touch the two pilots. They are used to these cramped conditions, where they can't stand or move, and must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive lasts 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there's an emergency, they can press a panic button, which releases a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, but Rachel thinks it wouldn't be a pleasant ride.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. She was on a ship's deck with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would handle being in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes with chimneys blowing out black smoke. The Russian team was setting up scientific equipment to study the effects of a project that would drill a 150-meter hole through a volcano.

When she's not at sea, Rachel is in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She spends two-thirds of her time teaching, which she enjoys, but she does it to support her research on "black smokers." These are underwater volcanoes where water comes out of the rock, looking like black smoke. It flows out at one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees Celsius. The only time Rachel felt scared was during a dive with an American team. They were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when there was a sudden explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and Rachel thought she was going to die. They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive.

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, seeing something no one else on Earth has seen before. After studying the black smokers for three years for her PhD, seeing them in person was an amazing experience.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and somewhere under all that, suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body couldn't handle any more stress. My mind was tired of dealing with foreign timetables, currencies, and languages. "Never again," I said as I stepped onto home ground. I said the same thing the next year. And the year after that. All I had to do was buy one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could spend a whole month traveling anywhere in Europe. Once you've learned to sleep in a train corridor, ordinary beds never feel the same. The train's rhythm rocks you into a deep sleep. Carrying everything you own in a backpack makes you travel simply and can lead to burning socks that have become too smelly and getting rid of books when you're done with them. This way of living fits the spirit of Inter-Rail, where common sense and reasoning can be tossed out along with the paperback book and the socks. All it takes to feel this carefree is one of those tickets in your hand. Any system that lets young people travel through countries at a rate of more than one a day must be special. On our first trip, my friends and I didn't realize the potential of this train ticket. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to and from our chosen campsite in southern France. But the idea of non-stop travel was too tempting because there was always one more country over the border, always a little further to go. And what did the extra miles cost us? Nothing. We weren't completely uninterested in culture. But this was our first holiday without parents, like it was for most other Inter-Railers, and we only included the most accessible sights in our schedule. This was our chance to escape the guided tour and do something different. I was proud that, in many places, all I bothered to see was the view from the station. We were just there to get by and have a good time doing so. In this, we were no different from most of the other Inter-Railers with whom we shared corridor floors, food and water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of a place that was just a name before. It's as if the city you arrive in never existed until the train pulls into the station and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by actually seeing Europe, by watching the changing landscapes and noticing the differences in attitudes and lifestyles, can you really have an accurate picture of the continent in your mind. Everyone knows what's there, but it's meaningless until you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos are so boring. While the train trip won't let you discover anything new in a global sense, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is a big place, and Inter-Rail gives people the best chance to realize this, though in our case, it didn't happen immediately.

Arriving at an airport in another country only to find out your baggage is missing is very frustrating. At best, you'll have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline returns your luggage. At worst, you might be in a completely different climate, far from home, and stuck with unsuitable clothing. Airlines don't often disclose how many bags they lose, but frequent travelers will eventually face this issue. Even top airlines make mistakes, and no airline can guarantee your checked luggage will be on the same flight, especially if you have to change planes.

Here's how the system works: Airlines require you to check in early to give enough time for your baggage to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are set to ensure there's enough time to transfer luggage between flights. Usually, this system works well. However, extra security checks and air traffic issues can delay flights, causing the baggage system to fail. Human error or accidents, like a torn-off destination label, can also cause problems. These issues are more common at large transfer airports, or 'hubs', due to the high volume of bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport handled over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone managed two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, often between Terminal 1 and Terminal 4. Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have their off days. The risk of losing baggage is higher at certain airports. In the U.S., Miami airport is known for losing luggage when passengers connect to Latin America.

To avoid losing your luggage, choose direct flights when possible and check in early. If you must change planes or want a cheaper flight, try to stick with the same airline. Allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses, including flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline official in the baggage hall and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.

Charlie James is a wildlife photographer who specializes in kingfishers, which are beautiful blue-green birds that live near streams and rivers and eat fish. These birds are often seen in areas where old trees hang over the water, creating a mix of soft greens, browns, and yellows from the sunlight. The kingfisher moves quickly and directly through this scene, like a flash of light, leaving a lasting impression despite its small size.

Charlie fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. He can't quite explain why he is so drawn to them, but they are legendary birds. In Greek mythology, the kingfisher was a moon goddess who became a bird. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its top turned blue like the sky, and its underside was burned by the sun. Scientifically, kingfishers don't have blue pigment in their feathers. Instead, the structure of their feathers reflects light in a way that makes them look blue, and they can appear green depending on the light.

Many wildlife photographers are fascinated by kingfishers because of their colors and the fact that, while they are shy, they can be observed from a hidden spot. Charlie's first hideout was an old blanket he used to cover himself while waiting for a kingfisher. The bird came close, but it took him four years to get a good picture. During this time, he became very focused on the European kingfisher, the only one of its family that breeds in Europe. He spent as much time as possible by streams rich with kingfishers, even skipping school, which led to him being considered an 'academic failure.'

However, his passion was noticed, and at 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine. He later worked as an assistant to the editor and eventually became a freelance wildlife film cameraman. Now, he dreams of making the ultimate kingfisher film, with no words, just beautiful images. He loves the simple approach and enjoys photographing parts of the kingfisher's wings. His photos express his deep connection with the bird, but he knows there's more to his relationship with kingfishers than his work can show.

**Conducting an Orchestra: Insights from Five New Conductors**

**A. Anne Manson**  
Anne Manson, 30, had an unexpected opportunity when she asked to observe conductor Claudio Abbado's rehearsals in Vienna. She ended up filling in for an absent assistant and was later invited to assist with another opera. Manson, who is American, works with a London-based opera company that focuses on modern pieces. She is gaining recognition in Europe, supported by the British Arts Council, and has worked with Abbado on several occasions since her first experience.

**B. Andrew Constantine**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of conducting is convincing people to give you opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after failing in two others. He feels the timing was perfect, as earlier success might have led to obscurity. The competition opened doors for him, including a role as an assistant to a renowned conductor. However, he is concerned about being permanently labeled as a "competition winner." He notes that orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra, which hired him post-competition, are inviting him back, which is crucial for sustaining his career.

**C. Wasfi Kani**  
Wasfi Kani, founder of Pimlico Opera, enjoys the extensive rehearsal periods in opera production. She began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's business sector until Pimlico Opera became fully professional. Lessons with Sian Edwards were pivotal for her, as Edwards was similar in stature, unlike her previous teachers. Kani appreciates the complexity of opera, including managing singers' personalities and frequent disagreements.

**D. Roger Vignoles**  
Roger Vignoles, 48, found conducting unexpectedly intriguing. His background as a resident musician at an opera house and experience with skilled conductors prepared him for this role. Last year, he directed Handel's "Agrippina" from the piano at a festival, which was less challenging than anticipated. He realized he knew the music well and aimed to achieve his desired performance. Vignoles values the respect he has earned as a musician and is open to exploring various opportunities to discover his preferences.

**E. Wayne Marshall**  
Wayne Marshall, now 32, was noticed by conductor Simon Rattle in 1986, which led to his first conducting job in London on short notice. Despite the challenge, including dealing with musicians who were not fully engaged, he maintained a firm approach and clear direction. Marshall, who has never formally studied conducting, believes in expressing his needs confidently. He acknowledges the kindness of others in his journey and is determined to pursue what he enjoys.

**Variations on a Theme**

If you're planning to take children to a theme park in Britain, there are many options available. We asked five families to try out some of the best ones.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**

Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is great for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. Thereâ€™s a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are more thrilling rides like Splash Out, where you end up in a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the kids wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park lacks a bit of atmosphere, and the scenery could be better. However, the staff are very helpful, and the park is clean, well-organized, and focused on safety.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**

None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didnâ€™t know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He was thrilled with the Mountain Train and especially liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings at his height! The older kids enjoyed the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to rest. The landscaping is beautiful, and the staff are friendly and helpful. Thereâ€™s something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**

After seven hours, we still had more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had an amazing trapeze act that kept us excited. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes shut, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think youâ€™ll get wet, but you donâ€™t. For younger kids, Toy Land is great fun. The children looked at the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved they were too small to go on it! The park is well-designed, so even waiting in line isnâ€™t too boring. Itâ€™s very clean, and the staff are excellent. On one ride, I couldnâ€™t sit with both girls, so a staff member offered to go with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**

We arrived at 1 p.m. and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great theme park for younger children because the rides arenâ€™t too scary. Iâ€™m usually scared, but I enjoyed myself. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts calmly and then becomes really fun. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I didnâ€™t go on the Big Leap, but it looked exciting if youâ€™re brave enough. If the kids were older, they might have found it a bit tame, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**

The park advertises 'No Limit to the Fun,' and we felt that was true. Europeâ€™s tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, stands out, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride, although Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older kids went on several times. Sarah was too small for a few of them but enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staffâ€™s attitudes varied. Some were great with younger kids, but the welcome wasnâ€™t always warm. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldnâ€™t have dared tell the kids we were leaving early.

Running a business in the countryside: Five women share their experiences.

A. CHRISTINE HOGAN runs a computer-aided design business with a yearly turnover of over Â£200,000 and employs four full-time staff. She says, "My customers are friends." Christine and her husband moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home, so she started a computer-aided design business, using her previous experience with computers. It required a lot of money initially, and the start was tough. She was careful with finances, always informing the bank manager if she might overspend. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings if needed. The business remains small, with local clients often picking up their work.

B. MAGGY SASANOW, a greetings card designer, enjoys her independence. She studied art at university and initially wanted to work in a museum. After marrying and moving to the countryside, where museum jobs were scarce, she started her own business. She creates 50 different greetings cards, selling them to museums. She works from a large room at home. The downside of working from home is the constant distraction of household chores. Her business grows through word of mouth, without advertising. Although she misses exchanging ideas with others, she finds more benefits than drawbacks in her work.

C. DELIA TURNER runs a curtain-making business that has faced ups and downs. She started eight years ago when the industry was growing, and her turnover increased from Â£24,000 to Â£80,000 in two years. She once managed six full-time staff but had to let them go due to economic decline, which was difficult as jobs are scarce in her area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband's help and employs women who work from their homes. She adapts by lowering prices when needed and exploring new opportunities.

D. TESSA STRICKLAND manages the editorial and production side of her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago for financial reasons and her love of the country. She enjoys flexible working hours, as 80% of her income comes from international deals, requiring her to take calls at odd hours. The challenge is maintaining discipline to stop working. Her business publishes children's books from various cultures, collaborating with authors and artists. Initially, she felt isolated, having worked in London before.

E. MEG RIVERS runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop with a turnover of Â£250,000 a year, employing six people, some part-time. She started at home ten years ago, focusing on healthy fruit cakes with quality ingredients. As demand grew, she began sending cakes nationwide. Seven years ago, she rented a small building for production, employing a baker, assistant, and professional cake decorator. She now manages the business side and no longer bakes. Her biggest challenge has been financial, as they started with limited funds.

Meet the Amazing Watkins Family

The Watkins family is unique because not only are the sons talented musicians and composers, but their father, John, also makes musical instruments. When John and Hetty Watkins, both schoolteachers from South Wales, needed a cello for their ten-year-old son Paul, they found the cost too high. John decided to try making one himself. He attended evening classes at the Welsh School of Instrument Making for about three years. After practicing on violins and violas, he successfully made his first cello for Paul. Paul used this cello until recently, as John improved his skills and made another one for him.

John has since retired from teaching to become a full-time craftsman, making up to twelve violins a year. Selling a violin to the famous American musician Jaime Laredo was a highlight for him. Both Paul and his younger brother, Huw, were encouraged to play music from a young age. Paul started with the piano and then moved to the cello, inspired by a cellist in his father's music group. Although his parents wanted him to play the violin, Paul preferred the cello. Huw, on the other hand, chose to play the piano and compose music.

Huw, now 22, is making a name for himself as a pianist and composer. Paul, with his father's cello, won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition. At just 20, he became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, a position he held until last year. He now plays a Francesco Rugeri cello, on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. John admits that the Rugeri has a special quality, but believes his own cello will improve with age.

Paul will soon perform Elgar's Cello Concerto on television with the Rugeri cello. However, he won't be able to watch himself, as he will be performing at the Cheltenham Festival the same night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will premiere in London at the Wigmore Hall. John and Hetty will need to be both diplomatic and energetic to keep up with their sons' busy musical schedules in the coming weeks.

The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden for the Trust. According to Gareth, a warden needs common sense and good people skills because they work with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and builders. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his family's farm before becoming a warden. Although he didn't have formal training, his local knowledge and farming experience helped him get the job. 

Gareth finds it useful that he still farms with his parents, as it helps him understand farmers' issues. His farming background also makes him physically fit for tasks like building fences, planting trees, and constructing walls. Working with the Trust has taught him more about nature conservation. He remembers collecting flowers and bird nests as a child and realizes how farming has changed the countryside. He believes it's not the farmers' fault, as they were following government advice.

Initially, farmers and conservationists disagreed, but now they communicate better and understand each other's perspectives. Gareth believes they are close to working together. His job involves conservation, managing public access to Trust land, planting trees, and meeting tenant farmers. He ensures tasks are completed efficiently and enjoys seeing projects finished, although he spends a lot of time on paperwork.

Gareth loves his job, even though he's always on duty. He enjoys talking to the public, except for those who act entitled. He finds dealing with such attitudes frustrating but believes common sense is key. If you have common sense and like outdoor work, you might consider becoming a warden like Gareth. However, don't expect a job opening on the Lleyn Peninsula anytime soon!

Text: 'The Netball Captain In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met with England's netball captain. Kendra Slowinski leads England's netball team. When I met her, she was having a typical day leading up to next month's World Championships: teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. 'Don't you get strange looks?' I asked. 'I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice anything else. I might see cars slow down from the corner of my eye, but that's it.' 'My whole life now is about being at my best for the Championships,' says Kendra. 'I'm on a strict schedule to get as fit as possible.' These are her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries participating. 'We'll have home support, which is special,' she says. 'It's important to improve netball's reputation in this country. Playing here means more pressure. A home crowd will have expectations and give more support. People will expect us to start the tournament well.' Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'As far as I know, we've always beaten them, but they'll be exciting to play. They have a lot of skill.' The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. But, as Kendra points out, the World Championships will be tough. 'You have to push yourself to play every day, there's no rest between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different because there's only one chance, and you have to be ready to make the most of it.' In the fifteen years she's been playing at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. On the court, players are more aggressive. 'You don't train so hard not to win,' says Kendra. 'But once the final whistle blows, you become a different person. We're all friendlier after the game.' Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. 'It's essential that we all think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. 'As captain, I think it's important to have a strong mental attitude and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging the team.' 'From the start, my netball career has been carefully planned,' she says. 'I decided some time ago that this competition would be my last as a player.' She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening candlelight ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.'

Text: 'SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS How should parents handle a child with exceptional musical talent? It's not always obvious how to nurture and support their gift. Some parents might not even notice their child's needs until frustration leads to difficult behavior. While most schools can support academically gifted children, musically talented ones need special attention that regular schools might not provide, especially if music is seen as a secondary subject. These children, along with those encouraged by parents or teachers, might benefit from attending a specialist music school. In Britain, there are five such schools, which are relatively new. They offer a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen to fully develop their skills with guidance from professional musicians. At these schools, students spend one-third to half of their day on music activities, such as individual lessons (up to three hours a week on their main and secondary instruments), orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice for several hours daily in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program focusing on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages, though students can study more subjects if they wish. All five British specialist schools are independent, with small classes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students are boarders, living at the school full-time, which means they grow up with peers who share similar goals and interests. What are the downsides? One major issue is the cost; boarding fees range from Â£12,000 to Â£17,000 a year. However, schools try to help parents of exceptionally talented children with scholarships and financial aid. Another concern is that not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many school directors question the wisdom of admitting children as young as seven into such a demanding environment. They emphasize, though, that their goal is to develop 'well-rounded and balanced individuals'. Separating musically gifted children early can be stressful. Musical talent might fade during teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to a sense of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and provide help and advice if needed. While most former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, many question the limited academic program, which is secondary to music activities. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, feeling frustrated if their intellectual needs aren't met. For these reasons, it might be better to wait until the child is old enough to decide for themselves before considering specialist education. Those who are also academically gifted might thrive in a less specialized setting, like a school with an excellent music department, or by combining regular schooling with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with top teachers and orchestral and chamber music experience. However, this option isn't feasible for families living far from London or other major cities.'

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her house is surrounded by a large garden, which provides many of her painting subjects. The garden is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The garden has a beautiful mix of colors, shapes, and structures, especially in the two long flower borders along the path that goes from east to west. This beauty is partly thanks to the previous owners, who loved gardening and left plants that Susan liked. She also inherited their gardener, Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They got along well, and although Danny initially doubted some of her choices, he understood her vision when she explained she wanted to paint them.

Susan prefers to paint detailed studies of individual plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants in their natural setting, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She explains, "I don't set everything up at once. I paint one flower, which might take a few days, then add another, building the painting over time. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish." Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. She finds the process of flowers decaying fascinating. For example, tulips change shape and open up when left in water, becoming more interesting over time.

Susan has always been interested in plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers from the countryside. She wasn't interested in gardening back then and didn't like garden flowers, thinking they looked artificial. She admired wildflowers for their ability to grow in difficult places, like rock cracks or cliff tops. Today, her garden includes plants from distant lands, which thrive as if they were in their native China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed approach to gardening, similar to an aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm.

With two upcoming exhibitions and plenty of subjects to paint, Susan finds it hard to spend time gardening. She now has an extra gardener to help, but she believes that to stay connected to her work, "you have to get your hands dirty."

Text: 'Keeping the holiday-makers happy A chalet girl's work is never done, Sarah Sutherland-Pilch tells Veronica Lee - in between making beds and delicious dinners. This is the second year as a chalet girl for Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex. Known by her nickname, Pilch, Sarah works for a company in Val d'IsÃ¨re, France, cooking and cleaning for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses, known as chalets, that are characteristic of the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. Being a chalet girl isn't a career, she says, but an enjoyable way to spend a year or two before settling down. 'It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week.' Sarah does not 'live in'. She gets up at 7 a.m. to walk the mile or so to the chalet, which sleeps up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing that of the guests. 'They get the works - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants.' When the last of the guests has had breakfast, by about 9:30 a.m., Sarah clears up and either makes the afternoon tea, which is left for the guests to help themselves to, or cleans the rooms - 'the worst part of the job,' she says. By about 11 a.m. she is ready to go on the slopes herself. She skis as much as possible. 'On a good day we can be up there until 4:30 p.m.' Sarah returns to the chalet in time to prepare dinner and takes a shower before doing so, but does not sleep. 'It's fatal if you do,' she says. Dinner, a three-course affair, is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. Sarah clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. 'There's nothing worse than coming in to a messy kitchen the next morning.' Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests, other times they are content to be left alone. 'Good guests can make a week brilliant - breakfast this morning was great fun - but some weeks, for whatever reason, don't go quite so well.' Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives - and they go out at about 11 p.m. 'We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's and perhaps Dick's T-Bar at the end of the evening,' she says. But Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night as Sunday is her busiest time of the week. 'A frightful day,' she says, 'when you certainly don't want to be cooking breakfast feeling exhausted.' Work begins earlier than usual on Sunday, since breakfast for guests who are leaving has to be on the table by 7 a.m. As soon as the guests are gone, Sarah starts cleaning madly. 'We just blitz the place - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready.' If she hasn't already done the week's shop on Saturday, Sarah does it now. At around 3 p.m., the cleaning work done, Sarah then prepares tea for the new guests. 'They get here at around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are disoriented and full of questions. I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them.' Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes any guests needing boots or skis down to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet from one of the ski shop staff. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a chat with friends, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night,' she says.'

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing what to wear was hard because I usually wear a uniform. I visited a photo studio and press previews before lunch. The zoo is calm, but here I was rushing around. Some fashion team members seemed stressed, unlike my job, which isn't pressured. At a fashion shoot, I laughed thinking I'd usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I'm interested in how magazines work, but I love my zoo job, so I'll stay."

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived in leather boots and dark trousers, but the zoo gave me a green polo shirt, which was good because I got dirty. As I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad but had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I might work with elephants, maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, joined the TV gardening show Ground Force. "I was excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was nice. I liked being in the fresh air since I sometimes don't see daylight due to my shifts. It was hard work but fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. My idea of gardening didn't include hard work or planning. I'm more enthusiastic than effective, so I won't leave my nursing job."

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener with Ground Force, worked at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and gave out tablets. I thought I'd faint, but I was fine. The nurses' friendship was great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. My job feels like a waste compared to nursing. My day at the hospital wasn't pleasant, but it was satisfying."

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform and felt differentâ€”people respected me. Before the flight, we learned about safety and handling heart attacks, which I knew from fitness training. On the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines and felt self-conscious. On the return, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one adult."

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer. "I was nervous because I don't exercise. I was surprised by the attention given to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, I was surprised some trainers didn't eat super healthy, but they drank lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job, but it inspired me to join a gym and be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Journey Memories**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There's a local train from Cannes that travels along the coast and crosses into Italy. It offers stunning views of the sea, no matter the weather or season. On the other side, you can see some of the most beautiful gardens and homes in France, making you feel like you're peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The passengers are always lively, a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the breathtaking journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I've enjoyed many train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels across the desert in northern Sudan. Growing up in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. When I moved to England as a teenager, I had never been on a train. London Waterloo was the first real station I saw, and its great glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I'm especially grateful to the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone mentioned that pink is good for the brain, and I've worn it ever since. The journey through France and then by boat up the Nile to Luxor was the perfect way to relax after the wedding preparations.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in an African country. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The timetable was unreliable; we were just given a day. We heard the driver would often wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train arrived, hundreds of people climbed into and onto the carriages, with some even traveling on the roof for free. At night, the train crossed some of the most beautiful landscapes I've ever seen, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite train memories as children, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw few trains. It wasn't until I was a teenager that trains became important to me. I made a film featuring a railway in Yorkshire, mostly filmed on an old, disused line maintained by volunteers. That's where my love for steam trains began. When we weren't filming, we rode the train whenever we could. When I returned last year, it felt like time had stood still; everything was still in place, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Are you trying to get published? If you're wondering where to send your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has the advice you need. Many readers ask us, "I've written a story or book. Who should I send it to?" The first thing to know is that you should research the market and learn about publishers while improving your writing skills. Selling your writing requires understanding the publishing world. No matter what you write, you need to know the markets you're targeting. The best way to do this is by reading everything relevant. Visit your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what publishers are currently accepting.
