Keep updating this knowledge because new publications appear, editors change jobs, and magazines shift focus. Publishers are always looking for new talent, so writers must provide what they want. 

If you're unsure what to write, start by exploring different options. For example, if you want to write short love stories, first find out which magazines publish them. Get recent copies and study the stories they buy, paying attention to the readers. Editors focus on meeting their readers' needs. Writers often ask me, "My story has been rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?" As a former teacher, I never discourage anyone, but if the work isn't publishable, I give honest feedback with a positive outlook. Many new writers send their work out too soon, often before they're ready. If you've only written one story or article, it's unlikely to be published. Success usually comes after years in publishing or journalism. 

When you send your work for the first time, keep writing more stories while waiting for a reply. Write ten or even twenty more. Each one will improve, and you'll start seeing yourself as a writer. Your fluency and confidence will grow. Don't throw any work awayâ€”improve it instead. I also suggest not showing your work to others, especially early on. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course nearby or join a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if possible.

On the last day of a difficult year, I was at the Baltimore railway station, waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. The station was busier than usual, losing its usual clean and airy feel. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and college students sat on the floor with their bags. A well-dressed, grey-haired man was moving around, asking strangers questions. He approached a woman sitting alone and then a girl standing near me, who had long blond hair. He asked her, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" She replied she was heading north but to New York, not Philadelphia. He thanked her and moved on.

I became curious about him. He asked an old lady if she was going to Philadelphia, but she said Wilmington, so he moved on. I was going to Philadelphia, but he didn't ask me, probably because I didn't look reliable to him. He seemed stressed and asked a woman reading a book if she was going to Philadelphia. She said yes, and he asked her for a favor. I pretended to check my watch, even though I didn't have one, and listened.

The man explained that his daughter was flying abroad for a study year and had forgotten her passport. She called from the Philadelphia station, unsure of what to do. He told her to stay there, and he would find someone to bring her passport. The woman asked why he didn't go himself, and he said he couldn't leave his wife alone because she was in a wheelchair. This seemed like a weak excuse to me, and I was suspicious. The man held a padded envelope, not a plain one, which seemed odd. I silently warned the woman to be careful.

**Gary and Me**

John Moore, a restaurant owner, shares his story about his son Gary, a well-known TV chef. John believes everyone gets a chance in life. Gary's chance was cooking, and John's was running a restaurant. When John found the restaurant, it was in poor condition, but he saw potential in it. This venture reminded him of his childhood when his mother worked in a factory, leaving him alone. He wanted to ensure family time, so his wife managed the children and the accounts while he ran the business. They lived above the restaurant and valued family meals, which helped their children, Gary and Joe, become confident. From a young age, they interacted with customers, giving them a strong start in life.

Gary was an energetic child. At seven, he once jumped into a corner bath like a pool and knocked himself out. As he grew, he worked for pocket money, starting with odd jobs and then helping in the kitchen by age ten. He was disciplined, often waking up before his father. Gary wasn't very academic but excelled in the kitchen. By 15, he was as skilled as the adults and sometimes managed the kitchen, preparing over a hundred meals. John knew Gary would pursue catering because of his talent. For school work experience, John sent Gary to a friend's restaurant.

Recently, Gary started playing drums and formed a band. John advises him to focus on one thing, saying, "If you chase two hares, you catch neither." He told Gary to achieve his goals by 30, or it might be too late. At 17, Gary went to catering college. On his first day, he quickly completed a morning's work in an hour and helped others. John's proud of Gary's success in TV cooking shows. He taught Gary that hard work is essential because nothing is given for free. Gary seized his opportunity and succeeded. John reflects that if children remember even a little of what parents teach, it's a success. Gary's actions show he listened to his father's advice.

Finding an affordable flat in Dublin was as difficult as finding gold during a gold rush. The best way to find a place was through personal connections: if you knew someone who knew someone leaving a flat, that often helped. But for someone like Jo, who had just arrived in Dublin, there were no personal contacts to rely on. She had no one to inform her about a soon-to-be-vacant bedsit. So, she stayed in a hostel and searched for a place. For Jo, Dublin was a big unknown. She felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she took the train to work there. She never questioned why she was going. Everyone she knew from school assumed she would leave their small town, which they considered boring and isolated. They all wanted to escape, experience life, and have a real existence. Some of her classmates moved to nearby towns like Ennis or Limerick, where they had family to help them settle. But none of Jo's classmates were going to Dublin. She was going alone. Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed permanently in the hostel, as it was run by nuns and safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm, as they were known to be cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a whole week. Jo didn't know her family was still thinking and talking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was close to the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. She hoped it would be nice, that the people would like her, and that it wouldn't be too expensive. There wasn't a line for this flat because it was more like "Third Girl Wanted" than "Flat to Let." The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary. It was a red-brick terraced house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf, who seemed to have been rejected, was coming down the stairs. "Desperate place," she said to Jo. "They're both awful. Common as dirt." "Oh," said Jo and continued climbing. "Hello," said a girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her type." "What did she do?" asked Jo. "Do? She didn't have to do anything. She just looked around, made a face, giggled, and said, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh accent. We wouldn't have her here, would we, Pauline?" Pauline wore a very colorful shirt, almost as bright as her hair. Jo realized Pauline was a punk, which surprised her. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but never talked to one. "I'm Jo, I work at the post office, and I called about the flat." Nessa said they were about to have tea and offered Jo a mug. One mug had "Nessa," another "Pauline," and the third "Other" written on it. "We'll put your name on it if you stay," Nessa said kindly.

People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in marinas, movies, and TV shows. However, the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society warns that dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds explains how their numbers are decreasing. Dolphins are special to us because they are very intelligent, understand human emotions, and represent freedom in the wild seas. TV shows like "Flipper" and "Seaquest" have made us love them even more. But these shows don't show the real problems dolphins face in polluted and overfished seas today. For example, the number of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has dropped by up to 89,000. You might think such popular animals are protected by laws and marine reserves, but they are not, and this could become a major wildlife crisis.

There are 40 different types of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The first two live far out at sea and are rarely seen, so we know little about them. The larger bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and were once found along the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only found in places like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales, and the few that remain show signs of stress.

It's hard to pinpoint exactly why dolphin numbers are falling because their habits are complex. Overfishing, which is reducing fish stocks and harming local fishing industries, also threatens dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish are overfished in one area, they might not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They also risk getting caught in fishing nets, which they can't see. Modern fishing methods use large nets that float or are dragged quickly through the sea. Many dead dolphins have been found on beaches in France and Cornwall, showing marks and cuts from these nets.

Pollution is another problem. Waste and chemicals in the sea can accumulate in dolphins' bodies. For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, so dolphins can absorb them, and they build up in their bodies. Female dolphins then produce milk with high levels of pesticides, passing the poison to their young. There is a case of a young dolphin dying from its mother's poisoned milk.

Perhaps the most debated threat to dolphins is human disturbance. Dolphins live in groups and rely on sound to understand their world. Noise pollution from ships and oil wells travels four times better in water than in air, which might disturb dolphins in ways we don't fully understand yet.

Text: 'GETTING FIT Exercise is crucial for your mind, body, and spirit. It's one of the best ways to keep balance in your life, especially when everything around you feels chaotic and fast-paced. You might be tired of hearing about fitness, but there's a reason it's talked about so much: it's really good for you. There are many reasons to exercise and very few reasons not to, for most people. Exercise improves muscle tone and quickly changes your body shape. It boosts muscle strength and helps you maintain good posture, which is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. It prevents muscle imbalances that can lead to injuries. It quickly improves specific areas like thighs, stomach, and upper arms. It also benefits your heart, lungs, and blood circulation. You might have heard these reasons many times and feel bored by them. But here's something that might catch your attention: exercise helps reduce depression and tiredness, and it helps regulate sleep patterns. It also helps manage stress and can relieve certain medical conditions. By now, these points should convince you a bit. If not, common sense should tell you that exercise is beneficial. There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, calisthenics, jogging, using free weights, or weight machines. Remember, training too hard or with too much weight can cause injury, so start slowly and carefully. If you're unsure, consult your doctor about what's best for you. Good posture is essential for improving your body shape. A stiff or sagging body not only looks unattractive but also lacks energy and is more prone to minor health issues. If you tend to slouch, imagine a helium balloon pulling the top of your head up. This will help lift your chest for better breathing and make your abdomen look slimmer. When your chest is balanced while standing, you should be able to see your ankles. Stretching your muscles improves flexibility and movement, helps maintain correct posture, and prevents muscle tears and injuries from overuse. Doing this four or five times a week will make your body more flexible and fit. Stretching should be a key part of your exercise routine, done slowly and precisely. The best exercise routine includes a good warm-up, stretching exercises, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.'

IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT

What motivates film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman to leave their home comforts for months? It's the quest for the perfect shot. Among the many creatures in East Africa's jungles and plains, two of the hardest to find are producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. Currently, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has faced six months of almost nonstop rain, leading to unexpected challenges. Newman mentioned they had to buy an expensive tool so Amanda can pull their vehicle out of the mud when it gets stuck. Their collaboration has produced some of TV's best wildlife films, like their acclaimed film on leopards. Even while this film about Africa's elusive cats was airing, they were back in the wild, this time following the equally elusive jackal. This is common in TV partnerships. Traveling film-makers have been exploring the globe to capture exotic wildlife since TV began. I talked to Newman about their partnership during one of his rare visits to a safari lodge. 'We sometimes argue, but we usually resolve it quickly,' he says about his colleague. Neither sees themselves as the leader, and they get along well because they view animals similarly. 'When we're on the move, we set up our tents each night. But now, we're in a more fixed camp, and since we start at 5 a.m. each day, we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a flask.' Their daily meals are pre-packed and heated by whoever is available. 'We can be out for up to eight weeks, so food can be a concern,' says Newman. It's a tough life, but being alone in remote areas lets them get close to the animals and become part of their world. Newman recalls filming a lion family where a lioness would greet their car as part of her routine. Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on 'The Great Rift,' and two years later, they teamed up to film Arctic foxes. Since then, they spend four months on location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before starting, they must submit a script for approval. 'Amanda and I had a good working relationship from the beginning,' says Newman, 'because we shared the same ideas and vision. We aim to create films rich in atmosphere that capture the true spirit of the place and animals, touching people's hearts. I believe evoking an emotional response is better than appealing only to the intellect.'

In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met with Kendra Slawinski, the captain of England's netball team. Kendra has a busy schedule leading up to the World Championships next month. She spends her days teaching at a local school and then trains in a supermarket car park. When I asked if she gets odd looks while training there, she said she's too focused on her movements to notice much, though she might see cars slowing down.

Kendra is dedicated to being in top shape for the Championships. This will be her fourth time competing, and it's set to be the largest event yet, with 27 countries participating. She feels the support from the home crowd will be special and hopes it will boost netball's reputation in England. However, playing at home also means more pressure to perform well from the start. Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Although England has always beaten them, Kendra expects an exciting game because Barbados has talented players.

England is currently ranked fourth in the world, but Kendra knows the Championships will be challenging. Unlike a series where you can lose a game and still win overall, the Championships offer only one chance to succeed. Over her 15-year career, netball has become more intense and competitive. Kendra emphasizes the importance of training to win, but she also notes that players are friendlier once the game ends.

Netball is now more scientific in its approach to fitness. Kendra believes it's crucial for the team to think and train like world-class athletes. As captain, she aims to lead by example with a strong mental attitude, supporting and encouraging her teammates.

Kendra's netball career has been carefully planned from the start, and she decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but for now, her focus is on this final event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might feel emotional, knowing her loyal supporters are with her every step of the way.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the depths of the Atlantic Ocean. She is a lecturer and researcher in marine geochemistry at the Oceanography Centre, Southampton University. Her work involves studying the chemical processes in the sea. When she's not teaching, she dives three kilometers into the ocean in a small steel vehicle to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, space is so tight that she can touch the two pilots. They can't stand or move much and must stay inside until someone opens the door from outside. A dive lasts about 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface.

If there's an emergency, they can press a panic button to release a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. However, no one has tested it yet, and Rachel thinks it wouldn't be a pleasant experience. The first time she entered the vehicle, she was on a ship's deck with an instructor who explained emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. This was to test her reaction to being in such a confined space.

Rachel has completed six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, is a vast area of underwater volcanoes with chimneys emitting black smoke. The Russian team was installing scientific equipment to study the effects of a project that would drill a 150-meter hole through a volcano.

When not at sea, Rachel works in her office at the Oceanography Centre. Two-thirds of her salary comes from teaching, which she enjoys, but it allows her to continue her research on "black smokers," another name for underwater volcanoes. These volcanoes release water that looks like black smoke at a rate of one meter per second and a temperature of 350 degrees Celsius.

Rachel's only frightening experience was with an American team when an explosion occurred while towing equipment. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and she feared for her life. When nothing happened, the relief was immense.

Diving to the ocean's depths is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she sees the chimneys through the porthole, she feels a sense of wonder. She is often the first person to see these sights. After studying black smokers for her Ph.D. for three years, seeing them in person was an incredible experience.

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are crucial. Research shows that people form opinions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice our clothing, eye contact, body language, speaking speed, voice volume and tone, and the words we use.

Mary Pearce, who studied to be a teacher, shares her experience: "I worked hard for my degree and felt confident when I graduated." She applied for a job at a local primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. "I noticed a small hole in my jacket that morning," she remembers. "I could have changed, but I didn't want to be late, as punctuality is important to me." Mary didn't get the job. Her friend, who works at the school, told her the Head Teacher commented, "If someone doesn't present their best image at an interview, what kind of teacher will they be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "Interviewees who care about their appearance are more likely to care about their jobs. People often think it's what's inside that counts, but in an interview, you should present yourself in the best way possible." Many people overlook the importance of a professional image. For instance, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but didn't even get an interview. "I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel," she says. "He told me I didn't fit the image of an office manager and suggested I improve my wardrobe before applying for a promotion again. I was shocked because I do a good job, and I thought my appearance shouldn't matter."

Movement and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of our feelings and attitudes are communicated through words, 38% through voice, and 55% through facial expressions. If our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will trust the non-verbal message more. So, ensure your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.

It's also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, and her interview went so well that she was offered the job immediately. "I was thrilled," she recalls. "But I showed too much enthusiasm. Once the boss saw how excited I was, he knew I wouldn't refuse the offer. As a result, he offered me a lower salary than I expected. I'm sure I could have negotiated a better salary if I had controlled my excitement."

Finally, consider what you say and how you say it during an interview. David Artesio, a manager at an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. "The annual report, for example, can tell you about the company's activities. Mentioning an area that interests you during the interview shows your interest in the company." Business consultant Marian Woodall advises having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. As she says, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators use short sentences and clear points."

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London but now runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, the City went from being exciting to a grindâ€”no one was having fun anymore. I hadn't planned to leave for another five or ten years, but then I was made redundant unexpectedly. The payout wasn't great, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a top local hotel. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm glad I'm not stuck in an office anymore, but it's surprising how little has changed: I still work 80- to 90-hour weeks and sell a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now earns a living as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy to become an artist seemed logical. The career counselor I spoke to was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to get back to work for financial reasons. But we married young, and our children didn't need our support. Moving to the north of England was a leap into the unknown. We left all our friends, but our friendships have survived the distanceâ€”many visit us now."

**The Hatmaker**  
After five years as a company lawyer, Katherine Goodison started her own business making hats in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I didn't want to become a senior partner working even more hours, so I left. People said I'd get bored, but that hasn't happened. The key is having deadlines. In fashion, there's always something to do, so I keep a strict schedule. I'm happier and less stressed now. I miss socializing with colleagues, but I love being responsible for my product. If I do a bad job, it's on me. You care more when your name is on the line."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. I liked the adrenaline but never found the work rewarding. I almost got made redundant in 1989, but I resigned and traveled for a year to figure out what I wanted. I was interested in health, so I visited top gymnasiums and talked to the owners. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took massage courses. Then I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future. That's the best part."

Text: 'Dedicated to their sports Four young sports stars talk about their lives. A Darius (runner) I've always been into sports. I tried many different ones, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I had a chance to join a professional football club, but I chose athletics instead. My biggest achievement was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much media attention, which was disappointing. I hoped to get sponsorship because training is expensive. I train at home during winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun because there are great facilities and nightlife there. However, I have to be disciplined. If friends invite me out before training, I have to decline. I wish I didn't have to, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to compete in the next Olympics, which would be amazing. B Gabriel (surfer) The surfing community is small, so you often meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often at dawn, so you have to avoid late-night parties. I don't mind that much, but I do miss sleeping in. However, it's worth it because without dedication, I might not have won the National Championships last year. After a win, I make sure to have a big night out, and if there's prize money, I treat myself to a nice trip. The sacrifices are worth it because winning the championship led to me hosting a surfing series on TV. I guess I'm a bit of a celebrity now. C Dieter (yacht racer) With five guys on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We're traditional and always celebrate a win in style. Some say we act childishly when we're out, but we don't seek media attention. Sometimes reporters care more about our celebrations than our race results. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's nice to come back and hang out with friends from different backgrounds. You can't focus on the sport all the time; it's not healthy. I'm known in the sailing world, but I've only been recognized in public a few times. I wouldn't want to be a celebrity. I get nice letters from people asking for signed pictures, and I reply to each one, even if it takes time. D Tomas (tennis player) It's great to feel the crowd's support when I walk on court. At the last tournament, it got a bit overwhelming with people crowding around. Still, I enjoy being recognized by fans when I'm out shopping. It has downsides, though. My last girlfriend didn't like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we broke up, I think. It was tough, but you have to make sacrifices in any sport; you have to be serious and professional. It doesn't bother me much. I'm happy to focus on my game now and enjoy other things in life after I retire, which happens early in this sport.'

Shopping with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother describes it as "absolute murder" because her kids want everything they see, like sugary cereals, Disney videos, or comics. She can't afford all these things and feels guilty when she gives in to their demands, as she believes she's buying unhealthy items. However, she also feels bad for constantly saying no and worries about not giving her children the chance to make their own choices. 

Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a supermarket trip. Over Â£150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on TV. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often don't understand why their parents can't buy everything they want, and arguments about health don't stand up against appealing ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always correct. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if kids only learn from TV ads, they get a biased view. Parents feel frustrated competing with advertisers and having to let their children down repeatedly.

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell kids to ask their parents to buy things. But as Dibb notes, the goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy, so the effect is the same.

Deciding which of their children's requests to agree to or refuse is a major stress for parents. One mother says she discusses food with her children and has taught her son to be skeptical of ads. As a result, they have fewer conflicts in the supermarket because her children don't ask for things she won't buy.

Parents admit they are sometimes inconsistent in their responses. Mike, a father of two, says they refuse to buy sweets for their son because they're unhealthy, yet they buy treats like cream and chocolate for themselves. He acknowledges that it's natural for children to want nice things, but he still gets annoyed by their demands. His willingness to say yes often depends on his mood and life circumstances, making it hard to be consistent.

Supermarkets could help reduce parent-child conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering supervised play areas. Although parents might spend less without their children, the idea of shopping without a child's demands could attract more customers, balancing any loss.

Text: 'Five-star luxury meets modern technology The five-star Merrion Hotel, which has just opened, is the result of careful research into what customers want and nearly two years of work converting four large eighteenth-century houses in Dublin. This approach allowed the hotel to install the latest technology for both staff and guests. At the Merrion, General Manager Peter MacCann expects his staff to know guests by name. For details of guests' preferences, he uses the hotel's computer system. This system helps treat returning guests in the special way expected at a five-star hotel. Although it cost Â£250,000 to install, MacCann believes it will pay for itself over time. He praises its efficiency and is enthusiastic about its features. For example, if a guest requests certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is possible because of the guest-history feature, which allows staff to record any number of preferences. Hotel guests often complain about room temperature. Another high-tech system controls this important comfort area. Guests can change the temperature themselves within three degrees of the normal 18Â°C, and each room can be adjusted between 14Â°C and 25Â°C at the front desk. However, it is the other technology in the rooms that guests are likely to appreciate most. This is especially true for business users, and MacCann estimates that up to sixty-five percent of his business will come from this market. To meet these needs, the hotel has moved the traditional business center into individual bedrooms. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility. Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has tried to anticipate future improvements. Extra cables have been installed to handle future scientific advances. The televisions are rented, not bought, so they can be replaced with newer models at any time. DVD recorders can also be upgraded when needed. Despite all this modern equipment, MacCann says they have tried hard not to overwhelm guests with technology. The 145 bedrooms are large, well-furnished, comfortable, and welcoming. There are also a swimming pool and gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden at the center of it all. As in all luxury hotels, the food must be excellent. Chef Patrick Guilbaud's Dublin restaurant already had two Michelin stars when he decided to move his restaurant to the Merrion. Being part of the hotel has many benefits for both him and the hotel. He has been able to design a new kitchen and bring it into the modern age. There are also better parking facilities than at his previous location. For the hotel, they can offer a popular and successful dining option without financial risks. With the help of technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion is likely to succeed.'

**Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the fullest to share their secrets.

**A. Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:**  
"I get my energy from excitement and challenges. Learning new things gives me a lot of energy. Activities with rhythm, like flamenco dancing, are also energizing. Dance is expressive and revitalizing. Feeling bored or that life is pointless can drain you. Being effective, even in small ways, boosts your energy."

**B. Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:**  
"I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it, so it doesn't feel like a chore. Enjoying your work keeps you from feeling low, even if you're tired. I need a good amount of sleep to feel great. When I only get six hours, I feel sluggish. Exercise gives me energy, but finding the energy to start is hard! I do yoga once a week and try workout tapes at home. Exercise lifts my spirits. I feel low in the office between 3 and 5 PM, so I think it's good to eat something then."

**C. Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:**  
"I don't rely on healthy eating for energy; it's my natural enthusiasm and positivity. I dislike negative attitudes. I believe in enjoying life and seizing the moment. Enjoyment is key. Achieving goals is important. My job is exciting, surrounded by lively young people. I love being busy and sociable. I enjoy taking photos and writing imaginary song lyrics for fun, which is a good mental release when traveling."

**D. Floella Benjamin, Author and Children's TV Presenter:**  
"My energy comes from doing things I love. I believe in my work and family life, and being positive helps. Working with kids is great because they are resilient and give a lot. Energy is like a natural chemical, activated by interacting with others. Smiling at people and getting a smile back is thrilling. It's better than feeling sorry for yourself. I try to eat healthily and don't smoke or drink, but I don't have an exercise routine. My most energetic moments are playing with kids."

**E. Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:**  
"I love transforming a wasteland into a garden. I once turned a concrete area into a garden by breaking up the concrete and adding soil. It was more rewarding than workouts or tennis. Knowing someone wants to read my writing gives me energy. I find it hard to write without an audience. I also enjoy exploring private lands like a child, and if caught, I pretend I didn't know it was private."

**F. Katherine Monblot, Therapist:**  
"You need to have interest and respect for what you do. I like taking risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you dislike drains you. I used to be on committees and resented the time they took. You have limited energy, so focus it on what's most important to you."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until iron was introduced in Scandinavia around 200 AD. In Scandinavia, the upper classes considered skating an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was elegant and reserved. However, at the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style, making skating more popular. Today, skating combines art and athletics, making it both graceful and physically challenging.

For beginners, balance and control are crucial, and speed comes with practice. Your body position is important for balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and knees flexed to center your weight, leaning slightly forward. Relaxation is key in skating, more so than in other sports. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It's fairly simple, right? As you practice, you can gradually make longer movements.

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills a skater should master. Even top professionals fall. To avoid injury, try to stay relaxed when you fall, which reduces the impact. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand. Once you can move confidently on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer guidance to help you learn basic figures, and soon you can try turns, jumps, and spins.

If you watch good or professional skaters, you'll notice how relaxed and smooth they are. To achieve this, you should regularly practice exercises. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises should include those for the legs, back, and shoulders, focusing on the ankles and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating improves balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It boosts heart and lung health and strengthens the body. Combined with swimming or jogging, it offers a great program for overall health and fitness.

**Trills and Triumphs**

Seeing a talented child win a medal can be very emotional. Julia Gregson spoke with three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges they face.

**A. Annika Reeder, 15,** won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She dreams of becoming a physiotherapist and competing in the next Olympics. "The work is tough right now. There's no time for TV, hanging out with friends, or doing much besides gymnastics and school. I take training one day at a time. When I'm extremely tired, my coach might give me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can't take too many days off, or you'll get stiff."

**B. Annika's mother** says, "Annika showed great potential from a young age. I've seen parents push their kids, but it doesn't work. To perform at Annika's level, you have to want it yourself. People often say we've sacrificed a lot, but they don't see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it's done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who hid behind me, but now she's met people worldwide and gained confidence."

**C. Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at ten and has since won the British National Championship. "It's good my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere. Shows last from one to five days. I never get tired of itâ€”I love the excitement and fun. Even without my parents, I'd do it because I'm determined. I'm glad they're happy when I win, but I do it for myself. This year, I aim to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win an Olympic gold medal."

**D. Sarah's mother** shares, "Sarah's passion for horses started at age 1. By 5, she was up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for major shows, we travel all over England. To save money, we sleep in our horse box. Sarah is well-organized and happiest on a horse. Watching your child succeed in something they love is unbeatable."

**E. Jane McShane, 10,** is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When playing, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around and don't think too hard. I'm not worried about getting arrogant; I don't talk about my success at school. I don't like feeling embarrassed."

**F. Jane's mother** recalls, "Jane played her first game at 5. My father suggested it. He tried to teach me chess when I was young, but I was bored. Jane loved it immediately. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. I'm happy when she wins, but if she wanted to quit, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to discourage her just because she's exceptional. If she has a gift, she should reach her potential."

It's true - we're all getting taller. Chris Greener was only fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, "What do you want to be, the flagpole on a ship?" because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. On average, people in Europe grow about a centimeter taller every decade. More and more very tall people are being born each year. Interestingly, this doesn't mean we're evolving into a new super race. Instead, we're returning to our original size from the time of the cavemen. We're finally overcoming the effects of generations of poor diets, which is having a big impact. Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, says, "We are becoming like the Cro-Magnons again, the people who lived 40,000 years ago."

For most of history, our ancestors ate a wide variety of foods. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. Some hunter-gatherer tribes still live this way. One study found they ate 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, agriculture began, which had serious consequences. Farmers took over most green areas, and now just three plantsâ€”wheat, rice, and maizeâ€”provide over half of the calories we eat. This limited diet has harmed our health and growth. Over the centuries, we've eaten soups, porridges, and breads that left us undernourished. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, once thought a blessing, was actually a health disaster, according to some anthropologists. Despite this, agriculture spread because farmed land could support ten times more people than hunter-gathering.

Only recently have wealthier nations started to address poor nutrition. In Europe, the US, and Japan, diets are now more like those of our ancestors. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a positive trend, but it brings challenges. While people are getting taller, things like bed lengths and legroom in planes and trains haven't changed much. Clothes manufacturers also have to adjust their products. The question is: how tall will we get? We can't grow forever. There must be a limit. Robert Fogel from the University suggests it could be around 193 cm, and we might reach it this century.

However, scientists note that while individuals are growing taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate warmed, we became thinner and smaller, even with good nutrition. If the planet continues to heat up, we might shrink even more. So, global warming could counteract the growth in human height.

Text: 'Studio Audiences What is it like to be in the audience when a television show is being filmed? Cosmo Landesman found out. Like technical difficulties, studio audiences are a common part of television, yet they remain a mystery to many of us. Watching them get excited on game shows, we wonder - who are these people? Among all live entertainment audiences, studio audiences are often seen as the least prestigious. I've heard that even people in the TV industry look down on them - one cameraman even compared them to cattle. I used to think studio audiences were just people eager for a brief moment of fame. But there's no typical studio audience. They come from all walks of life, professions, and income levels. TV shows try to attract different types of people for different programs. Those of us who prefer watching TV at home can't understand why anyone would go to a studio. Why apply for tickets, travel far, and endure hours of boredom in an uncomfortable studio just to watch something you can see at home? One idea is that people hope to appear on TV for a moment. I didn't believe this until I spoke to Angela, who said she came for the chance to be on TV. Another idea is that people are curious to see behind the scenes. But the most common reason I heard was simply that 'a friend gave me a ticket'. Few of us have been in a studio audience, yet we think we know what it's like. You sit there, packed among strangers, while someone holds up signs saying APPLAUD or LAUGH - and you clap or laugh as instructed. This might be true for some shows, but not all. As one studio manager says, 'We always hope a show will be good enough not to need these signs.' But is there any real difference between being in a studio and watching TV at home? For Claire, being in a studio is 'more exciting', while Charlotte enjoyed feeling involved with live TV. 'Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him on TV at home, you miss a lot.' What I missed was seeing live actors - from where I sat, I could only see the back of someone's head. The opening scenes were filmed so far away that I ended up watching the show on a studio monitor. Going to a studio might be a terrible way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most of the audience, it was simply fun and a free night of entertainment.'

**Bruce**  
I prefer places where nature and human presence mix. When I travel, I like charming villages with old temples more than empty deserts. At eight, I went to school in England and would cycle to Lastingham village on Saturdays. Cycling was my escape from school. I enjoyed exploring the stark hilltops, cozy valleys, and old villages. Being from Scotland, the landscape felt both familiar and different, and I still visit today. I used to write about my adventures in a diary, which was my first step into travel writing, a field where I later became well-known.

**Sophia**  
There's a small railway from Hythe to Dungeness, run by enthusiasts. I always choose first class because it's only a bit more expensive. The scenery isn't dramatic. The train crosses Romney Marsh with its sheep and runs beside a canal. But my favorite part is when the train passes through back gardens. For a moment, we see people in their daily lives, making tea, washing dishes, or setting up a deckchair. I see myself through their eyes, a woman in a tiny train, peeking into their homes. It's the ordinary landscape that draws me in. Just fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. It makes me look closer, searching for something that opens my eyes.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a beautiful, remote coast. The beaches are hard to reach and rocky, so there are few people. Some brave surfers come, but most visitors enjoy the sea's majesty. The coast faces the Atlantic and is known for shipwrecks. There are coastal walks you can combine with trips inland through lush valleys filled with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering places with a family who owns property in Southole village.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland perfect for hiking. Few people live or visit there. It's a hidden, empty, and remote area, and I love the sense of space. I found it by accident as a student and have visited every year since, sometimes alone, with my boyfriend, and now with my son. It hasn't changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these trips more special. It saddens me that he's growing up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain, to find peace and reconnect with my English roots. I grew up in Sri Lanka but went to school in Devon at twelve. I used to cycle around the moors and village lanes. We had a story about a place we never cycled past: if you went down the driveway, you'd never return. That place was Glenthorne. It's my dream place, a magical, secluded, romantic house. You can't hear anything except the sea, wind, and birds.

HAPPY HUNTING GROUND

We're a family that loves animals and enjoys being around all kinds of creatures. One afternoon, a series of events led to complete chaos. My daughter called me at work, excited because she had found a wonderful pine snake. "Can we keep him?" she asked. I agreed, but only for one night. We had a special tank ready for temporary guests like this, just enough time to admire them and look them up in our well-used natural history book.

I got home late and quickly started boiling a pot of water when I heard screams from my sons' bedroom: "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I rushed in to find a crisis involving Domino, our cat, and Bianca, a white mouse I received as a Mother's Day gift. (Some mothers get perfume, I've heard.) Domino, with the mouse's feet sticking out of his mouth, was running around the room, avoiding the children who were trying to stop him. I jumped into the chaos and tripped over something, landing on the floor. As I considered how to stop Domino, I noticed the snake was escaping from its tank, slithering onto the floor.

The room was a frenzy of cat, mouse, kids, and snake, with the dog barking wildly. The pot boiled over in the kitchen, so I quickly turned off the gas and returned to the chaos. I managed to grab Domino by the tail and rescued the mouse, which was surprisingly unharmed. This mouse was caught by Domino three more times in its life but eventually died of old age.

Feeling encouraged, I turned my attention to the snake. It didn't have any obvious weak points. I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, rocking back and forth without a flute. Slowly, the snake relaxed and rested its head on its coiled body, though it still watched me suspiciously. I carefully slid my hands under the snake and stood up, carrying it to the end of the garden. I pointed it towards a tree, hoping it would choose to live there. When I finally let go of its head, expecting it to attack, it instead slid over my shoulders like a colorful shawl, seeming to settle in for the winter.

We stood there in the duskâ€”four children, me, and the snake. My eldest, DJ, broke the silence with a scientific observation: "You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and fat and warm, and the shed isn't." I had the children gently encourage the snake to move on. Slowly, it did, climbing up the wall and disappearing over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, my three-year-old, Clay, summed it up for all of us: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

In today's fast-paced world with phones, faxes, and computers, the traditional art of letter writing is at risk of disappearing. However, I believe receiving a letter offers a unique joy that other forms of communication can't match. There's the thrill of its arrival, the pleasure of seeing who it's from, and the enjoyment of reading it. I've been writing letters for as long as I can remember, starting with little notes to my mother. She always made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts, no matter how short or messy they were.

When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, my mother and I would write to each other weekly. Occasionally, my father would write too, and his long, funny letters were always a delight. These letters mostly talked about everyday events involving my parents and their friends. Although we also made phone calls, it's the letters I remember most. I also received letters from boyfriends. Many of them had to work or study far away, so we stayed in touch through letters. Surprisingly, this strengthened our relationships, as I found it easier to express myself in writing.

I love receiving letters with birthday or Christmas cards. While notes are nice, a letter full of news is even better, especially if it comes in an airmail envelope with beautiful stamps. I get letters from Mangala in Sri Lanka, someone I trained with over 20 years ago, and I have penfriends in Australia and Vancouver. There's also a lady from France I write to regularly. We met by chance in a restaurant, and if we hadn't exchanged addresses, we wouldn't have this wonderful correspondence. I get to practice my French, and we've visited each other's homes.

My greatest letter-writing success was visiting my American penfriend in Texas this summer. We had been writing to each other for 29 years without meeting. Everyone was surprised that our correspondence lasted so long, and the local newspaper even featured our story on the front page. I'm happy that my children are continuing this tradition. Like my mother, I insist they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little notes, just as I did to my mother, and both my children have penfriends in Texas, arranged by my penfriend. I strongly encourage everyone not to let letter writing become a 'lost art.'

Text: 'Careless tourists damage ancient alpine rock art Tens of thousands of ancient pictures carved into the rocks at one of France's most important tourist sites are being gradually destroyed. Scientists and researchers are worried that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so quickly that they might not last for future generations. The mountain, once a place for prayer and worship, has 4,000-year-old drawings carved into the rock. These include pictures of cows with horns, cultivated fields, and various gods and goddesses. However, as more people visit the site, the pictures are being ruined by careless graffiti. Jean Clottes, chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, 'People think that because the pictures have been there so long, they will always be there. But if the damage continues at this rate, there will be nothing left in 50 years.' He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, wearing away the rock and the details of the artwork. Some visitors even break off parts to take home as souvenirs. 'When people can't take a good enough photograph, they rub the drawings to get a clearer picture,' he said. 'The drawings are polished by the weather, and if the sun is shining and visitors can't see them properly, they simply rub and scrape them to make them look fresher.' Other researchers describe how people arrive with long sticks with sharp ends to scratch their own drawings or even their names into the rocks. But experts disagree on the best way to preserve the drawings. Henry de Lumley, director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, believes that the only way to save the site is to make the whole mountain a 'no-go' area, allowing the public to visit only on guided tours. Otherwise, he says, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research work will be reduced. Clottes disagrees. 'The measure proposed by Henry de Lumley is the most severe, and while it is the most effective, it is also certain to bring about protests from people who live there,' he said. 'The site was classified as a historic monument years ago by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do as much as possible to save what is there.' David Lavergne, the regional architect, also wants to avoid closing the site. 'Henry de Lumley's idea isn't ideal,' he said. 'Our department feels that the best solution is to let people look at the site, but because the area is very big, it is difficult to prevent visitors from damaging it. I would prefer that everyone was able to look at it, but the main problem is financial. We do not have the funds to employ the necessary number of guards. We may have to consider charging a fee. There seems to be no prospect of government funding.' In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who also worked on researching the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to reach - tourists can now avoid the three-and-a-half-hour walk by hiring vehicles - the damage will increase rapidly. She thinks that the only solution is to rope off the area and provide guides. 'You can't say the plan can't go ahead because there is no money,' she said. 'That is not good enough. Money must be provided because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we don't take steps, we will be responsible for losing the drawings for the next generation.''

Shopping with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother describes it as "absolute murder" because her kids want everything they see, like sugary cereals, Disney videos, or comics. She can't afford all these things and feels guilty when she gives in to their demands, as she believes she's buying unhealthy items. However, she also feels bad for constantly saying no and worries about not giving her children the chance to make their own choices. 

Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a supermarket trip. Over Â£150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on TV. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often don't understand why their parents can't buy everything they want, and arguments about health don't stand up against appealing ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always correct. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a biased view. Parents feel frustrated competing with advertisers and having to let their children down repeatedly.

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But as Dibb notes, the goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy, so the effect is the same.

Deciding which of their children's requests to agree to or refuse is a major stress for parents. One mother says she discusses food with her children and has taught her son to be skeptical of ads. As a result, they have fewer conflicts in the supermarket because her children don't ask for things she won't buy.

Parents admit they are sometimes inconsistent in their responses. Mike, a father of two, says they refuse to buy sweets for their son because they're unhealthy, yet they buy treats for themselves. He acknowledges that it's natural for children to want nice things too, but he still gets annoyed by their demands. His willingness to say yes depends on his mood and life circumstances, making it hard to be consistent.

Supermarkets could help reduce parent-child conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering supervised play areas. Although parents might spend less without their children, the idea of shopping without their demands could attract more customers, balancing out any loss.

Text: 'Going up the wall In the past, climbers went to mountains. Now, challenging climbs can happen anywhere, indoors or outdoors. The audience watches closely. High above them on the climbing wall, hanging upside down by just two fingers, is French climber Francois Lombard. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. This arena is more known for hosting the TV show Gladiators, but both the show and the climbing championships have one thing in common - The Wall. The possibility of these events is due to new and fast-developing technology. Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were good climbing spots. In winter, they either braved the cold, went walking, or climbed snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing evolved, it became important for top climbers to stay fit. With cliffs unusable for much of the year, they used brick edges or stone buildings to train. This kept their fingers strong and helped them avoid boredom. Soon, many sports centers started building walls specifically for climbing, using bricks with special edges to grip. Many of these early walls were inspired by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher who, in the mid-1960s, built a climbing wall in a corridor at Leeds University. Robinson had the idea of setting natural rock in concrete blocks, which could be part of a wall. Many climbing walls like this were built in sports halls across the country during the 1970s, but they had design issues. Walls could only be built vertically, while outdoor cliffs have features like overhangs and angled rock slabs. Another problem was that once built, the walls couldn't be changed, and climbers would get bored with the repetitive holds. In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny created a material that he shaped into forms similar to those found on cliffs. These could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted a new challenge. French manufacturers also started experimenting with panels on a steel framework. Concrete was too heavy for overhanging walls without major construction, but steel frames could be set up anywhere as standalone structures. A system of interchangeable fixtures provided climbers with endless new holds.'

Text: If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they'll probably say it's 'risky' very quickly. Acting is indeed a risky career because there are more actors than there are roles. When you decide to become an actor, some friends might say you're crazy, while others might react differently. Everyone will give you different advice. But it's a personal decision, and only you can take responsibility for your ambition. There are no easy paths, no exams to pass, and no guarantee that training will lead to success. It's about luck and talent. However, there is a need for new talent, and acting can bring excitement, glamour, and sometimes big rewards. Talent is often seen as natural skill plus imagination, with imagination being hard to measure. It also involves courage and belief in what you're doing. The desire to act is hard to explain, but in theatre, it's about the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection drives actors. If you ask successful actors how they made it, they might shrug because they don't really know. They understand their skills and techniques but take nothing for granted, knowing their success can be temporary. Disappointment is a big challenge for actors. One month you might be out of work, and the next, you could be auditioning for a role. Even if you want the job badly, you might not get it. So, actors often find ways to handle the stress of auditions and rejection. Nobody likes being rejected, and this risk starts as soon as you begin auditioning professionally. You are showing that you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the job. Ultimately, if you don't care enough, no one else will care for you.

**Food for All: A Selection of Top Cookbooks**

**A. Delia Smith**  
When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, Delia Smith often comes to mind. Her recipes come from all over the world and are known for being exciting yet practical for the average cook. Her book, *Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course*, is a staple in many kitchens. It offers simple yet expert advice on both basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of excellent recipes. Recently updated, it remains a top choice for anyone looking for a single, comprehensive cookbook.

**B. Raymond Blanc**  
Raymond Blanc went from being an amateur chef to owning the most famous French restaurant in Britain in just 15 years. His book, *Blanc Mange*, accompanies his first TV series and aims to teach better cooking by explaining how ingredients work together. With over 80 recipes, it serves as a practical guide, even explaining why some dishes might fail and introducing basic food chemistry. Raymond loves cooking to entertain, and this book shows just how skilled he is.

**C. Le Cordon Bleu**  
Le Cordon Bleu is synonymous with the best in classical French cooking. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, the school released the *Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook*, featuring 100 of its most respected recipes. While these recipes are classics, they have been updated to be lighter and healthier. The book starts with kitchen basics and includes sections on Appetisers, Main Dishes, and Desserts, all with step-by-step illustrations. Expert chefs from around the world share their famous recipes and secrets.

**D. Nigel Slater**  
Nigel Slater, food editor of *The Observer*, challenges the idea that good food requires long hours in the kitchen. His book, *The 30-Minute Cook*, shows that fast food can be delicious. He believes you can make something tasty in the time it takes to deliver a pizza. This book includes over 200 recipes from around the world, all ready in 30 minutes. Nigel's lively writing style makes cooking enjoyable, and his recipes prove that fast food can also be great food.

It's true - we're all getting taller. Chris Greener was only fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, "What do you want to be, the flagpole on a ship?" because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. On average, people in Europe grow about a centimeter taller every decade. More and more tall people are being born each year. Interestingly, this doesn't mean we're evolving into a new super race. Instead, we're returning to our original size from the time of the cavemen. We're finally overcoming the effects of generations of poor diets, which is having a big impact. Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, says, "We are becoming like the Cro-Magnons again, the people who lived 40,000 years ago."

For most of history, our ancestors ate a wide variety of foods: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. Some research shows they ate about 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, agriculture was invented, which had serious consequences. Most green areas were taken over by farmers, and now just three carbohydrate-rich plantsâ€”wheat, rice, and maizeâ€”provide more than half of the calories we eat today. This limited diet has harmed our health and physical development. Over the centuries, we've eaten soups, porridges, and breads that left us underfed. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, once thought to be a blessing, turned out to be a health disaster according to some anthropologists. Despite this, agriculture spread because farmed land could support ten times more people than hunter-gathering.

Only recently have wealthier nations started to address the poor nutrition of this system. In Europe, the US, and Japan, diets are now more like those of our ancestors. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a positive trend, but it comes with challenges. While people are getting taller, things like bed lengths and legroom in planes and trains haven't changed much. Clothes manufacturers also have to adjust their products. The question is: how tall will we get? We can't grow forever. There must be a limit. Robert Fogel from the University suggests it could be 193 cm, and we might reach it this century.

However, scientists note that while individuals are growing taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate warmed, we became thinner and smaller, even with good nutrition. If the planet continues to heat up, we might shrink even more. So, global warming could counteract the growth in human height.

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London but now runs a sheep farm. He spent 14 years in the business world, which he found exciting at first, but it eventually became tedious. He hadn't planned to leave for another five or ten years, but he was unexpectedly made redundant. Although the severance pay wasn't great, it was enough to start his farm. His big break came when he met the head chef of a local hotel with a top-rated restaurant. Supplying them helped spread his reputation, and now he also sells meat through mail order. He's happy to be out of the office, but he still works 80- to 90-hour weeks and is still selling a product.

**The Painter**  
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now earns a living as an artist. Painting started as a hobby, but he found it more exciting than his job. Taking redundancy to become an artist seemed logical. A career counsellor was surprised when Ron said he didn't want to return to his old job, as most people in their mid-forties need to work for financial reasons. However, Ron and his wife married young, and their children were independent. They moved to the north of England, leaving friends behind, but their friendships have endured, with many visiting them now.

**The Hatmaker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. She enjoyed her job as a lawyer and earned well, but the long hours were exhausting. She didn't want to become a senior partner, so she left. Some people thought she'd get bored, but she never has. The key is having deadlines, as the fashion business is always busy with collections and seasons. She feels happier and less stressed now, though she misses socializing with colleagues. She loves being fully responsible for her work, as her name is on all the promotional material.

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started in financial markets at 22, enjoying the adrenaline but not finding the work fulfilling. In 1989, he almost lost his job but chose to resign and travel for a year instead. During that time, he explored his interest in health by visiting top gymnasiums and talking to their owners. To change careers, he took various massage courses and was eventually offered part-time work at the Life Centre. He has no regrets and now feels in control of his life and destiny.

Two brothers, Dave and Norm Lagasse, have turned a childhood game into a successful business. In their forties, they live in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, and often play pichenotte, a game their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, brought from Quebec, Canada. The family played it regularly, even after moving to New Mexico. The game was unknown in the southern USA, so visitors were intrigued by it.

Three years ago, Dave noticed their old pichenotte board was worn out and decided to make a new one. It was so well-made that relatives and friends wanted their own. Curious about the game's appeal, the brothers took a board to a sports bar in Santa Fe. Initially, people were skeptical, but once they tried it, they couldn't stop playing.

Dave researched the game's origins and found it likely started in India as 'carroms,' evolved into 'squails' in Britain, and was brought to Canada by British immigrants. The French-Canadian version, pichenotte, developed in Quebec. The game involves skill, with players flicking 12 pieces or 'pucks' across a board to score points by landing them in a hole or on concentric rings.

Seeing the game's popularity at the bar, the brothers made more boards and sold them at markets and craft fairs. The game became so popular that championships were organized, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As demand grew, the brothers decided to make pichenotte boards full-time. They set up a workshop in their garage and have produced over 450 boards, made of birchwood and mahogany, each weighing 12kg and 1cm thick. The boards sell for $595 on their website.

Although there are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage yet, the brothers are optimistic about the future. They hope their business will eventually allow them to replace their garage workshop with a luxury car. Until then, they enjoy playing the game that might make them wealthy.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you enter the Model Village, it's hard to believe that just a few years ago, this area was a neglected piece of land, overgrown with brambles. It was considered useless for a long time. However, through the careful planning and hard work of one man, Colin Sims, and the constant support of his wife, this land was transformed into the beautiful village you see today.

During the construction, thousands of tons of soil and clay were moved to create the landscape. While machines like bulldozers helped, a lot of hard manual work was also needed. After shaping the land, about 1,000 tonnes of topsoil were added to create the lawns, flower beds, and rockeries. Hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted, carefully chosen to survive the salty air near the sea and the strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were sourced from as far as Canada and New Zealand.

Colin Sims designed the entire village, and over 100 models were made by him over nine years since the village opened in 1972. The models are made from materials like stone, concrete, treated wood, and plastics to endure all weather conditions. Initially, Colin needed help from experts to understand how different materials would last over time, but he soon became an expert himself.

You'll notice that a consistent scale is used throughout the village, with great attention to detail. This was achieved through patience and unique construction techniques. The Model Village is a popular attraction, known for its high-quality craftsmanship and maintenance. The techniques used here have been adopted by other model villages in England and are even taught in some college courses.

The model buildings represent traditional British architecture but are not exact replicas of specific places. One of the most impressive is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower, inspired by manor houses in the West Country. As you explore, you'll also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition.

Please stay on the paths during your visit and avoid touching the models, as any damage can require extensive repairs. Photography is allowed from the paths, and dogs are welcome if kept on a short lead. To enhance your experience, some models have buttons you can press to make them move.

At the end of your visit, we welcome your feedback. New models are always being planned, and your ideas can help us create a more diverse and interesting display. We also want to know if any models don't meet the village's standards, as we are constantly updating and replacing them. We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don't forget to tell your friends about us!

Week after week, British tabloid newspapers publish photos that invade people's privacy and violate the editors' code of practice. While pop stars sometimes pose for paparazzi, this is not common. More often, people in the public eye are harmed when their private moments appear on the front page. Despite this, few people use the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), an organization meant to handle such issues. These photos rarely serve the public interest. Do intimate photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a photo of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has previously complained about long-lens photos and had a valid reason to do so, as hotels are places where privacy is expected. However, she didn't take action, and the PCC didn't investigate, which is scandalous. The PCC should also look into a recent story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star hasn't filed a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action on these and other inappropriate stories? Initially, this seems like a good idea. It would likely result in many rulings against newspapers, which would be reported by competitors and covered on TV and radio. The public wouldn't support the newspapers, forcing editors to stop publishing such content. Photographers would also be affected, as it would no longer be profitable to hide and take photos of celebrities. If the PCC acted as a 'police officer', it would face challenges. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it encourage victims to complain? And if they refuse, should it proceed anyway? Celebrities and royalty might expect every story about them to be investigated and be upset if it isn't. The role is too large. How could the PCC monitor all British press: national, regional, and magazines? There's also the issue of embarrassment. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want the added embarrassment of an investigation? Most likely want to move on with their lives. Some might have other reasons for staying quiet, like a worse story they want to keep hidden. In this case, even the PCC could be seen as an enemy. A British comedian was also targeted by the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon. He didn't complain then or later when his family was photographed on holiday. He feared the newspaper, News of the World, would republish the photos with a new story about his 'anger', claiming it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he should have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People worry they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. Finding an easy solution to this serious problem is difficult.

Many people give advice to college graduates starting their first job. This article focuses on moving to a second job. We are not talking about those looking for another temporary job while searching for a permanent one, or those leaving a bad job after just a few weeks. Instead, we are discussing those who are taking a significant step in their career, choosing a job that matches their goals now that they have some experience, skills, and a clearer idea of their career path. 

What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. Consider if you want to specialize in a specific area, move up to higher responsibilities, or switch to a broader field. Whatever you decide, choose your second job carefully. Plan to stay in it for two to three years.
