This job will be important when you apply for your next one, as it should show that you are serious about your career. It should also challenge you, help you grow, and give you more responsibility.

If you feel like traveling, now is a good time to do it. You can work temporarily when you return and then find your second job. Future employers will be glad to see that you have satisfied your travel desires and are less likely to leave again.

Juliette Davidson spent her first year after graduating from St. Aldate's College working for three lawyers. It was a great first job because the people were supportive. She learned about office work and improved her word processing skills. However, there was no room for growth, so she quit, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year. Now, Juliette is a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. In two and a half years, she has become more capable, and her job has expanded. Her boss wanted to help her develop from the start. Although her job title is the same, her duties have changed. She has moved from mainly typing and phone work to handling most of the correspondence and budgets. She also deals with various inquiries, from company chairmen to people wanting to start their own business. Brenda involves her in all her work and gives her specific projects and events to organize.

Confident people: What's their secret? Confident people might seem like they were always that way, but most will tell you it's a skill they've learned. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.

A. Jenny: When I left school, I was very shy and thought I'd always be that way. At 25, I was asked to help at my daughter's school. I didn't think I could do it, but I surprised myself. Someone suggested I take a university course. I was nervous on my first day, but my confidence grew, and I became more outgoing. Working at the school was a turning point in my life.

B. Michaela: Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to take over the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive, thinking that's what confidence was. But I learned that to be confident, you have to believe in yourself. If work gets too demanding, I don't feel guilty about postponing tasks. When faced with something difficult, I remind myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you lack confidence, so I talk to myself to overcome it.

C. Lisa: People think I'm confident, but the calmer I look, the more terrified I am. In TV, looking confident is crucial. Interviewing people taught me that everyone gets tense in important situations, and we feel calmer with friendly people. My mother once told me, 'Who's looking at you? Everyone's worried about themselves.' That's worth remembering. You gain confidence by facing fears. I was nervous for my driving test, but I passed and felt I'd never be that scared again.

D. Barbara: My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but it's something I've built over time. By learning from mistakes, you're more confident next time. I work hard and am popular at the restaurant, but not everyone likes me, and that's okay. You have to like yourself for who you are. My company offers training courses that boost self-esteem and encourages setting achievable goals. Seeing tangible achievements helps more than aiming too high and getting nothing.

E. Kim: After college, I worked as a secretary and was too scared to speak up in meetings. Eventually, I gained the confidence to share my opinions. When I started in politics, I was nervous about public speaking. I told myself, 'People do this every day, so you can too.' Writing notes helped, like a comfort blanket. Everyone feels a bit shaky speaking in public. The secret to confidence is telling yourself, 'Nothing is impossible.'

Text: 'Visit to Malaysia Paul Forster attends a kite-flying festival and spends a night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled as I gave him his torn kite. 'You should keep it,' he said, 'it's a tradition - if the line breaks, finders are keepers ... and I have plenty more.' He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. Each kite was exactly 120cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat next to them under the shade of the coniferous trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, watching Malaysia's biggest kite festival. In the center of the beach were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites, and a row of competitors held their kite lines, waiting for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites soared into the sky like rockets. Over 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts five days each year. Each participant entered four different kite designs, judged on decoration, stability, and flying efficiency. 'Flying kites isn't hard,' said Adnan, 'but making them requires real skill. Visit me at home, and I'll show you how it's done.' I accepted his invitation, one of five I received that day. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large polished room. As night fell, he invited me to return the next day to help rebuild his kite, but my plans didn't allow it. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur into mountains covered with lush rainforest. I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road ended at a river. A narrow boat was there to ferry people across. Nearby, a small sign caught my attention. It pointed up a path into the forest and read: 'Jelawang Jungle 3 km.' It would have been helpful to know that most of this distance was uphill, steep, and slippery. When I reached the track, I found a man waiting with a flask of tea. This was Baba, who managed a tented kitchen and several bamboo huts. I decided to stay, trying not to think about insects under my thin foam mattress. The night was completely dark, filled with various sounds. A waterfall roared nearby, and countless creatures moved and squeaked. In the morning, there was a stunning view over five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind, then lightning hit the treetops. Moments later, I was soaked. Sliding downhill, I wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the huge raindrops. I also worried about my car being swept away (it sometimes happens) and the risk of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, the car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track. In Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, everyone asked me questions: 'Where are you from?' 'How old are you?' But they were all friendly. Kelantan might be famous for its kites, but I remember it more for its kindness.'

Text: 'What type of shopper are you? Whether you love it or hate it, we all go shopping. But there are different types of shoppers. Do you know which one you are? Abby Edwards asked around ... A. Melanie, 22, dancer I'm a shopping addict - I can't spend enough money! When I have cash, I'm out shopping, and it keeps me happy. I find it hard to ignore sale signs. My boyfriend is just like me, so we often shop together. We're an addicted couple! B. Brenda, 40, office manager I'm a reluctant shopper. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I don't spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter to buy clothes, but I don't enjoy it because we all have different tastes. I don't spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and rarely tell my husband the real amount - I always lower the price a bit! The real price always sounds too high. C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager I only shop for essentials. I hate shopping and only go when I really have to. When I do, I know what I want and won't settle for anything else. I find shopping tiring and there's always something else I'd rather be doing. D. Anita, 35, TV producer I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don't waste time and get in and out quickly. I do have some mistakes hidden in my wardrobe, so maybe I'm a careful shopper who sometimes makes wrong choices! E. Lizzie, 41, secretary I don't enjoy shopping at all. I really dislike shopping for clothes because I can never find what I want or anyone to help me. The shops are too noisy, everything is messy, and I find it a nightmare. Luckily, I rarely have to shop for clothes because most of my clothes are given to me. For food shopping, I go to the local supermarket once a week and finish it quickly! F. Lisa, 22, actress I'm probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go out to look around the shops with my friends, and we often end up buying things. I don't usually have a specific item in mind, but if something catches my eye, I'll buy it. G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant I'm a careful shopper - I like going, but I don't buy much. I usually know what I want and rarely go overboard. I sometimes shop to cheer myself up, but I often feel worse because I've spent too much! H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on a Saturday because it's too busy. I'd say I'm a careful shopper. I always have a good idea of what I want, and I never buy things immediately. I have to check other shops in case I find a better deal - it takes me a long time! I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager I'm an unwilling shopper - maybe because I work in the city center, the shops have lost their appeal for me. When I have to shop, I'll go, but I don't try things on because it's too much trouble. Clothes I buy don't always fit, but I don't mind too much. I'd rather make a few mistakes than spend a lot of effort shopping!'

Text: 'NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE The Open University offers degrees just like any other university. However, you can continue working while you study. It also allows you to explore a wide range of interests. If you have never studied before, you will experience the joy of learning new things. You will meet a diverse group of people and make new friends. Your qualification might also lead to new career opportunities. Instead of attending lectures in person, you study at home using television, radio, and computer software. You can choose to attend a class once a month at an Open University center if you want. Like any university, there are exams to take. If you want more information, simply fill out the form below. This could be the beginning of an exciting new chapter in your life.'

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about "Surprises." You can get the free quiz sheets at the Orange Street entrance. Children will explore 14 surprising paintings and answer questions about them. The quiz is available during normal gallery hours from 25 March to 9 April.

**New Picture**  
The Gallery has a new still life painting by Dutch 18th-century artist Jan van Os. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first of its kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778 because the artist painted flowers as they bloomed in different seasons. Miss Violet Churchman donated it in memory of her sister Ida Nancy. It is now displayed in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**  
The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" started in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery recently acquired works by three Spanish painters from this period: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. The exhibition also features Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italians who worked in Spain, Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition runs until 31 May.

**Lecture News**  
A series of lectures accompanies the special exhibition every Wednesday. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will discuss Melendez's work. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will lecture on Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists tell stories through their paintings.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**  
The Gallery restaurant now offers an improved and expanded service. With new kitchens, it provides a wide choice of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Information for Visitors**  
Free guided tours of the Gallery are available every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm (except Sundays). These tours introduce some of the Gallery's greatest paintings and showcase the collection of important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

Text: 'Little Chefs For a group of children aged ten to fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning serious cooking skills. These weekly lessons, held in small classes, are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children eager to join. Parents pay Â£280 for the course, where their children can have fun and learn to cook well. Bill, a ten-year-old class member, says, 'I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to enjoy the food we've made.' Flora, who is twelve, is having trouble with onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. Then my mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking while they're young, they'll have the skills to cook for themselves when they leave home.''

The Outdoor Centre charges a fee for a car with four people. If there are more than four people, each extra person costs 50p. You need to pay the fees at the main office. The centre is open to everyone and aims to provide outdoor sports and recreation for the public. If you are visiting as a group, please let the centre know in advance.

Windsurfing - One-day Course: Beginner windsurfing courses are available on Saturdays and Sundays, depending on the weather. Learning to windsurf is very enjoyable, and the thrill of sailing across the water for the first time is unforgettable. Beginners can use boards with small sails. The course costs Â£32.50, which includes all equipment.

One-day Adventure Course: This is a great chance to try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. The course is designed to introduce adults to outdoor activities in a fun and relaxed way. You don't need to be very fit or have any previous experience. Just bring your interest. The course costs Â£22.50.

Play Park: The Play Park is perfect for children aged two to ten. It is one of the best in the country, featuring sand and water play, slides, a large ball pool, a play castle, and more. Next year, the centre will add a new Play Palace and Play Ship.

Group Day and Residential Courses: We offer day and long weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups visit us regularly. We have three large rooms, each with twelve beds, available for groups of up to 36 people (minimum 12). 

Summer Adventure Holidays (for ages 8-14): Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. Safety is our top priority at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are fully trained in First Aid and qualified to teach the activities. We ensure that all children participate in activities suitable for their age and abilities. Children must be able to swim 25 meters and be in good health to join this program.

Stamp collecting is a hobby that many people of all ages enjoy because it is both interesting and fun. Every year, more people start their own stamp collections and find a hobby that can last a lifetime. It's easy to start collecting stamps because they are everywhere. You can find them on holiday postcards from friends, birthday cards from relatives, and letters from pen pals from around the world.

Once you start collecting seriously, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of new stamps for your collection. You have three options for receiving these stamps: we can send you a complete set on an envelope addressed to you, provide them in a colorful information pack with interesting facts, or send you individual stamps to arrange in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members, and you can join too. A two-year membership costs just Â£5, and there is a discount if a group joins together. This is great value for money. When you join, you receive a Starter Pack at no extra cost. This pack includes 100 stamps to start your collection and an attractive box to store them. You also get a helpful 4-page guide with tips on how to expand your collection and addresses of shops and businesses that sell stamps.

Every two months, you'll receive the club magazine, which is full of competitions and quizzes. It also gives you the chance to exchange stamps with members worldwide. Why not start an adventure that will bring you years of enjoyment? You'll spend many happy hours looking at the amazing variety of stamps in your collection or searching for rare ones. Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and experience the fun and excitement of stamp collecting. To join, simply fill out the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will arrive within 28 days of receiving your application.

Text: 'MONEY What is money? The pound, the dollar, or the franc are like units of measurement, such as a gram or a kilometre. The key difference is that you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can purchase a book, a large bag of sweets, or a couple of cinema tickets. However, the note itself is just a piece of printed paper that costs very little to produce. Thousands of years ago, people didn't have money as we do today. There were no banks or shops. Back then, a farmer like Mr. Green would trade the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a direct exchange between two people, each having something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own 'currencies' to make trading easier. These different currencies eventually started to connect, leading to the use of national currencies that we see today.'

Text: 'Enter our Fiction Prize contest! You could win Â£1,000 and have your story published in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other winners will receive Â£100 each. We are looking for talented writers who can create engaging stories. Our judges include novelist Mary Littlejohn, TV reporter Michael Brown, and Keep Writing's editor, Susan Hitchins. Last year, detective stories were popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything, but here are some tips: Write about what you know This is important advice for all writers. Last year, most stories were about love, family, and friendship issues. However, you need to make ordinary situations interesting and engaging. Write about everyday things in a fresh and surprising way. Get your facts right Make sure your descriptions and explanations are accurate. Don't write about something unless you're sure about it. Hold the reader's attention Start with an interesting beginning and end with a surprise. A weak ending can ruin a story. Develop your story carefully and think of an unexpected twist at the end. Think about the characters Use well-chosen words to make your characters feel real and alive to the reader. Your story must be original, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, and typed, double-spaced, on one side of each page. We cannot accept stories by fax or email, even if the deadline is near. Include the application form with your story. We cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. You should not have had any fiction published in any magazine or book in this country, and your story must not have appeared in print or recorded form anywhere in the world. Your Â£5 entry fee will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. The deadline is 30 July, and we will notify the winner within a month. If you win, you must agree to have your story published in our magazine.'

Text: 'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many centuries, she was the only woman scientist recognized in history books. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured his daughter received the best education possible. This was unusual because most women at that time had limited opportunities to study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and began teaching mathematics. She quickly became well-known for her understanding of new ideas. Although we don't have any copies of her books, we know she wrote several important mathematical works. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented several scientific tools to assist her work. During that period, many rulers were afraid of science, and anyone associated with it was at risk. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked on the street and killed.'

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**

The Nene Valley Railway is a 12-kilometre-long railway that travels through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in Peterborough in the east and goes to Wansford, where the railway's main office is located, near the A1 main road. There is also a 2-kilometre extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to Yarwell, the current western end of the line. Ticket prices are Â£10.00 for adults, Â£5.00 for children, and Â£25.00 for a family (up to 2 adults and 3 children). Special prices may apply on public holidays.

**Nene Park**

Nene Park offers a great day out for families with its golf courses and a large Caravan Club site. The park has thousands of hectares of public land with boating lakes, picnic areas, a nature reserve, and a miniature railway.

**Wansford**

Wansford Station houses a unique collection of historic trains from across Europe. This includes famous trains like the elegant De Glen Compound locomotive from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, the largest working steam engine in Britain. British trains like '92 Squadron' and 'Mayflower' are also on display. You can see these engines all year round, even if the Nene Valley Railway is not running. However, the buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are only open on days when the train is running. There is a site entrance fee of Â£2.00 for adults and Â£1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**

The Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. For example, it was used in the James Bond movie "Octopussy." Come and see where it was filmed.

**Services for Schools**

From May to July, the Railway offers special services for school groups. Teachers can set projects for students to work on during their visit or back in the classroom. An educational pack is available for Â£1.50 plus postage. At other times, schools can hire the train called 'Teddy Bear' with up to 3 carriages on non-service days. Bookings should be made one month in advance. Special low fares are available for groups of 60 or more students. Call 01780 784444 for more information.

**Private Hire of Trains**

The Railway is a popular venue for family events or company visits. It offers an interesting setting for an afternoon or evening out. Special programs can be arranged to include a buffet, bar, entertainment, discos, and more. For more information, please contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are over 9,000 types of grasses, and they grow everywhere on Earth. Grasses are the only flowering plants that can survive in the cold environments of the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals rely on grass in some way. Grass can quickly regrow after being cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new grass leaves grow from below the soil, not from the top. This allows large groups of animals to live in one area. Once they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow, providing a fresh meal.

Kal Kaur Rai, recently named Young Achiever of the Year at the Asian Business Awards, has always had a passion for fashion. Since childhood, she enjoyed drawing clothes and creating patterns. However, she never shared her dream of turning this hobby into a career with her parents, who owned a supermarket, because she believed they wanted her to pursue a more traditional career path. So, she studied management at university. 

After graduating, Kal moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She needed to attend industry events but couldn't afford the designer clothes she admired, so she began making her own skirts and tops. Her friends loved her creations and asked her to make clothes for them too. This led her to find a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis. Her clothes sold well, and nothing was returned, which gave her the confidence to leave her advertising job. She took out a Â£20,000 loan to start her own womenswear label.

Kal's parents were supportive of her career change, which made her happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns more than Â£500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates outfits for pop stars, and she has gained public recognition by winning the award. Kal acknowledges her success and feels fortunate, saying, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

SUNNINGDALE HOTEL

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has been known for its excellent service, welcoming guests from all over the world. Over the past 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed here.

The hotel is located on a main road leading to the town center, about 20 minutes away by bus. Buses to various parts of the town stop outside the hotel, but avoid buses with the blue "Express" sign as they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 meters away.

The main building has 200 well-furnished, centrally-heated single rooms, each with hot and cold water basins. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of all corridors. The hotel offers a shop, sitting rooms, four television rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos available for guests. Parking is available in the hotel drive. Free daily newspapers are provided, and stamps can be bought at the office.

Guests staying for long periods must pay weekly in advance and give one week's notice before leaving. Both short-term and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests are given priority for rooms. Meal times are: breakfast from 7 am to 9:30 am, lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm, and dinner from 5:30 pm to 7 pm. During the week, dinner can be requested until 11 pm by signing the late list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices for breakfast and dinner.

No animals or fires (for heating food or rooms) are allowed. Guests are asked to respect others' comfort. If you have tapes or CDs, please keep the noise down, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. If arriving by train, it is recommended to take a taxi to the hotel, as it is some distance from the main railway station.

Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in cinema history. However, his life wasn't always easy. As a child, Tom was shy and struggled to make friends, even though he loved participating in school plays. After finishing high school, he moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter and took drama classes at the same time. In 1980, film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he became one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions for each film. Today, Tom continues to act in movies and remains very popular with fans worldwide.

Title: "Little Cat, Little Cat, Where Have You Been?"

Bo the cat had an unexpected adventure when she decided to explore a furniture van. The van's driver found her after driving over 500 kilometers. It was a long day, and both the driver and Bo were hungry. He gave her some milk and started looking for her owner. He called his last customers, but none of them had lost a cat. Since it was late, he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he brought her to an animal hospital.

Meanwhile, Bo's owner was also trying to find her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered to a neighbor. Luckily, he recalled the company's name. He contacted their office, and soon Bo was safely returned to him.

Text: 'The Ghan Train Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin, in the north of Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train crosses Australia from the warm northern coast through endless desert to the colder Southern Ocean. It's often called the 'famous Ghan', mainly because it's known for being late. The idea of a rail link between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but flooding often made it hard for trains to pass. A new line was finished a few months before my trip. The railway was built for speeds up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train. There are few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan doesn't aim for luxury like the Orient Express, though the food on board is excellent. The railway was originally meant to carry goods, not passengers. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to Australia's south via Darwin and the train, instead of by ship around the continent, would save time and money. It's not every day a transcontinental railway is completed, and the Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south one. As I waited to board the Ghan, I saw everyone was excited about the journey. Most of my fellow travelers were Australian pensioners, eager to board. Our first stop, where the Ghan waited four hours, was at Katherine. Some passengers got off here for a boat trip up the gorge. I didn't leave the train until Alice Springs, where I went on a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock isn't encouraged now, and few people do. Our group walked around the rock and stayed to watch the beautiful sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week heading south, so many passengers stop here. The view from the train after Alice Springs isn't very interesting. There's a lot of flat land, with only cattle to see. But at dawn on the third day, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and although the train might not have delivered on everything the ads promise, it took me to some of the most amazing sights Australia has to offer.'

Each year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it's so far north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time climbing Ben Nevis. It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We took a route up the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. It's 600 meters up, probably the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are like big bowls in the mountain walls halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow can be so hard it's like walking on ice. Even though some of us were very experienced, we packed all kinds of safety gear, like lights to attract attention, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather forecast was perfect, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge. The path soon got steep, and my legs felt heavy. I was the weakest in the group, so I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I reached them, they started again. I promised myself that I would always train properly before a climb in the future. After 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path that would take us to the top of Ben Nevis. It's only a meter and a half wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of meters on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and all the way to the island of Skye, 48 kilometers away. But we weren't so lucky because a mist had come down. On Ben Nevis, getting back down to camp can be as challenging as going up. You need to read a map well because a wrong turn could lead to slopes too dangerous to go down in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns doing that job. That first time, it was only when I was safe in the tent that I could say I really enjoyed the experience. But at least I made it to the top.

Anna's new school

This week has been very exciting because we've just moved into our new school building! It's an incredible place. The builders used wood for the entire structure, just like our old school, but this one is designed to be very environmentally friendly, one of the first of its kind in our country. The construction took several months, so we watched it all happen. It was thrilling to see the builders clear the land, although it meant losing some beautiful open space. The noise from the machines was very loud, and the builders often had to stop because of heavy rain. We started to worry that the building might never be finished.

Now, we have five classrooms, which are hugeâ€”much bigger than those in our old, very old school next door. We share one room with the town's people for meetings and other events. There's also a nursery, a lovely dining room, and large changing rooms that we're eager to use once our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you'll notice there are no heaters! Instead, the heat comes from usâ€”the students, teachers, and the computers we use. The building is so well designed that it keeps all the heat insideâ€”and the sound too. When we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we're in a concert hall!

Another interesting feature is the tree on the school roof! The builders placed it there after finishing the roof because it's a tradition in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins very fast. It's so large that it can be seen from miles away! We took some pictures to put on our website.

Even though we're already using the new building, some parts are still being added. For example, we're currently putting on a play for parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall for it. The new hall will be ready by next year. We're thrilled with our new school, and our teachers say we'll learn much faster here!

International Book Club

Have you ever considered joining a book club and buying new books through the mail? At the International Book Club, many members already purchase books from us this way.

To join:
Simply send us your first order from our book list.

Immediate benefits:
As a special offer, you can choose books at a reduced price from our new members' book list, up to a total value of Â£6 (plus postage and packing). This way, you save money compared to the publishers' prices. Tick the box on your form to order a free watch. If you reply within seven days, we will send you another free gift, carefully selected by our staff from our book list. You can also order a DVD from our list at half the recommended retail price.

When you've joined:
As a member, you'll enjoy savings of 30% to 50% off the publisher's price on every book you buy, delivered straight to your door. You'll receive a free club magazine once a month, keeping you updated with the latest best-sellers. Each year, we offer over 1,000 books to choose from. You can find all our titles for the year on our exclusive members' website.

Being a member:
We only ask that you choose four books during your first year. After that, you can decide how many books you want. Each month, our club magazine features a Club Choice book, either fiction or a reference title, offered at a special price. If you don't want this book, just indicate that on the form. We will send the book if we don't hear from you.

To apply:
Fill in the enclosed form and return it in the postage-paid envelope provided. Your books will arrive soon. Don't send any money now; we will bill you with the books. You have up to two weeks to decide if you want to keep the books. If not, return them or send your payment.

Text: 'No Title A month ago, I never imagined that I would be hanging 30 meters above the ground on a Saturday afternoon in November and actually enjoying it. As I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The accommodation wasn't luxurious, but it had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be away from the city and breathing fresh air. On Saturday morning, we met the other ten members of our group. Cameron was there with his two friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn came with Amanda. We all came from different places and none of us knew the area well. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we weren't sure exactly what we would be doing. Half of us spent the morning caving, while the others went rock climbing, and then we switched activities at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally emergedâ€”covered in mud but thrilled and excited by what we had accomplished.'

Text: 'Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon, I accidentally left my handbag on the bus. Inside were my cheque book, address book, and purse, which had about Â£50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized my mistake, it was too late. I felt lost: I'm 72 years old, far from home, and quite worried. I stood by the road and cried. A young man saw me and asked what was wrong. After I explained, he kindly gave me money for the bus fare home. When I told the bus driver my story, he let me keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus. He told me they had found my handbag and offered to bring it back to me. I got my handbag back, with everything still inside. I want to express how grateful I am to everyone who helped me that day and how much I appreciate their kindness and honesty. Mrs. B. James, Newport'

Sharks are some of the most intimidating animals in the ocean. They are excellent hunters because they have good eyesight and can sense movement through special lines on their bodies. This makes them very dangerous to smaller sea creatures, which they eat. While sharks share some similarities with other fish, their bodies are different. For instance, most sharks need to keep swimming constantly to breathe and survive, so they rarely sleep. Additionally, if sharks are flipped onto their backs, they can become completely still. This is helpful for researchers who need to study sharks, as it allows them to learn more about these interesting animals.

Text: 'AUSTRALIA for only Â£1985 OUR PRICE INCLUDES Scheduled flights with Qantas, Australia's national airline, from London or Manchester to Perth, and returning from Melbourne. After arriving in Perth, you'll take Air Australia flights between Perth, Alice Springs, Cairns, and Sydney. A coach will take you from Sydney to Melbourne, passing through Canberra and Albury. All airport transfers in Australia are included. You'll stay for nineteen nights in quality hotels with full continental breakfast. The trip includes a day visit to Ayers Rock, a full-day boat trip on the Great Barrier Reef, a visit to an Australian sheep station, and city sightseeing tours in Perth, Alice Springs, Sydney, Canberra, and Melbourne. All state and local taxes are covered, as well as hotel baggage handling. An experienced Globewise Tour Manager will be with you throughout the trip. PERTH Enjoy long, golden beaches, excellent restaurants, lush green parks, and the beautiful Swan River. A city sightseeing tour is included. ALICE SPRINGS Fly over the outback to Alice Springs, located in the heart of Aboriginal country. A full sightseeing tour is included, where you can see the Flying Doctor base and the 'School of the Air'. AYERS ROCK Travel to Yulara National Park to visit the mysterious Olgas and Ayers Rock, known for its caves and Aboriginal rock paintings. Then, fly to the lively seaside town of Cairns to relax in the sun. GREAT BARRIER REEF We've included a full-day boat trip on the famous reef, where you can see amazing, brightly colored fish and other sea creatures. SYDNEY Experience the excitement and beauty of Australia's largest city. A sightseeing tour and a visit to the famous Opera House are included. You can also book a day trip to the Blue Mountains. MELBOURNE A city sightseeing tour is included, or you can choose to visit the Penguin Parade. We promise that by the end of the trip, you'll want to return!'

Text: 'Joining the Kirov Ballet I'm Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov Ballet School in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I felt nervous because I didn't know anyone. Everyone gathered around me, asking questions in Russian. I tried to respond in Russian, and then they switched to English, so we managed to communicate. Now, six months later, everyone is very kind to me, my Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers. For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mum stayed with me, and when she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called home late at night once because I felt lonely. Compared to my ballet school in England, the classes in Russia are very challenging, and I eat a lot to keep my energy up. This makes me confident that I can meet the school's high standards. In the evenings, I watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the movie ends. Now that I've settled in, I feel really at home here. I enjoy walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when it was extremely cold. I decided to buy a fur hat because it was minus 10Â°C, but the Russians said it was mild for that time of year! At least my room was warm and cozy. Right now, we are preparing for a new production, and there's also a competition for young dancers that I'm going to enter. I feel so lucky to be here.'

The ICEHOTEL

For many years, people visited the Arctic in the summer to see the midnight sun. In winter, however, only a few locals stayed in the snowy and icy landscape. By the late 1980s, people started to see the cold winter as an opportunity. In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit held an exhibition in a specially built igloo in Jukkasjarvi, a small town on the frozen Torne River. This igloo, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors. One night, some foreign guests decided to sleep there. They enjoyed the experience so much that the idea of an ice hotel was born. Today, the ICEHOTEL is famous worldwide.

Every winter, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from around the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As soon as one part is finished, it opens to visitors and overnight guests, while other parts are still under construction. The first section is ready in December, and new sections open each week until the entire hotel is completed by January 7th. Since the hotel is built outdoors using natural winter materials, the completion date can change depending on the weather. In spring, the hotel melts as temperatures rise.

Inside the hotel, the temperature stays between -5Â°C and -8Â°C, no matter how cold it is outside. Guests receive warm outer clothing like overalls, hats, and gloves as part of their stay. It's also wise to bring sweaters, a scarf, and plenty of wool socks. Choose footwear that is larger than usual to fit thick socks. If you're planning a visit, you can buy warm clothing and other items on the ICEHOTEL website. These can be delivered to your room when you check in.

The hotel is located in Jukkasjarvi, 200 km north of the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. Bus transport can be arranged from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

Text: 'Shopping for furniture A report by Dave Worthington Homestyle, a new furniture store, had to close soon after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Around 6,000 people rushed to the store for special deals, like a leather sofa for Â£45 (available only until 3 am) and a bed for Â£30 (available only between 3 am and 8 am). Normally, the store will be open from 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had planned to stay open for 24 hours straight on its first day. However, they had to close just 30 minutes after opening. A police officer at the scene said: 'We knew a big crowd was expected, but people were not patient. The store filled up quickly, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. People outside got upset because they thought everything would be sold out before they could get in, and they refused to wait quietly. Another issue was the long line of cars trying to reach the parking lot. Many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked to the store, which completely blocked the road.' One customer, Jenny Smith, who got inside, said: 'I waited for three hours and didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were calm and explained the situation. They had no choice because it wasn't safe. I'll come back when they reopen, but I won't wait in line again.'

The Short Story Society is a group that supports writers in Britain. It started in 1899 and is now one of the most active arts organizations in the country.

**Society Magazines**  
The Society publishes several magazines. One popular magazine is the Short Story Review, which features stories by top British writers and gives new writers a chance to be published. Another magazine, Short Story News, includes interviews with writers and information about events, competitions, festivals, and the writing world. You can read some articles from recent issues by following the links on the website.

**National Short Story Competition**  
The Society organizes the National Short Story Competition, the largest of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and over, and stories on any topic are welcome. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words. Members of the Society do not pay an entry fee, while non-members pay Â£5. The competition runs from April to the end of October each year. The top ten stories are published in the Society's annual book, and the winner gets a publishing contract for their own collection of stories.

**Education**  
For almost thirty years, the Society has been bringing writers into classrooms to inspire children and teachers and boost their writing confidence. One of the current projects is the Young Writer of the Year, started in 1998, for writers aged 11-18. Winners receive book prizes and can attend a five-day course taught by professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**  
The Writers' Cafe is the Society's social hub. It is a relaxed and stylish place offering freshly cooked vegetarian food, excellent coffees, and cold drinks. It is a great spot to read the Society's magazines. The Cafe also hosts monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. Located in central London, it is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday to Friday and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Society members get discounts on certain products and events.

**Becoming a Member**  
The Society has members all over the world, and anyone aged eighteen or over can join. If you want to become a member of The Short Story Society, click here to fill out a registration form.

Tanya Streeter is a world-record holder in free-diving, a sport where divers go deep underwater on a single breath. In 2003, she made history by diving 120 meters without any assistance, holding her breath for over three and a half minutes. This achievement made her the first woman to break a man's world record in any sport. A team of fourteen safety divers monitored her dive at various depths. Despite concerns about the dangers of free-diving, Tanya believes that safety and training are crucial.

Most free-divers focus on specific events, but Tanya's training routine is consistent. She spends two-thirds of her time on land-based exercises at the gym, with the rest split between pool and ocean training. She uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness but avoids running to protect her knees, opting for fast walking instead. When practicing dives, she usually travels and aims to complete fourteen dives over four weeks, resting between each dive to avoid fatigue.

Outside of training, Tanya often appears in public to promote sports products and supports environmental causes through research and films. Growing up on Grand Cayman in the Caribbean, she loved swimming and exploring marine life, which she feels is reflected in her current life. Known in some countries, she uses her fame to raise awareness about environmental issues. In her thirties, Tanya plans to continue breaking her own records and has no intention of retiring soon, having started free-diving at twenty-five.

Cartoon films have very few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the cinema screen. With new ideas and advanced computer programs, cartoons are becoming exciting again for people of all ages. By the late 1970s, the film industry thought cartoons were just for children. But soon after, a few directors came up with original ideas. They showed that it was possible to make films that both adults and children could enjoy. However, not every cartoon film was a hit. For example, The Black Cauldron didn't do well because it was too scary for kids and too childish for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started making a lot of money again.

Title: Caroline Benson's Journey to Her First TV Role

Caroline Benson, a new TV star, shares her experience of landing her first TV role. She never imagined that during her first year at university, she would be filming "The Finnegans." Although she had only acted in school plays, she had loved the book since she was eleven. Her grandmother often said she was just like Polly Finnegan, and Caroline always dreamed of playing her.

Before starting university, Caroline took a year off to travel. While in Chile, her mother emailed her about plans to turn the book into a TV drama. Caroline felt she had to audition for the role. Her mother, initially surprised, sent Caroline's photo to the director and convinced him to meet her. Caroline flew back home and got the part.

The outdoor filming began a week after university started, so she got permission to be away for three weeks. Once back at university, she woke up at 6:00 am to catch up on missed essays. She didn't tell her university friends about her role, but they eventually found out and were very supportive. It was an incredible experience, and she feels very fortunate.

Caroline plans to pursue acting as a career after university, even though she doesn't come from an acting familyâ€”her grandfather was an opera singer. She has auditioned for other TV roles but hasn't received any offers yet. Despite her busy schedule, she managed to maintain a full social life. When filming ended, she felt a bit lost. Since then, she has acted in two college plays. Unfortunately, she hasn't been home much, and now that her first year at university is over, she's heading to Greece for the summer with friends.

When I started the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my main goal was to make enough money to support my children. Now, 'The Body Shop' has become an international company that is growing quickly worldwide. Over the years, I have learned a lot, and I have shared much of this knowledge in this book. I believe our company has valuable insights on how to run a successful business while staying true to our values. This book is not a typical business guide, nor is it just about my personal story. The key message is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with love, and it can have a positive impact. In both business and life, I need to have fun, feel a sense of family, and be excited by surprises. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. This book shares these ideas with the world and makes them public. I like to think there are no limits to our 'family' and no limits to what we can achieve. I find that thought exciting, and I hope you do too.

Text: 'A JOURNEY ALONG THE BEAUTIFUL DOURO RIVER

JULES VERNE offers a 'hotel ship' experience on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can accommodate 160 guests in double cabins, each with an outside view, private shower, and toilet. The ship is air-conditioned and features a sun deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

Itinerary:

Day 1: Depart from London Heathrow to Oporto in the early evening. Upon arrival, your guide will take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will spend the night.

Day 2: Enjoy a morning tour of Oporto, then return to the ship and set sail for Entre-os-Rios. This part of the river journey lasts four hours.

Day 3: Continue traveling up the river. In the early evening, the ship stops at Peso da Regua, known for port wine production. Dinner will feature local food and drinks.

Day 4: After breakfast, take a bus to the historic town of Lamego to visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum. The museum, once a palace, houses a fine collection of paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. Return to the ship and sail to Tua.

Day 5: The Douro River narrows here. Depending on the river's depth, you might continue by a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. The return to Tua is by coach, offering many sights along the way.

Day 6: In the morning, drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for stunning views of the Douro Valley. Return to the ship for lunch, then take a scenic train ride through the Douro River Valley to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting.

Day 7: Visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch. Then, sail back down the river to Oporto, where you will spend the night on board.

Day 8: Arrive in Oporto with time for independent sightseeing and last-minute shopping before your flight back to London Heathrow.'

Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees, containing water and sugars. Bees can travel up to 75,000 kilometers and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the flowers the bees visit, with over 300 different types of honey available. Generally, lighter-colored honey has a milder taste than darker honey. In ancient times, honey was the main sweetener because sugar was very rare. It was highly valued by the ancient Egyptians, who even used it as a form of payment. Today, honey is produced and consumed worldwide. Studies suggest that honey can help prevent tiredness and boost athletic performance. Besides being a food, honey is also used for soothing sore throats and is an ingredient in many skin and hair-care products.

Norwich, the capital of East Anglia in Britain, has been inhabited for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had grown into one of England's largest towns. Norwich is known for its religious diversity, with two cathedrals and a mosque. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated the 800th anniversary of receiving a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be called a city and govern itself independently.

Today, Norwich is relatively small compared to cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was England's second-largest city. It continued to grow and became wealthy, known for having as many churches as there are weeks in the year and as many pubs as there are days in the year. Although there are fewer churches and pubs now, the University of East Anglia was established in Norwich in 1964. The city has a growing student population and is a successful commercial center, being the largest insurance services hub outside London. Norwich offers a variety of entertainment options, including theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants, and arts and leisure centers. It also has a football team called 'The Canaries,' known for their green and yellow colors, though the origin of the name is unclear.

A modern shopping center, 'The Castle Mall,' is one of the city's attractions. For over two years, residents lived with a large hole in the city center as builders excavated the main car park. Nearly a million tons of earth were moved to create a city center park on the Mall's roof, featuring water pools and trees. The local people are happy that the old open market remains next to the new development. Both areas are thriving, showing that Norwich has successfully blended the old with the new.

The Albuquerque Balloon Festival

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a desert city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event held every year. The first festival took place in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. It started with about a dozen hot-air balloons launching from a car park in the middle of Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown significantly. This year, at least a thousand balloons from over a third of the countries in the world are expected at its current location outside the city.

What to See

The pilots stay in radio contact and light up their balloons' burners at the same time. These are called 'balloon glows' and are great for taking photos. To see these 'glows,' you need to arrive just after nightfall or before 5:30 am as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready for take-off. The balloons come in all sizes and colors, some shaped like animals, cartoon characters, or well-known products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will love it.

In the afternoon, you can take a balloon flight over the desert with one of the many companies offering rides. Another option is to take the cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains. This is the longest cable car ride anywhere and offers a bird's-eye view of the festival. There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the opening night and the last three nights of the festival.

The Albuquerque Box

This is a local wind pattern that creates perfect conditions for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentler wind currents at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by rising or descending.

Practical Advice

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long waits at the festival site. Wear several layers of thin clothing. It can be quite cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, sunglasses and sunscreen are essential. Bring a flashlight for night-time events and, of course, your camera. If you're not using a digital camera, you'll need high-speed film for evening and night-time pictures.

The Eden Project, located in the south-west of England, has quickly become one of the UK's top tourist spots. When you first see it, the large 'biospheres' on this old industrial site might remind you of a scene from a science-fiction film. Each biosphere has a different climate zone, helping visitors understand the crucial connection between people and plants. It's fascinating to realize how many everyday products come from plants, such as wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate. The Eden Project grows over 135,000 different types of plants. No matter how cold it is outside, computer-controlled electric heaters ensure the plants stay at the right temperature. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always humid due to a large waterfall. Another zone mimics the climate of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to create a desert zone soon.

Text: 'No Title Some people have complained about this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I don't understand why. Isn't 500 pages of original writing of this quality for Â£6.99 quite impressive? Most of the book is fiction, including parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable pieces by well-known writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, the lesser-known writers seem to focus mainly on food. A word of caution about Jane Harris's Those Nails - it's best not to read it right after eating, as it has some very unpleasant scenes that might upset your stomach! The collection also features excellent work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. There are excerpts from novels-in-progress by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there's a bit of non-fiction, including a very funny article by Alan Rusbridger about certain newspapers and an extraordinary piece by Ursula Owen about herself. This is an outstanding collection, and I am eager to see what next year's selection will include.'

Text: "The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "This is when children are discovering the world." Margaret, who lives in London, prefers to start teaching children at ages three and four, but she often makes exceptions for enthusiastic five-year-olds. When she began teaching the violin in 1972, her first students were her children's five-year-old school friends. Margaret's students have group lessons, with about twelve students in each group, and each lesson lasts an hour every two weeks. Additionally, each student has one individual lesson with her every week. Parents must also attend the classes because it is important for them to be actively involved in the lessons. From the very beginning, students learn to play by ear. They do not start reading music until they have been playing for several years, and for a long time, there is a noticeable difference between their playing and their music reading skills. Margaret explains that her method is not intended to create great violinists, and she often advises students who excel to leave and study the violin using more traditional methods.

Moonshine, the band, released their third CD last week called 'Here Again', which follows their previous album 'The Waves'. There have been some changes since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar, replacing Simon McVee who left the band last year, and Tom Simpson has joined as the drummer. From the first song, which is a dance track, it's clear that the band is moving away from focusing only on slow songs. The second track is also a dance tune and is even louder and heavier. Most of the later tracks return to the band's usual slow style. These two dance tracks will surprise many fans, but they are excellent and could easily become hit singles. Singer Rob Letchford impressively hits every note perfectly. Fans should be thankful he recorded the songs before he had throat problems, which have caused the band to cancel their next tour. (Anyone who bought tickets shouldn't worry, as all concerts will be rescheduled once Rob recovers.) On this CD, Moonshine shows they can create perfect music in different styles, from the slow ones we know to the upbeat ones that make you want to dance. However, I felt that the best songs were at the beginning, and the last few tracks weren't as strong. Despite this, 'Here Again' is sure to be a big hit and bring more success to the band.

San Francisco is located on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to discover the area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola, who saw it in 1769. Interestingly, even though San Francisco Bay is an excellent natural harbor, it was discovered from land, not from the sea. In 1849, thousands of people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. However, it wasn't the gold seekers who became wealthy. The richest people made their money by owning banks and law firms, and they built large houses on a hill called Nob Hill. Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the former prison.

Text: 'SAMUEL PEPYS Samuel Pepys wrote the most famous diary in English. His diary gives a detailed and interesting view of everyday life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys talks about important events of the time, like disease outbreaks, an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself, including his flawsâ€”he often fell asleep in church or admired pretty girls. He describes his home life, such as arguments with his wife and how they made up, and his worries about her health. Besides books, he enjoyed music, the theatre, card games, and lively parties with good food. Pepys was a busy man with many important rolesâ€”he was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also known for his contributions to the British Navy.'

Text: 'The History of Shoes In the past, shoes were not designed to be comfortable or stylish. Early shoes were likely made from animal skins, which people wrapped around their ankles in cold weather. Today, we still use leather, but materials like silk, plastic, and cotton are also popular, depending on fashion trends. It was only about 150 years ago that people started wearing different shoes on each foot. Before that, both shoes were straight and could fit either the left or right foot. All shoes used to be handmade, but now, although some shoemakers still use traditional methods, most shoes are produced by machines in large factories. The invention of sewing machines allowed the shoe industry to make large quantities of cheaper shoes for more people.'

When I hurt my back, I had to pause my running career. During this time, I wanted to encourage more women to try running, to show them how enjoyable it can be and to boost their confidence to start running. I decided to create a women's running club in my area because I was frustrated with how some race organizers behaved. They often complain about the low number of women in the sport but use this as an excuse not to provide separate changing rooms. I put up posters, and 40 women of different ages and fitness levels joined. Most of them were interested in losing weight, but I don't think they had seriously considered running before. When they thought about it, they imagined difficult training sessions. They didn't picture themselves chatting and smiling while running in beautiful places, like along a river. Initially, they could only run for a minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes. They've also learned from other runners about diet and general fitness. I wanted to contribute to women's running, and I've enjoyed watching their progress almost as much as they have.

Text: 'THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the northernmost state of the USA. Many people moved there, hoping to become rich. New towns were quickly built and expanded. One of these towns was named Iditarod, meaning 'far, distant place'. In 1909, it grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska. During the summer, supplies could be delivered by boat, but in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making access impossible. So, in 1910, a winter trail was created for dog sled teams to deliver mail, food, and clothes to gold miners. This trail was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a dog team to travel across Alaska. They stopped at 'roadhouses' where the drivers and dogs could rest and eat. The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced steam boats and dog teams as the main transport method. However, in 1925, the dogs were needed again when a disease called diphtheria struck the city of Nome. The disease could be treated, but the nearest medicine was in Anchorage, on the other side of Alaska. Airplanes were still new, and it was uncertain if they could fly in such cold weather. Also, Carl Eielson, the only pilot skilled enough for the flight, was away. So, it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine. The journey covered over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty teams just six days to complete the trip. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who came to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He relied on his dog Togo to navigate through the blinding snow, and Togo proved to be a dependable guide. The last part of the journey was completed by Gunnar Kaasen, who had been driving dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Balto. At one point, Balto refused to move forward, saving the team from falling into icy water. The diphtheria outbreak was stopped, and Balto became a hero. Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the route of the 1925 journey. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.'

Text: 'Sweden's Ice Hotel The village of JukkasjÃ¤rvi is in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40Â°C. Despite the cold, 6,000 tourists visit each year to experience one of Europe's most unique hotels. At this hotel, you can eat, drink, and sleep in rooms made entirely of ice. You can even have a wedding there if you wish. The bar is also made of ice, so placing hot drinks on it is not a good idea! The bedrooms are kept at around -4Â°C, but guests receive special sleeping bags to stay warm. If needed, suitable outdoor clothing is also available. The hotel is rebuilt every winter because it melts in the summer. Building it requires 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.'

In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football on an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one minded that I was a girl, but then the team we defeated complained." This story caught the attention of Jose Craveirinha, a supporter of African athletes, when it appeared in a local newspaper. He went to see Maria and found her playing football outside the club. He quickly noticed her speed. "He talked to me about athletics, but I didn't know what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and started training me. It was tough, and my legs hurt a lot." Jose visited her parents and convinced them that Maria could succeed in athletics, which might help lift them out of poverty. They agreed to let her train with him. In 1991, Maria finally accepted an offer to train in the United States. She had previously refused because she would miss her family. Her life was very different from the girls she met in the US. She says, "They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew little about me and even less about my challenges. But I knew I was fortunate to be there. The trainers were excellent, and I learned a lot." Today, Maria continues to run and spends most of the year living happily in South Africa with her mother.

The Skywalk at the Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. Visitors come to the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and especially to enjoy the view. The view is spectacular, and the Skywalk enhances it. The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and floor, allowing you to see the stunning canyon rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at once. It opened in 2007, and since then, thousands have visited it. You must wear special shoe covers to prevent scratching the glass. Walking on the Skywalk feels like floating high in the air, like a bird.

Text: 'THE ROCKIES The Rocky Mountains stretch almost the entire length of North America. They begin in the northwest but are only a few hundred miles from the center in the more southern regions. Although the Rockies are smaller than the Alps, they are equally impressive. There are many roads through the Rockies, but the best way to experience them is by train. You start in Vancouver, one of Canada's most beautiful large cities. This city is unique because it is located by the water and surrounded by mountains, allowing residents to ski just 15 minutes by car from the city center. In the past, thirty passenger trains departed daily from Vancouver on the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the journey remains an exciting adventure. You sleep on the train, which is enjoyable, but you pass through some of the most stunning scenery at night.'

Text: 'ZOOS People started keeping animals in zoos over 3,000 years ago. One of the first was the Gardens of Intelligence in China. In the past, animals in zoos often performed tricks for visitors. This practice has stopped, and now zoos aim to show animals behaving naturally. Today, most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. However, not everyone agrees with the idea of zoos. Supporters argue that zoos allow us to learn about nature and see wild animals up close, which wouldn't be possible otherwise. Critics, on the other hand, believe it's wrong to keep animals in cages. They also point out that in poorly managed zoos, animals might live in dirty conditions and eat the wrong food.'

Text: 'JAZZ By Katie Atkins, aged 14 I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes, from black school uniforms like ours to bright T-shirts. We didn't look like adult professional bands, but we were all used to performing in competitions, so the quality of playing was impressive, especially since everyone was so young. Musicians from each band even created new tunes right on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band played! We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to join gets inâ€”only about half do. However, anyone eager to play attends jazz practice before school, and we often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning its style. There are also trips to jazz summer camps across the country. I've been to a couple and learned a lot. Adults are often surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher thinks it's because pop music isn't challenging enough for serious music students like me. I find jazz exciting because it's both new and oldâ€”you can create your own music, but you also feel connected to its history, playing on stage like the great jazz performers before you. My school is really lucky because we have great teachers and supportive parents. Without them, we wouldn't achieve much with our music!'

Text: 'Watering the Desert In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime from November to March. However, it doesn't rain often, and when it does, the city's water pipes struggle with the sudden floods, turning streets into rivers. Despite this, the rain is welcomed by locals, especially since many winters have been dry recently. Marrakesh's parks and gardens thrive not because of rain, but due to an ancient network of underground channels, built in the 11th century, that bring water from the mountains all year. These dry areas that get water this way are called oases. Traveling further south from Marrakesh, you reach Skoura. Here, every piece of land is divided into small squares by water channels and used for growing food. The Atlas Mountains, covered in snow during winter, provide a beautiful backdrop.'

Gareth Ellis, who is 13 years old, is the youngest child of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. His older brothers have jobs in banking and computers, but Gareth has always wanted to be a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined a circus. "People laugh when we tell them," says Kath. "But it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three." When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to try and find full-time jobs with a circus. They both got jobs with a well-known circus, and Gareth started training to be a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and go back home in the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away. "I can't say it was easy," says Kath. "There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a very small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving behind our lovely house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths." "People ask about my education," says Gareth, "but from the beginning, wherever we go, someone has always come to teach me. I use the same books as everyone back at school and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind my classmates." And what about the future? "It was a difficult decision," says Kath, "but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day," he says, "maybe Bippo's circus."

Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8 to 18. Our members gather news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to major newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites for publication. Accepted stories can be read or listened to on our website. We have three centers nationwide where young people can meet and work on projects, and we plan to open more. Since starting in 1994 as 'Young News,' over 2,500 young people have joined us. 

Sophie, a former member, shares her experience: "I learned about Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article on young people's views on hip hop. I was impressed by the young journalists' opportunities. Age didn't matter; they were trusted to handle stories independently. I joined the Eight-eighteen center in my city, received training, and stayed until I was 18. The skills I gained helped me get a job at 19, and now I'm the youngest employee at a major news website, reviewing articles before they go online."

When you join Eight-eighteen, you'll receive training and attend monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. We encourage members to share skills. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and up who teach new members basic journalism skills. As they gain experience, some present sessions to young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, often at youth clubs and summer camps, with support from older staff.
