We hold training sessions for new members three times a year. The next session is in February. If you're interested in joining, contact Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The program is open to children with all levels of reading and writing skills. Membership is free, and there's no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website. Hereâ€™s what you need to know before booking a flight.

**Flight Overview**

During the short Antarctic summer, we offer sightseeing flights from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica and back in a Boeing 747. Flight dates for next year aren't set yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be transferred if we change the date.

**Frequently Asked Questions**

**How long is the flight?**

The flight lasts about 12 hours. After four hours, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica, and the rest of the time returning. During the flight, experts who have lived on Antarctic research stations give talks about the environment and history and answer questions. A camera near the pilot shows you a pilot's view from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a window seat?**

All passengers receive two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, you switch to the seat on your second pass. Business and first-class passengers have a window seat for half the flight and a seat next to the window for the other half. Economy passengers have a window or next-to-window seat for half the flight and an aisle seat for the other half. Over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to move around the plane to share the views. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' over points of interest so both sides of the plane can see the sights.

**What if the weather is bad?**

We have 17 approved flight plans. On the morning of the flight, the captain checks satellite images and chooses the route with the clearest views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**

Most Antarctic wildlife is at sea level, over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we can't see them clearly. We don't land in Antarctica for environmental reasons. To see wildlife, you would need a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**

Absolutely! All cameras are welcome. We also offer fun photo opportunities on board where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

Text: 'Little Chefs For a group of children aged ten to fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning serious cooking skills. These weekly lessons, held in small classes, are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children eager to join. Parents pay Â£280 for the course, where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Bill, a ten-year-old class member, says, 'I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to share the food we've made.' Flora, who is twelve, is having trouble with onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. Then my mum suggested I take up a hobby instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking while they're young, they'll have the skills to make food for themselves when they leave home.''

Winter Driving

Winter driving is dangerous because it's hard to predict what will happen, and accidents can occur easily. Fog might appear suddenly as you go over a hill. Ice can be hidden under melting snow, ready to make you lose control. A car coming towards you might unexpectedly slide across the road. 

Rule Number One for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make your car hard to control. So, whenever you turn the wheel, use the brakes, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee on the seat next to you. Drive in a way that you wouldn't spill it.

Rule Number Two is to be aware of what might happen. The more ice there is, the further ahead you need to look. Test how long it takes to stop by gently pressing the brakes. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. Generally, allow double your normal stopping distance when the road is wet, three times this distance on snow, and even more on ice. 

Try to keep control of your car at all times to avoid trouble.

Craigie Aitchison was a painter from Scotland. He moved to London planning to study law but ended up going to art school. He found traditional drawing classes hard but continued painting. In his late twenties, he received a grant from the Italian government to study art, which sparked his interest in early Italian artists. This influence is visible in some of his work. Aitchison was inspired by the greens and browns of the Italian countryside and the clear light there, which he wanted to capture in his paintings. To achieve this, he painted colors in thin layers from light to dark, though he admits he never knows exactly how the final painting will look. He says, 'It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top.' Aitchison makes it sound simple, saying, 'Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I simply notice what you put the colors next to.' Unlike some artists, he doesn't make sketches before starting a painting because he thinks it might make him lose interest. Instead, he changes his paintings many times before they are finished. This is why he prefers models who don't ask to see their portraits while he's working. 'If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it.' Since moving to London, he hasn't felt connected to the Scottish art scene. He says he doesn't follow any tradition and just paints in his own way. However, his work still influences young British painters.

Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we were against it because of the noise. Ben argued, "It's better than watching TV or playing computer games in my free time, and it'll keep me out of trouble." Eventually, we agreed. "Okay," we said, "but you must be considerate of the family and neighbors when you play."

That was just the start. Since drums are hard to move, Ben's bandmates began coming to our house with their guitars and other equipment. So, for several hours a week, our house is filled with the sound of their instruments and singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band practices, my husband and I go for a long walk. I must admit, even though their music sounds a bit unusual, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I can't judge their musical talentâ€”after all, I didn't expect my parents to like the same music I did as a teenagerâ€”but they do play regularly in local clubs for young people.

Our main concern is that they might not spend enough time on their schoolwork because of their music, though this hasn't happened yet. I always remind Ben how important his studies are. But one thing is certainâ€”Ben was right: it has kept him out of trouble, and he is never bored.

Atlantic College

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a top private school in Wales. This school is special because it offers students valuable experiences outside the classroom, along with their regular studies. The students, aged 16 to 18, come from all over the world. They spend their mornings studying, and in the afternoons, they engage in meaningful activities like helping on a farm, assisting people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the best things about Atlantic College is its diverse student body. Students come from various social backgrounds and countries. Since the fees are high, at Â£20,000 for two years, many students receive financial aid. A quarter of the students are British, and many of them attend thanks to government support.

Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands, said, "I really admire the college for promoting international understanding among young people. You learn to live with and respect others, even those you don't get along with. During the summer holidays, my mother noticed I argued much less with my sister."

In conclusion, Atlantic College provides its students with an excellent education through effective methods.

Text: 'Being an older student At 32, I have just finished my first year at university. I attend lectures regularly, and I've had to learn to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I was earning a decent salary, but I was bored because the job didn't challenge me mentally. I felt trapped in the job and became more and more unhappy. I envied the students at the local university because they seemed happy, carefree, and hopeful, and I wanted to be part of that. However, now that I'm a student, I find it hard to connect with younger classmates. They often mistake me for a lecturer and ask me questions I can't answer. I also feel distant from the lecturers because, even though we are the same age, they know much more than I do. But I am grateful for this chance to study because I know a qualification is necessary for a fulfilling job, which is very important to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending weekends with my books rather than going out partying. There are also typical student perks like long holidays and discounts at theatres and cinemas. I often wonder what I'll do after university, but I hope that continuing my education at this stage in life has been a good decision.'

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he didn't enjoy farming. At fifteen, he started working as a mechanic and built his first car in 1893. After driving it for 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two larger cars. In 1903, he founded the Ford Motor Company. He used strong but lightweight steel to make affordable cars for regular people. In 1908, he created the first Ford Model T, which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was valued at $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and inexpensive, but this simplicity sometimes meant fewer options. Henry Ford famously said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

Text: 'Dear Sir, I saw your ad for English courses in the newspaper. I would like more details. How much does a course cost? Also, how long is each course and when does the next one start? Yours, Maria Gonzalez Dear Ms. Gonzalez, Thank you for your letter. Our next course begins in three weeks, on Monday, 9 May. It lasts 6 weeks and costs Â£150. If you want to start in June, we offer another course that lasts 10 weeks for Â£200. I hope this answers your questions. Yours, David May'

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before her climb, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small apartment in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and family to travel to Asia with other climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is tough. "You have to carry everything on your back," she said, "so you can only bring what you really need. You can't wash on the mountain, and eventually, I didn't even bring a toothbrush. I'm usually a clean person, but there's no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only bring enough to drink!" When Rebecca reached the summit of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. She suddenly became famous. Now, she has written a book about her journey, and people often invite her to speak about it. She also has a new job on a science TV program. Rebecca is well-known today and has more money, but she still lives in her small apartment in south London, surrounded by her pictures and books about mountains.

Dear Mike, I'm sorry you couldn't make it to my party yesterday. Jon mentioned you had a bad cold and chose to stay in bed. Are you feeling better now? The party was great; the best I've ever had! Many of my friends came, and they gave me some wonderful presents. I'll tell you more about it when you come to school on Monday. Love, Lorenzo

CANADA GEESE

Canada Geese are large birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they need to fly south to warmer places because the winters in Canada are too cold for them to survive. Last spring, Bill Lishman discovered sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents, and Bill worried that they wouldn't know where to go in the autumn. Bill had a small plane, so he decided to teach the birds to follow him. Throughout the summer, he took short flights in his plane, and the young geese flew behind him. When autumn's cold weather came, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, which is 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way there. Bill left the geese in Virginia and returned home. This spring, Bill expected the birds to come back, but they didn't show up. So, he flew to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but couldn't locate them. When he got back home, he found the geese waiting for him. They had managed to find their way back without his help!

Text: 'ESTHER'S STORY When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her Â£500 for her birthday. While most of her friends chose to go to college, Esther used the money from her aunt to start a business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make her own jam. She sold each jar for Â£1 to her friends and quickly doubled the Â£500. Initially, her parents were not happy with her making jam; they wanted her to study and become a teacher or a doctor. However, Esther ignored their wishes and continued her jam-making. After a few months, she began selling her jam at the local market. She then expanded her business by making orange juice, which she sold to a school where a friend worked. After two years, her business grew significantly, and her parents were proud of her achievements. She produced various foods and sold them to shops and supermarkets. Her business became so successful that she needed to hire employees.'

Text: 'Dear Jacqueline, Would you like to join me at the cinema after school today? We can watch Pocahontas at the ABC cinema. The movie starts at 6 o'clock. Shall we meet outside the cinema? Love, Isabella Dear Isabella, I'm really sorry, but I can't go to the cinema this evening. My mother has work, and I need to cook dinner. Why don't you ask Karen to go with you? I hope you enjoy the film. You can tell me about it tomorrow. Love, Jacqueline'

Corryvale Farm is located in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler run the farm, where they have cows and chickens, selling milk and eggs. However, most of their income comes from Jenny's sheep. She owns 50 sheep, and each sheep produces enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen shears the sheep to prevent them from overheating. 

Five years ago, Jenny decided to make sweaters from the wool and sell them at country markets. Unfortunately, it was summer, and the hot weather meant people weren't interested in buying sweaters. So, she started making socks instead. The socks were a hit because they were affordable, durable, and easy to wash. This marked the beginning of Jenny's business. Initially, she made the socks at home, but as her customer base grew to thousands, she had to send the wool to a factory. Now, the socks are produced by machines.

Jenny's socks come in six colors, five sizes for all ages, and are designed for different activities like walking, sports, and skiing. The busiest time for Jenny is Christmas, as Corryvale socks are a popular gift. In Jenny's office, the walls are covered with letters from satisfied customers from around the world.

28 Long Road Brighton  
22nd March  

Dear Pat,  

I arrived here three weeks ago. I'm studying at a language school in Brighton. The students come from many different countries, and I've made a lot of new friends. We have classes for five hours every day. I really like our teacher. His name is John, and he helps me if I make a mistake. I want to visit London next weekend because I'm going back to my country on Monday. Can I see you there? Please write to me soon.  

Best wishes,  
Maria

Text: 'BURGLARS LOVE THE AFTERNOON Most house burglaries occur between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., according to the police. Inspector Ian Saunders informed our newspaper that house burglaries have increased by over 30% compared to last year. He mentioned that 67% of these burglaries happen when people leave and forget to close a door or window. He further explained that burglaries at night are rare because families are usually home. However, he noted that winter afternoons are ideal for burglars because it is dark, making it easier for them to go unnoticed. Additionally, many houses are empty during this time as people are often still at work. Inspector Saunders suggested leaving lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday to deter burglars. He also encouraged neighbors to keep an eye on each other's homes when people are away and to contact the police if they notice anything unusual. 'We can also advise you on how to secure your home,' Inspector Saunders added. 'This assistance is free of charge.''

Dear Lynne and Tony,

I wanted to express my gratitude for the two nights I spent at your wonderful home. It was great to see you both again. Enclosed are the photographs of your children that you requested. They turned out well, don't you think? I hope you enjoy them. I'm really pleased with my new camera. Next week, I'm planning to visit my sister in New York. I'll be taking many photos there as well. It's been a long time since I last saw her. Thanks once more.

Love,  
Roy

Text: 'The History of Farming Before farming, people gathered plants and fruit from forests to eat. This meant they had to move constantly to find food. However, around 12,000 years ago in the Middle East, people began to cultivate crops. These were the first farmers. Farming allowed people to settle in one place, and their villages gradually expanded. Some villagers could focus on other tasks, like making clothes, because farmers provided food for everyone. Unfortunately, farming was challenging during bad weather, leading to food shortages. Today, farmers can produce more food, and it is transported over long distances to reach our homes.'

Nicola Peet started working after finishing school at eighteen. She first went to college and then got a job at a local airport. After nine months, she joined Saudi Arabian Airlines and later became an air hostess with British Airways. Four years after that, she became a manager, which is her current job. Hereâ€™s what she shared about her work:

"My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time flying. I train air hostesses and assist them with any issues. I also attend many meetings. My work hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. At the start of my day, I check flight schedules on my computer and talk to some of the air hostesses. Occasionally, I go on long flights to see how the air hostesses are performing. That's my favorite part of the job, although I enjoy the office work as well. Traveling can be tiring. After a long trip, all I want to do is eat and then sleep! I don't earn a lot, but I'm happy with British Airways and want to stay and keep traveling."

Dear Maria,

It's nice to be back in my home country, but I still think about all the friends I made in our English class, especially you. I cried when I left England because my visit felt too short. I would like to return to England, but next time I plan to stay in a different city. I've started taking English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study even more. How about you? Are you still looking for a job? I hope you find one soon.

Love,  
Sophie

Text: 'Dear Sir, I lost my bag on a train last week. I was on the 8:30 a.m. train to Cambridge on May 10th. It is a large blue bag with my name written on the outside. Have you found this bag? Yours faithfully, Mary Johnson Dear Ms. Johnson, I am happy to inform you that we have your bag here. If you come to this office, I can return it to you. The office is open from 9 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. every day. Yours sincerely, J Wilson'

The Weather People are interested in the weather for many reasons, and it is important for people in various jobs. For instance, the weather significantly affects farmers. In the past, farmers spent a lot of time observing the sky, animals, and plants to understand the weather better. Nowadays, there are many computer programs that help us learn about the weather, and people can even access weather information on their mobile phones. Despite technological advances, many people still believe in traditional weather predictions. For example, they say that if there is a red sky in the evening, the next day will be sunny. Some also believe that when cows lie down in the fields, it will soon rain.

Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from a small Canadian town. They have been friends and classmates for a long time. Like their other friends, they enjoy fishing and swimming on weekends. However, for the past few months, they have been spending their weekends in Peter's room working on his laptop. This isn't because of homework; they have created a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's younger brother, Kevin, who struggles with reading. Kevin finds it easier to learn words by seeing pictures and hearing information rather than just reading. Frazer wanted to help him. So, Frazer and Peter spent over 200 hours developing a computer game, which is now ready to use. It's a game that uses both speech and pictures. For instance, when you see the word 'hat', there is a drawing of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying 'Hat! Hat!' at the same time. The boys have won many prizes for their game, and it will soon be available for sale worldwide. Many schools are interested in purchasing it.

Text: 'HOW DO THE IRISH POP-GROUP 'BOYZONE' MAINTAIN A HEALTHY LIFESTYLE? Getting enough sleep is crucial. When I visit my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. However, after a concert, it's hard for me to sleep because my mind is still filled with music. Exercise is also important. Before my car accident, I spent two and a half hours a day, five days a week, at the sports centre. Now, I can't do that, so I do about 150 sit-ups daily. I avoid alcohol and smoking. I try to eat healthily and drink plenty of water, aiming for about eight glasses a day, though I don't always manage that. It's important not to work constantly. I love my job, but I also enjoy other activities. In my free time, I listen to music or watch TV. It's beneficial to relax sometimes. I don't feel tired anymore since my doctor advised me to improve my diet. Now, I eat a lot of vegetables like carrots and spinach every day, but I still enjoy a burger occasionally!'

Bollywood, the film industry in Mumbai, India, produces nearly 1,000 films each year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has created over 29,000 films, making it the largest film industry in the world, surpassing the USA. Watching films is the most popular leisure activity in India, with ten million people going to the cinema daily. Bollywood films often feature romantic love stories, with singing and dancing as key elements. These films are also popular outside India, earning Bollywood over $500 million last year from international sales. Indian actors make more films annually than their Hollywood counterparts, but they earn less money. As a result, most Bollywood films cost about $2 million to produce, whereas Hollywood films usually cost at least $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young and work intensely for a few years. However, Amitabh Bachchan, considered by some as India's greatest actor, is an exception. He has starred in over 140 films during a career spanning nearly 40 years.

I am Bill Bryson, originally from the United States, but I've written several travel books about England. I lived in England with my wife and four children for 20 years. However, for the past three years, we've been living in the United States. Our children are now experiencing life in the U.S., and I believe they will be happier for having lived in two different countries. I have a fondness for Britain and wish to return, but my daughter, Felicity, is about to start college here, so it will be another four years before we can move back. Recently, I spent six weeks in England working on a radio program about the English language and promoting my latest book. Unlike many writers who dislike traveling to promote their books, I enjoy it. I like exploring new places and meeting new people. This is quite different from my writing life in the U.S. In England, I was driven around in large cars and stayed in luxurious hotels, which was enjoyable because I didn't have to worry about expenses. Everyone was very kind to me, and I had a great time.

Schnauzer Dogs

There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes arrived in England over 50 years ago, but the Giant Schnauzer is a more recent arrival. The name "Giant" fits well because these dogs are 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair that needs regular trimming. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, while the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. Schnauzers originate from Germany, where farmers use them to help with sheep, and they are also employed by the police due to their intelligence. A Schnauzer is a good family dog, as it is friendly and great with young children.

Mary Daniels, a student from England, had an exciting summer holiday this year. She joined a group of fifteen people on a trip to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. Their mission was to help build a road through a forest connecting two large towns. Mary explained, "It was challenging because there was no drinking water and no shops to buy food." She also mentioned that the mountains were very cold and wet, making it one of the wettest places on Earth. Mary spent six weeks in the mountains, working hard, but she considers it the best experience she has ever had. She hopes to return next year to continue her work there.

Dear Keira,

Thank you for your letter. Today was my first day at my new school. A girl named Nicole helped me find my way around and showed me where the classrooms are. She is very nice, and I'm planning to visit her this weekend. My favorite class today was Maths, and I was pleased because I knew more than the other girls. I also tried playing hockey for the first time and really enjoyed it. Most of the teachers seem friendly, but I'm a bit scared of the head teacher. No one likes him because he shouts a lot. I have to go now because I need to do my homework.

Hester

New Books This Month

The Long Night  
This is the first book by David Reilly. David started writing after teaching English for several years. The story is about Maha, a nurse in northern Australia. She works in a small hospital. One day, a baby is very sick, and Maha has to drive all night to take the baby to the nearest big city. They face many challenges on their journey.

Hard Work  
This is the twentieth book by Joanna Jones. The story is about Sombat, who works with his father, a carpenter, in Thailand. They work long hours making tables and chairs, but they don't have much money. One day, a man dressed in black buys the most beautiful table in their shop.

Hospital or Cinema?  
Marcie Jacome, who studies English in London, wrote this story earlier this year. The story is about Tina, a young Brazilian woman who dreams of becoming a doctor. She goes to London to study English and medicine. However, she meets a man who asks her to go to the USA with him to become a film star. What will Tina decide to do?

Horse racing has been an important sport throughout history. It began in Central Asia around 4,500 years ago and was popular in ancient Greece and Rome. Modern horse racing started when Arab horses were brought to Europe in the 12th century. Initially, races were long and involved only two horses. However, in the early 18th century, races became shorter and included several horses competing at once. Today, horse racing is one of the most-watched sports in the USA, second only to baseball, and it is also popular in many other countries.

Nick Barlow is a British actor who loves his job because it allows him to travel the world making TV shows. He feels welcomed everywhere he goes and cherishes the memories of each country he visits. Although he has been to many places, he still dreams of visiting South America and returning to Australia. Nick travels with a team that handles the cameras and filming equipment. He packs lightly for himself, bringing only a few shirts and trousers, but he always includes some books in his suitcase. His wife, Helen, is supportive of his travels. She has many friends and stays busy while he's away. When Nick returns, she enjoys hearing about his adventures. However, there can be challenges. Once, while Nick was in the Malaysian rainforest, he learned that Helen was in the hospital. He felt awful for not being able to help, but she insisted he stay. He was relieved when she recovered.

Parrots are beautiful birds known for their vibrant colors and long tails. You might have seen them in forests or zoos. They are native to countries like Brazil, Australia, and India. Parrots often live in large groups and enjoy eating fruit, which can sometimes cause issues for farmers. There are many species of parrots, but they all share strong beaks and feet, which help them climb and hold food. The largest parrots can live up to 80 years. Although they are quite noisy, parrots are intelligent and can be taught to speak. Some zoos even have parrot shows where you can watch them perform tricks they have learned.

Howard Bonnier Bray is a charming village about fifty kilometers west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there about three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr. Bonnier's name yet, but he is already quite famous in France. This is because he has written for French magazines about almost all the best restaurants in that country. He is only 29 years old. When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He enjoyed this so much that he decided not to spend money on clothes and CDs; instead, he used his money to visit France and dine in good restaurants. He also bought many French and English cookbooksâ€”he says he has more than two hundred and fifty! So why did he decide to open a restaurant? Simply because he loves cooking. Has it been easy? He says it's expensive to start your own restaurant and much more difficult to cook for fifty people than for your family, but he is sure he has made the right choice.

John Pickering works in a park in a small town in central England, where he cuts the grass and waters the flowers. However, last week he was in Tokyo, where millions of Japanese people watched him on television. This is because John, who is 35 years old, is currently the top singer in Japan. He first went to Japan a few months ago to perform in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A disc jockey heard his songs and played them on the radio, leading to hundreds of young people calling in to request the songs again. In Japan, John performs under the name Jon Otis. Despite his success, he plans to continue working in the park in England because he is unsure how much money he will make from his music. "I need to keep my job in the park," he says. "I still have bills to pay!" The other gardeners are unaware of his fame in Japan and have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, who works in a hospital, says, "This won't change our lives. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"

Could I take a two-week holiday in July? I prefer the first two weeks, but if that's not possible, the last two weeks are fine. Additionally, can I have three extra days off in the first week of December?

Line dancing has become a popular hobby for thousands of people in Britain. In nearly every town, you can find clubs and classes dedicated to this activity. According to Fiona Lever, a line dancing teacher, "Line dancing is easy to learn. If you can walk, you can do it!" You don't need a partner because you dance in groups, making it a great way to meet new people. Her classes include both young and old participants. Boys particularly enjoy it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet while dancing. When did line dancing start? Most people believe it began about fifteen years ago when American country music gained popularity in Britain.

Text: 'The Rhino There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open fields of Africa, while the others live in Asian forests. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough and they have very little hair. A rhino's big body stands on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run up to 50 kilometers per hour. Rhinos are generally quiet and calm animals, and they eat only grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs 40 kilos at birth and has been inside its mother for about fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs over 200 kilos and can live up to 50 years.'

Text: 'THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE Today, police officers are everywhere, but in 1700, London had none. A few elderly men used to guard the streets at night, and they were poorly paid. Around 300 years ago, London began to grow. The city was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were so many thieves stealing money in the streets that people preferred to stay at home. In 1750, Henry Fielding started paying a group to catch thieves. They were similar to policemen and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had grown much larger and needed more police. So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan (or London) Police Force was established with 3000 officers. Most of them patrolled on foot, but a few rode horses. Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Today, London police are well paid, and those who still ride horses earn even more than the others.'

Text: 'TO ALL STUDENTS: Are you interested in joining a camping trip this weekend? We will travel to the forest by school bus and stay at a campsite from Friday to Sunday. The campsite offers hot showers, a small shop, and bicycle rentals. The trip costs Â£25. Please note that it gets very cold at night, so bring warm clothes and sturdy shoes. If you want to join, let me know today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, thousands of people visit Edinburgh, the capital of Scotland, to experience the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is full of actors and artists from around the world. They come for the largest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are lively with music and dance from morning until night. You can even watch artists painting on the streets. One of the highlights of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small venues like halls and cafes. Many tourists come to see new films, plays, and listen to music by famous musicians. This year, there are over five hundred performances with actors from more than forty countries. Tickets for these shows are quite affordable, and it's often easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So, plan to visit Edinburgh next summer, but remember that finding a room can be tough, so consider booking your hotel now!

ICE-FISHING

If you drive three hours north from Toronto, you'll reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and thousands of Canadian fishermen visit every weekend. They build small wooden huts on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Inside these huts, they fish for the fish swimming beneath the ice.

Bob Marvisch has been coming here every year for twenty-five years. He says, "You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks and gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching the fish is easy. First, you break the ice and make a small round hole. Then, you take a fishing line, put some bread on it, and drop it through the hole into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. The fish are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but after catching three or four, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today, I've caught twenty-five! It's a great sport, and you can meet some nice people here!"

Subject: Tough Week

Hi Anna,

I'm having a rough week. Yesterday, my team lost a volleyball match because the other team played much better. Then, my friend Jeff from Australia called with bad news. He can't visit us during the holidays because he got a summer job, so we can't go camping together. This morning, my sister woke up late and took my bike to school without telling me. I'm really upset with her. I hope you have some good news to share. Please write back today if you can.

Greg

Madame Tussaud's Museum is a very popular tourist attraction in London. At this museum, visitors can see wax figures of famous people. Madame Tussaud, whose real name was Marie, was born in France in 1761. Her uncle was a doctor who created wax figures of people and opened a museum for them in Paris. Marie worked with him on these figures. During the French Revolution in 1789, Marie was imprisoned and had to make wax copies of the heads of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud. In 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures and opened a museum there. Her wax figures are still on display today.

BICYCLES

Bicycles are an affordable and environmentally friendly way to travel. The first bicycle was created about 150 years ago. Initially, bicycles were costly, so only wealthy people could afford them. These early bicycles looked very different from the ones we see today. As bicycles became more affordable, many people started buying them. People began using bicycles to commute to work and for leisure activities. Nowadays, cars are used more often than bicycles because they are faster and protect you from the rain. However, some people still prefer cycling to work. They argue that there are too many cars in city centers, making it hard to find parking.

Text: 'The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14 Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. It had beautiful flower gardens, but we were mainly interested in the elephant show. We went to a large square with seats on three sides. Three elephants came in with their keepers and stood in front of large white cards. Each elephant was given a paintbrush and started painting on its card. The keepers occasionally gave them new brushes with fresh paint. Following their keepers' instructions, the elephants slowly drew pictures. I was amazed! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the keepers held up the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We gave the elephants the bananas we had brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they don't work there anymore, but the smartest ones live in special centers where visitors can watch them.'

Text: 'Big Cats There are many different types of big cats, and they vary in size, appearance, and behavior. Tigers are the largest of the big cats, reaching up to 3.7 meters in length from head to tail. Unlike most cats, tigers enjoy water and will often cool off in pools when it's hot. Lions are unique among big cats because they live in large family groups called prides. In these groups, several lions work together to hunt and provide food. Lions typically inhabit flat, open areas where they have a clear view to track other animals. All big cats need excellent eyesight to hunt smaller animals for food. They also require speed and strength to catch their prey.'

Dear Mrs. Brian,

I regret to inform you that I can no longer attend your class because I need to return to my country. My sister is getting married next month, and I want to help her choose a dress. My parents are preparing a big meal for the guests, and there will be a lot of work in the kitchen. I'm sorry to leave the English class. You are an excellent teacher. Please say goodbye to the other students for me.

Thank you once again.

Best wishes,  
Soraya

Text: '14 Sheffield Road Rotherham 20th May 2002 Dear Mary, I will be in London next Thursday morning. Would you like to have lunch with me? Please let me know when you are available and where I can meet you. I hope to see you then. Yours, Joan 20 Didsbury Drive London NW1 22 May 2002 Dear Joan, Thank you for your letter. I received it this morning. Yes, I would love to see you. How about meeting outside my office at one o'clock? There's a good Italian restaurant nearby. Do you like Italian food? I need to be back at work by two o'clock, so please don't be late! Yours, Mary '

Dear Lorna,

How are you? I'm excited to share that I got a new job last month in the city centre. I'm working at a Tourist Information Office, and it's really interesting. I start work every morning at 7:30, so I have to wake up very early! I love this job because I get to meet people from many different countries. I enjoy telling them about our city. I've attached a photo of me in my new uniform. Do you like it?

Love,  
Gloria

The ostrich is the largest bird in the world, with adults weighing over 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches are found in southern Africa, but their numbers are low. Although ostriches have wings like all birds, they cannot fly. Instead, they use their wings to help them change direction while running. Ostriches are very fast runners, reaching speeds of 65 to 90 kilometers per hour, making it hard for predators to catch them. Baby ostriches are about the size of chickens and take around 3 years to grow into adults. They eat plants and can survive for several days without water.

Victoria Jamieson from Britain began snowboarding at the age of 20. Now, at 23, she has won many competitions in the sport. We interviewed her last week at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland and asked why she took up snowboarding. She said, "I've always enjoyed all kinds of sports, especially skiing, so snowboarding felt like a natural choice. It's quick to learn, and you can become really good in just a few months." 

When asked about her practice routine, she explained, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. But I love doing all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains because it's so beautiful. However, free-riding, which is snowboarding outside of competitions, is the best thing in the world for me."

We also asked her what is important when learning to snowboard. She advised, "You can learn quickly, but you need lessons. It's also crucial to have the right clothes so you don't get wet, as you'll spend a lot of time falling down at first!"

23 Oak Avenue  
Manchester  

Dear Sir or Madam,

I am writing to request a room at your hotel for three nights, from September 15th to 17th. I would like a single room with a shower and a telephone. Could you please provide a quiet room on the ground floor? I will be driving to the hotel, so I would like to know if there is a car park available. I expect to arrive at around 10:30 p.m. Could you also inform me of the restaurant's closing time in the evening? If possible, I would appreciate having a meal upon my arrival.

Thank you for your assistance.

Yours faithfully,  
Mark Jones

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. People of all ages have climbed it, from a seven-year-old boy to an 87-year-old man. There are different routes to reach the summit. The Marangu route, which is five kilometers long, is considered the easiest. It usually takes about five days to complete and is very popular with tourists. However, only about half of the climbers manage to reach the top. This is often because the weather can change very quickly. At the start, it might be hot and wet, but at the summit, there is ice and snow, and temperatures can drop below 20 degrees Celsius. Climbers need to bring both sunglasses and warm clothing!

Text: 'Otters Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes using small pieces of wood. They usually come out at night. Otters are excellent swimmers and can move through the water at speeds over 10 kilometers per hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, allowing it to stay underwater for several minutes. Twenty years ago, there were not many otters in Great Britain because the rivers were polluted, causing many fish and insects to die, leaving otters with little to eat. However, today the rivers are clean again, providing plenty of food for them.'

Dear Deshini,

I'm excited to have you as my new penfriend. My name is Tom, and I'm fifteen years old. I was born in Canada, but now I live in England. Please write to me and tell me about your life in India. I would love to visit there someday. Do you live in a small village or a big town? What is your school like? Do you have any pictures of your school that you could send me? I'm sending you a few photos of my family, and I'll send more next time I write. I hope to hear from you soon.

Tom

17 Green Street  
Camden  
London  
29th August 2002  

Dear John,

Thank you for helping me with my English. You are an excellent teacher. I really enjoyed my time in Cambridge. Now, I am staying at my brother's apartment. He is studying medicine to become a doctor. I will be with him for two weeks before returning home to Greece. I really like London. Yesterday, we took a bus to Regents Park. The weather was very sunny, and we had a great time. Tonight, I am going to watch a film with my brother and some of his friends. I will write to you again from Greece.

Best wishes,  
Kostas

Text: 'Dear David, I'm planning to visit your country next month with two friends. We haven't decided where to stay yet. Are there any affordable hotels in your town? We would prefer to stay in the city center. Can you assist us? Carlos Dear Carlos, Hotels in the city center tend to be pricey, but I have some good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria about your visit, and she said you can all stay at her house. She has more bedrooms than I do! Is that okay with you? David'

Text: 'Buildings People have always constructed buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football matches and concerts. We use other buildings, like museums, to store beautiful things. Many people collaborate on a building project. The architect designs the building's appearance and creates drawings to show their ideas. Engineers ensure the building will be strong and safe. Then, workers carefully construct it. The Sydney Opera House is a well-known modern building with an attractive roof. However, the building is beautiful from every angle, not just from above. The Olympic Stadium in Munich also has a famous roof. This unique building resembles a tent made of glass.'

Indre, I need your help with a problem. Can you go shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother is turning 80 next month, and she's having a party on Saturday. The issue is that I don't have anything to wear. I've grown a lot, and now all my trousers are too short! I want to buy some new ones and maybe a pair of boots. I don't have much money, but I think it will be enough. Would you prefer to meet in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika

Text: 'The Cerne Giant Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England, located close to each other. Between these towns, the landscape is filled with green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a large figure of a man, known as the Cerne Giant, named after the nearby village of Cerne. The exact time when the Cerne Giant was created is unknown, but it is believed to be from a very long time ago. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the figure. If you visit on the first of May at sunrise, you will witness the villagers dancing around the giant on the hill.'

Gail Rollins is one of the top runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she aims to compete in the 10,000 meters and possibly the 5,000 meters at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was famous for finishing second in major competitions. However, she was always cheerful and smiling, which made her popular in her hometown. Everything changed in 2004 when she participated in her first half-marathon, a long road race. She won with an impressive time, the fastest that year for any British woman. Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, used to race when he was younger but had to stop due to an injury to his right leg. He can still run a bit and sometimes trains with Gail, but it's tough for him when she speeds past and he can't keep up. Gail trains diligently, doing a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon, but she takes Sundays off to rest. "I'm with her all the time," says Mike. "Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually about cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

Ivan Petrov Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From age twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher couldn't play the piano but taught him and his sister opera songs. His mother started teaching him piano when he was six. By ten, he wanted to write music and soon composed his first song.

Oleg Gagarin was the youngest of five children. At four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him traditional Russian music. At six, he began lessons with a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly started winning piano prizes. At fourteen, he attended a music college in Austria for two years before returning to Russia.

Josef Heptmann's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and he began playing the piano a year later. He gave his first concert at six. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months in England! Josef always loved music but was also interested in physics and languages. He is very busy now but hopes to write his own music someday.

Bill Prince-Smith had various careers as a farmer, teacher, and dentist before he started writing children's books at 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written over 80 books. He writes every day in his office and in the evening, he asks his wife to read his work. "She tells me if she doesn't like something," Bill says. His ten grandchildren, who live far away, also read his stories and give their opinions. This feedback helps Bill understand what young children enjoy reading. 

Bill's stories are about life in his village and nearby farms. His favorite book is his fifth one, "The Sheepdog," which is about a farmer and his helpful dog. "I've always liked animals," Bill says, "and dogs are so smart; they learn quickly." Last year, "The Sheepdog" was turned into a film using real animals and actors. The filmmakers used advanced computer technology to make it look like the animals were talking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes filmmakers change books, but they didn't change mine, and I love the film," he says.

Text: 'POSTCARDS Today, people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually feature images of beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards while on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the pictures are often better than their own photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the nineteenth century, and it showed a picture of a seaside town. Later, postcards began to feature images of current events, like accidents or visits from important people. People liked these because newspapers at the time didn't include pictures.'

Text: 'Dinosaurs No one has ever seen a dinosaur because they died out about 60 million years ago, long before humans existed. The exact reason for their extinction is still unknown. Birds are the closest living relatives to dinosaurs. Dinosaurs varied greatly in appearance, with over 5000 different species. Some were very small, while others were enormous. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any other land animals that have ever lived. For instance, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as large, but it was more powerful. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run fast due to its long back legs.'

Text: 'BEARS Bears can be dangerous animals. Adult bears are very strong and can kill a person. They are good at climbing trees and can run very fast. However, they do not see well and, like most animals, they use their noses to find food. There are seven types of bears: The largest is the white polar bear, which can be almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: One lives in the forests of North America, and the other lives in Southeast Asia. Not all black bears are actually black; they can be dark brown or reddish brown. Everyone loves the black and white panda bear, which is from China. Today, not many pandas live in the forest because it is hard for them to find food.'

CROCODILES

Crocodiles live in tropical areas around the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually stay in slow-moving water but can move quickly both in water and on land. Crocodiles are often seen in large groups. They eat anything they can catch, including fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they even eat large animals or humans. There are over ten different types of crocodiles, all with very sharp teeth. They frequently lose their teeth, but new ones grow back quickly. Most crocodiles are about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much larger. Crocodiles can live for many years; the oldest one in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL

In 1783, two French brothers created the first hot air balloon that could carry people. Then, 120 years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers in the United States built the first airplane with an engine and flew it. By 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Over the next thirty years, airplanes underwent significant changes. In the 1950s, they became much faster due to the introduction of jet engines. In 1976, the Concorde was developed in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world, capable of flying at 2500 kilometers per hour, making the trip from London to New York just four hours long. Today, millions of people travel by airplane, and it's hard to imagine a world without them.

Text: 'The Globe Theatre Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was quite different from visiting a modern theatre. The building was circular, had no roof, and people would get cold and wet if the weather was bad. The queen enjoyed going to the Globe Theatre, located by the River Thames, to watch plays by William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. Visitors would eat, chat with friends, move around during the performance, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre has been built in the same area near the river. You can watch a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.'

Dear Jeff,

I'm having a great holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and it was cold. Now the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week, we are staying in Sydney, but next week we will go to the Great Barrier Reef. I loved swimming there because the water was so warm. The fish are all different here: red, yellow, purple! Australia is very beautiful. We don't want to come home!

See you at the end of September.

Sue
